It gets the little things wrong - and that matters - but the broad outlines right.
The year's most muddled piece of storytelling.
Hell or High Water is a rare humanist Western: Finality is the true villain.
After half an hour or so of ... stutter steps, Pete's Dragon starts working on you, much like those gold standards of the boy-and-his-otherworldly-friend genre, E.T. and The Iron Giant.
It's a wobbly, uneven, ultimately wonderful film - its unevenness befitting its title character, who we come to love despite her loopy lack of awareness of her own deficiencies.
It's visually resourceful and honest in how it sets up and delivers on its shocks. There isn't a single false scare.
Gallo's combination of crudeness and sophistication has a preternatural power.
The movie ends up seeming like an inchoate hybrid of melodrama and psychodrama-between the oceans, indeed.
There is such a thing as a passionate, headlong phony, and you'll meet her in Author: The JT LeRoy Story.
Stone is so intent on making Snowden an icon that he scrubs him of his nuances, his individuality.
Although it's patchy and gives off an air of trying too hard, the movie is surprisingly funny.
Lane is everything Arnold must have hoped she'd be. The longing is in her eyes, but her mouth, with its thick upper lip, suggests skepticism and a healthy self-possession.
Schamus's style is deliberate but not cold, and the performances he has elicited are passionately deliberate.
My only serious complaint about Deepwater Horizon is that it's not quite the muckraker I'd hoped for.
I was surprised by how closely it conforms, beat by beat, to the most ruthless Hollywood vigilante template. It's all about insults, emasculation.
A filmmaker has a feel for this kind of storytelling or doesn't, and the people behind The Girl on the Train don't.
Certain Women turns out to be a study in women's uncertainties, in the experience of pain that leads not to action but acceptance. It's a slow go - but you get there.
The Accountant is laughable, but when you're not laughing at it, you're laughing with it. It's enjoyable enough.
Hype would bruise Barry Jenkins's Moonlight, which is so delicate in its touch that the usual superlatives sound unusually shrill. It's the gentlest, most suggestive of great films.
Ron Howard's mostly lame adaptation of Dan Brown's wholly lame novel.
The surface is classical, while Park's perversity bubbles up from beneath.
[A] superb documentary.

Doctor Strange has a dazzling, kaleidoscopic palette that compensates for the usual thin-ish story featuring A-list actors zapping one another, along with a hero who looks fearsomely witty even in repose.
Much of Arrival - the part that sticks closest to its source, egghead sci-fi cult figure Ted Chiang's "Story of Your Life" - is an eerie, tantalizing, altogether superb puzzler.
The performances are very fine. Watching Negga, I was afraid to blink - I wanted to see everything that passed between Mildred and Richard, no matter how fleeting.
In the main 13th makes connections that haven't been made in a mainstream documentary before.
In the all-star movie adaptation of August: Osage County, another play that holds the stage with fang and claw feels less momentous onscreen.

Say what you will about Mad Mel Gibson, he's a driven, febrile artist, and there isn't a second in his war film Hacksaw Ridge - not even the ones that should register as clichés - that doesn't burn with his peculiar intensity.
A veritable orgy of immorality, each scene making the same point only more and more outrageously, the action edited with Scorsese's usual manic exuberance but to oh-so-monotonous effect.
The Coens' True Grit isn't as momentous an event as you might hope, but once you adjust to its deliberate rhythms (it starts slowly), it's a charming, deadpan Western comedy.
Although it falls off precipitously, it's better to have Julie Taymor's The Tempest than not: The first half-hour is nearly as unfettered as Shakespeare's language.
With a million times more computing power at its disposal than its 1982 predecessor, Tron: Legacy still looks like Disco Night at the jai alai fronton.
The sad part is that How Do You Know is nowhere near as dumb as it looks. A couple of comic set pieces are inspired -- or would be, if Brooks's timing weren't off.
The Kidman in Rabbit Hole is a revelation.
Blue Valentine leaves you with the shattering vision of its truest victim -- the one who'll someday look for safety in places it might not be. And the psychodrama will go on and on ...
Another year, another Mike Leigh gem...
Coppola's poor-rich-girl vision is certainly consistent, although you sometimes wonder if she knows that hers is not the universal human condition.
The Green Hornet doesn't seem worth the outrageous 3-D-glasses surcharge. In all senses, there's little that jumps out at you.

Perhaps the late Blake Edwards could have found a balance between slapstick and psychodrama, but Ron Howard can't get the pacing right, and Allan Loeb's script is even wordier than the one he wrote for Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps.

No Strings Attached is so palpably calculated that you know if the camera had pulled back a foot from the bed in which Portman and Kutcher were pretending to have sex, you'd have seen their agents standing by beaming: proud parents, proud pimps.
Kaboom might be borderline camp, but there's no spillover. Or perhaps it's the other way around. Perhaps Araki's vision of human sexuality is so fluid that the borders are always expanding.
It comes together neatly, perhaps too neatly to be ... poetry. But it's not prosaic, either. It has a lucid grace.
It helps that Reilly is the opposite of a slob-comic. With his hangdog melancholy, he makes even the nonstop cunnilingus allusions poignant -- the product of emotional longing.
The movie is cunningly woven to show the tension between his insane success and his determination to remain a sane, normal 16-year-old.

I find him such a bland, pious, profoundly unthreatening little Furby of a pop idol, but little girls' celebrity crushes are not to be trifled with. And this sensationally engineered promo film makes Justin Bieber look like a true force of nature.

Wild-eyed, long-haired Brits leap atop the Romans' shields as the soldiers blindly hack away, the bodies so close that you can barely tell the victor from the vanquished. The battles in the fog and rain have a hallucinatory power.
The doughy Damon and aristocratic Blunt don't match up physically, and they never get any Hepburn-Tracy rhythms going that might create some current.
A gross-out comedy about the perpetual immaturity of the American male that has, amazingly enough, a mature perspective.
Uncle Boonmee is entrancing-and also, if you're not sufficiently steeped in its rhythms, narcotizing.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Blessed is the go-for-it movie that can make room for dissonances and weirdness.
Wasikowska's Jane is as watchful as only a damaged soul can be, and, when challenged, frighteningly fast.
The movie has none of the smugness of American Beauty: You could dream of living in a world like this.
The movie has so much texture that once it gets you, you're good and got.
The CGI alien is very well articulated, and Rogen is a virtuoso at mixing motormouthed rudeness with a hint of tenderness to take off the edge.
[It] has so many terrible ideas that the terrible execution is almost irrelevant: Even if the film were well done, it would still be a travesty.
It's the sort of movie in which half the audience will be drying their eyes and the other half rolling them.
A haunting duet for two great actors who haven't lost a step and have gained the most exquisite lyricism.
Everyone in The Town shines, even Blake Lively, but it's Chris Cooper as MacRay's imprisoned dad who astounds.

Although Catfish is opportunistic, even borderline exploitive, it gets at -- by indirection, through the back door -- the magic-carpet aspect of this scary new medium. Real people are so complicated and irreducible, you know?

The movie belongs to Stone, that gorgeous, husky-voiced redhead. When most actors deliver nonstop patter, their mouths get ahead of their minds, but Stone's brain works so fast that her mouth can barely keep up.
As with many recent Stone projects, it's hard to tell what the focus is supposed to be.
This is one of the most galvanizing documentaries I've ever seen.
In his mid-70s and working mostly abroad, Allen has settled into a new groove. But it's not a deep or enlivening one. His despair has finally become weightless -- a reflexive shrug.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's lustrous, deep-focus frames and headlong pace are difficult to resist. Its an entertainingly cynical small movie.
The poetic Swedish vampire picture (with arterial spray) Let the Right One In has been hauntingly well transplanted to the high desert of Los Alamos, New Mexico, and renamed Let Me In.
You say Inside Job is a bit like a classroom documentary? Its a class you need to take.
Hereafter occupies some muzzy twilight zone, too woo-woo sentimental to be real, too limp to make for even a halfway decent ghost story.
Shot by shot, scene by scene, it's a fluid and enthralling piece of work. I wasn't bored for a millisecond.
Swank is overeager and humorless, and I got tired of looking at her big choppers, but for all that I liked her.

Larsson is renowned for his attention to marginal details, which gives his prose a rambling, one-thing-after-another pace that many readers find soothing. Onscreen, the lack of acceleration makes for one of those long Scandinavian winter nights.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ken Hixon's script contrives a lot of mutual-healing set pieces and then sadly but shrewdly aborts them...
As in his pithy, tuneful songs -- many written from different perspectives, in different styles -- Merritt is committed to stylizing his misery instead of boring you with it.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Exposed, abandoned, branded as traitors, the Wilsons finally have no choice but to tell their story, the latest chapter of which is this potent Hollywood melodrama starring Sean Penn and Naomi Watts.
It's probably easier for an ex-prosecutor known for macho threats to say he got caught screwing than for him to say he got screwed. But folks, he was reamed.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For Colored Girls is so shamelessly terrible it would make a great midnight hoot-fest, if you had the stomach to laugh at Shange or some of the best (and most underused) actresses of their generation...
Morning Glory isn't terrible. It has a lot of craft, a lot of star power, and a fair number of laughs. What irks me is that the filmmakers settle for so little.
Hallows's first hour is deadly, all right.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Made in Dagenham is perfectly shameless but shamelessly perfect.
It's a prizewinning combination, terribly English and totally Hollywood, and Firth is, once more, uncanny: He evokes, in mid-stammer, existential dread.
This is, no doubt about it, a tour de force, a work that fully lives up to its director's ambitions.
Bier dramatizes our ambivalence so earnestly that it's tempting to give her awards rather than admit that the movie is a crushing bore.
It's a crackerjack ride, shot and edited for maximum discombobulation.
The thing is scary as hell when it's all creaks and thumps and doors swinging open. Then come the explanations, the special effects, and the inevitable feeling of been-there-been-bombarded-by-that.
The movie looks wonderful.
July is working as hard as any artist alive to find new forms to express the dread of formlessness.
The movie has an unexpectedly high proportion of delights to groaners, and it's full of actors you'll want to see...
Cowboys & Aliens is an agreeable time-killer, but I'll bet a couple of clever kids could make a livelier movie with a Woody puppet and a Predator doll.
It's wall-to-wall sci-fi pop-culture bric-a-brac, yet it feels organic. There's something more at stake than the fate of a movie-ish Earth.
You can study it, like a painting, and then realize, with a gasp, that it has got hold of you like a fever.
The Help belongs to Viola Davis.
Norton is an amazing actor, a hot-dog whose delight in transformation is infectious.
There's bad acting all around, but you can't fully blame the performers. The dialogue needed a writer to come in and punch it up - the lines sound like placeholders.
It's 80 minutes of dead air.
The movie is flushed with hope, wonder, heartbreak.
After a gripping first half, turns into one howler after another. And yet it's still gripping.
It's too corny to live. But the picture is a slam dunk. I mean a ground-and-pound double-leg takedown. It's really gripping.
Contagion is compelling.
Why would Gosling, a fascinatingly cerebral actor, take a role so far inside his comfort zone? Does he long to strike action-icon poses -- to be the new Nic Cage?
Parker reminds you what a dizzy, all-in, high-risk comic actress she can be when she's not too busy showing off the couture.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The movie doesn't quite come together, but it's full of smart, cynical talk, and it's very entertaining.
I hate to damage so fragile a work with overpraise, but, gay or straight, if you don't see yourself in this movie, you need to get a life.
Katie Galloway and Kelly Duane's nonfiction account is eerily suggestive -- and alarming.
Nichols has a genius for making landscapes and everyday objects resonate like crazy, for nailing the texture of dread.
What a tightrope this movie is.
This is the first bad movie that has ever made me call for a sequel -- to get it all right.

It's tempting to praise The Ides of March as a realistic depiction of how low we've sunk. But that would mean accepting the second-rate writing and third-rate melodrama and incredible shrinking characters.
It's a straight hagiography, without nuance or ambiguity or the admission of opposing viewpoints, even those meant to be dismantled.
Tabloid is candy for voyeurs. We laugh like mad at a nut whose only mistake was being born in the last century, too early to have made real money.
HPATDH 2 works like a charm. A funereal charm, to be sure, but then, there's no time left for larks.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Marsh's documentaries are inspired fusions of content and style, and here, the artistry intensifies the pain.
American Psycho is nearly perfect for what it is, but before we go on, we should ask what that actually amounts to. Can something with so rigid a thesis be a real work of art?
A cunning weave of low and high, regal and smutty, splendiferous and splattery.

What keeps us hooked is Ronan, a young actress of seemingly limitless abilities, and the tension she creates between Hanna's inhumanly agile body and quizzical eyes, which turn cold only when she pulls the trigger.
Redford does a fine, economical job re-creating the horror of the assassination, the dying president barely glimpsed but the bowls of blood carried from his deathbed all too vivid.
Russell Brand gives a career-killing performance.
Reichardt's westward-ho is a world of confusion, geographical and moral, a dislocation beyond the remedy of water or Bibles.
The movie doesn't quite jell, but you'll feel its sting for hours.
It's surprising that The Greatest Movie Ever Sold plays so entertainingly, given that Spurlock's quest is essentially beside the point.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Amusing and annoying in the wrong ratio, maybe 30/70.
Cave of Forgotten Dreams is sometimes frozen by Herzog's awe. But it's hard not to love him for always trying to look beyond the surface of things, to find a common chord in the landscape of dreams.

The movie's glumness is in synch with Foster's performances over the last decade: It's as if she's decided that acting is something you mature beyond. Which I suspect had a dampening effect on Gibson's performance.
There's a thrilling madness to Phoenix's Method.
There's something appealing about the movie's unpretentious carnival of carnage, although I could have done without the flamethrower assault on a school bus to raise the stakes.
Has a mixture of bloodletting and exultation that would make Sam Peckinpah sit up in his grave and howl with pleasure.
That lawn with its scraps of a ruined life is a setting both satirical and poignant, and Will Ferrell gives a performance of Chekhovian depth.
A giant notch up is Hiddleston, who'd make a good Edmund in King Lear: You register the chip on his shoulder rather than the villainy.

This supernatural comedy isn't just Allen's best film in more than a decade; it's the only one that manages to rise above its tidy parable structure and be easy, graceful, and glancingly funny, as if buoyed by its befuddled hero's enchantment.
I've never seen a film in which what was actually onscreen seemed so irrelevant.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Will you find it ridiculously sublime or sublimely ridiculous? Don't be afraid to find it both.
Arthur might have stolen this one were it not for a cast that inspires you to empty out your bag of superlatives.

It would be easy to dismiss as 100 percent ersatz if it didn't rekindle at least some of the old excitement -- and if the magic of Spielberg's older movies didn't filter through, like light from a distant galaxy.
Apart from having no particular reason to exist onscreen, especially at these prices, it's not half bad.
It's well and good to hear Buck and others tell his story, but the film wouldn't come to much if you didn't feel the connection between his present and past in every frame.
The film is sometimes gentle to the point of blandness, but it's never flimsy.
There's too much lustrous-hued loitering and too few martial-arts set pieces. This isn't another disposable B movie, though.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is ham-handed, repetitive, and rhythm-less -- a mess that's uglier than its hero and nowhere near as likable.
It takes you back to an era of arty, angst-ridden European existential pulp movies that were like abstract essays on the genre.
It becomes a meditation on the dual nature of film, on a "reality" at once true and false, essential and tainted.
The best part is Jemaine Clement as Benjamin's grandiose genre hero, Dr. Ronald Chevalier. Even if you love him on Flight of the Conchords, you'll be unprepared for his genius -- and charisma.
It's all so glancing and superficial that the movie doesn't seem to have a present tense. It goes by like coming attractions. It is, however, a treasury of bad biopic dialogue.
Daniels does everything to hold the melodrama at bay, but there's only so much he can do.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A portrait of one of the world's great companies by one of the world's great vérité documentarians.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The additions are okay; but it's the look that keeps you buoyed up, your eyes roaming the frames, laughing in surprise at the visual jokes and flourishes and textures. It's a dandy's movie, but that adds to the fun.

Any war picture in which the heroine stalls the villain with a quiet, painstaking tea ceremony until the wind shifts direction and the good guys can firebomb the bad guys into oblivion is too ineffably Zen not to love.
Evocative as it is, The Road comes up short, not because it's bleak but because it's monotonous, and because McCarthy's vision is finally as inflexible as his patriarchal hero's.
I'm not sure how Morton made sense of her character's ebbs and flows, but I never doubted her. She's a mariner in uncharted seas of emotion.
If there's a sure thing in movies, it's that if you cast Nicolas Cage in a role in which he goes crazy, he'll rise to the occasion and keep on rising until he seems even loonier than his character.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pedro Almodóvar's Broken Embraces is a lush, deeply romantic noir dense with nods to films past, yet it plays as if it sprung fully formed from the director's unconscious.
Too many films exploit the perils faced by children when the social contract is ruptured, but Mammoth earns its cruel, sensationalistic turns and then some.
Weitz's pacing is so limp you're going to need the electricity generated by a live audience to keep from yelling, "Hurry it up!"

Sheridan pulls you so deep into Brothers so fast that there isn't time for the alarm bell to go off that says: "Warning! Another Traumatized-Vet Movie!" You never catch Sheridan or Benioff grandstanding, only observing.
Clooney -- slim, dark, perfectly tailored -- glamorizes insincerity in a way that makes you want to go out and lie.
The narrative would be ho-hum without the spectacle. But what spectacle! Avatar is dizzying, enveloping, vertiginous ... I ran out of adjectives an hour into its 161 minutes.
By now we've seen so many good, bad, and indifferent Sherlocks that it's almost a relief to get something different, however wrongheaded. And there's no such thing as too much Downey.
Haneke doesn't deign to deliver the genre goods-resolution, catharsis, etc. That way he can crudely spell out his themes and yet still give the bourgeois audience the finger.
The final scenes have a transcendent mixture of hope and sadness. I've never seen anything like Mia's final dance, or the leave-taking with her little sister that follows.

I love this new breed of dirty movie. It goes beyond leering, beyond sexism, to the core tension of a culture that ricochets between Puritanism and promiscuity. And it has in Michael Cera a sterling mascot.
The movie is unfailingly likable and finally impressive. Goldin doesn't settle for easy answers, and he makes you think that no one should.
The movie has its evocative moments, but it's so rigged on the side of anti-intellectualism that you'd never guess that Tolstoy's late work inspired Gandhi and Martin Luther King.
Anyway, I cried. A lot. What can I say? I'm a sucker for kids on ventilators.
Steve Buscemi cuts so droll and heart-wrenching a figure in Hue Rhodes's deadpan road movie Saint John of Las Vegas that the plot -- shaggy and inconsequential as it is -- gets in the way.
It's a testament to Saavedra's tough performance that even with a happy ending, you wouldn't want to leave her with your kids.
In the light of day, it's all very silly and conventional. But of course we're not talking about the light of day.

Instead of being bombarded by computer illusions, we're allowed to suspend our disbelief, to bring our own imaginations into play. For all the artfulness, the feel of the film is rough-hewn, almost primitive. It's a fabulous tree house of a movie.
Quite enjoyable, even for those of us who don't follow British "football."
It's as if Farhadi became too depressed by his own cynicism to keep the drama humming. The movie turns into a dour demonstration of missed connections.
When actors like these are cooking, it's better than haute cuisine.
The movie is an ungainly pastiche, yet on some wacked-out Jungian level it's all of a piece.
To call this the best shrimp-from-outer-space South African apartheid allegory ever made does not begin to do it justice. But it's a start.
The lead actress, María Onetto, holds you through the longueurs.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I'm over the moon about this movie, which smooths out the psychological dissonances in Audrey Niffenegger's fine novel but is still an emotional workout.
The cutting is hyperkinetic, yet Lee is always in synch with the cast's phenomenal energy. He's in their thrall -- and so are we.
Lee and his producer and screenwriter, James Schamus, have turned Tiber's book into a gentle, rather tepid film. Its first half is modest and likable, but it goes on for over two hours.

Zombie isn't a storyteller, he's a wallower. And because his movies take place in a culture of violence and sadism, there's nothing for Michael Myers to do except echo what's already there and slaughter weaker sadists.
For all the Saturday-matinee heroics, the movie is dreary and monotonous, the vision junky in more ways than one.
No Impact Man -- the film and the book -- could well end up instruction manuals.
The effect is to clobber you with lines that were already clobbersome and needed no extra emphasis. It starts to feel less like a thriller than an actors' workshop.
Berlinger doesn't counter Chevron's counter charges with facts and figures. With footage of petrochemical-sludge swamps and babies covered with flaming sores, he doesn't especially need to.
What keeps all this from seeming overmelodramatic is Schneider's huge performance, which is too hilarious. All costume dramas need actors this rude.
The Informant! does raise a fascinating question: How can humans so compartmentalize their psyches? But Whitacre has no stature -- he's just a nut.

So many people risked their livelihoods to put the 7,000-page Pentagon Papers out there -- although its most tangible result was the creation of Nixon's plumbers unit. We have not celebrated Daniel Ellsberg enough. Let's begin.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is something rare, a boisterous American comedy with the power to trigger philosophical disputes -- even, if taken really seriously, fisticuffs. One can hope!

John Krasinski's adaptation of David Foster Wallace's ... Brief Interviews With Hideous Men works only in spurts, but when it does, it's enough to remind us how much deeper our dramatists could drill -- and of the magnitude of Wallace's loss.
As picturesque period biopics with too many symmetrical compositions go, Anne Fontaine's Coco Before Chanel is surprisingly intimate and nuanced.
A Serious Man is not only hauntingly original, it's the final piece of the puzzle that is the Coens.
Moore relates a half-century of fraud in singsong narration that makes him seem like Mister Rogers with 200 extra pounds and a Che Guevara T-shirt instead of a cardigan. But what a figure he cuts.
Barrymore hovers over her actresses like the nicest, most nurturing den mother imaginable, and on its own, Go For It formula terms the movie delivers.
Lone Scherfig's direction is glum. We're so clued in to what's really going on that we never share Jenny's authentic excitement at being introduced to art, music, and exotic locales.
This movie is glorious testimony to the moral power of satire.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You'll never hear an economist explain derivatives again without thinking of the woman who walks away from the camera, weeping, as her mortgage broker refuses her check, or children's dolls splayed out on the floors of empty homes.

The movie is a reductio ad absurdum, a sick joke taken to extremes, beginning with a goof on the notion that horror movies inspire copycats and ending with a test to determine whether some people will watch anything.
Morel will inevitably be compared to John Woo, whom he trounces. He has fewer mannerisms and a keener eye; his fastest, most kinetic shots flow together like frames in a flipbook.
Edge of Darkness is a meathead revenge picture, but it's very satisfying.
Robin and Marian are played by a scowling Russell Crowe and a grim Cate Blanchett, who has the face of a wooden squaw stained by decades of cigar smoke. I can't remember a more un-fun-looking couple.
Holy Rollers fuses a somber, old-world palette with a jittery urban unease -- a good mix of tones. It's also wonderfully acted.
It's smoothly written and smartly paced, and Michael Douglas is riveting.
Given all the weighty colloquia, Agora has remarkably few bad laughs, and the CGI re-creations of ancient Alexandria are so detailed I wanted to freeze the frame and linger on the city's layout.
The most depressing thing about Sex and the City 2 is that it seems to justify every nasty thing said and written about the series and first feature film.
Survival of the Dead almost never snaps into focus. Even its oxymoronic title doesn't work. It feels marginal, like an extended footnote.
For all the horror, it's the drive toward life, not the decay, that lingers in the mind. As a modern heroine, Ree Dolly has no peer, and Winter's Bone is the year's most stirring film.
This is a thoroughly exhilarating, thoroughly depressing portrait of the agony and ecstasy of celebrity.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This wistful little film is at just the right temperature.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The gags are all of a piece, right up to the forlorn yet enchanting finale.
Restrepo is, on its own terms, a stunning piece of work, but to get even more from it you should buy Junger's book, WAR, which expands on the footage we see.
The title, like Nicole Holofcener's Please Give, is one that trails you out of the theater and gives you something to brood on.
The journey is thrilling -- even if, on some level, you know that these kids are going in circles.
A remarkably flaccid effort -- much lamer than its predecessor, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, which was pedestrian and sleazy but hit its marks.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I wanted to surrender to this dream; I didn't want to be out in the cold, alone. But I truly have no idea what so many people are raving about.
Solondz conjures a world that's rotting away from the inside, in which only the children -- freckle-faced Dylan Riley Snyder and Emma Hinz -- weep over the loss of moral authority.
[A] frustrating, borderline exploitative, madly entertaining documentary.
Salt is a senseless blast.
Ward plays Reagan as not just engaged but swaggering and overexcitable -- a fun revisionist performance. But this is Kusturica's movie.
The film is repetitive, top-heavy: Wright blows his wad too early. But a different lead might have kept you laughing and engaged.
Michôd serves up Trainspotting-like tricks and narration that is beguiling, if rarely apropos. But the actors are something.
Patricia Clarkson is usually so "on" that it's a surprise to see her play a melancholy, passive woman -- and play her with such airy, elegiac grace.
Try not to hoot when the gaunt Roberts makes a bring-on-the-flab speech to persuade the equally slender Tuva Novotny to eat pizza, even if they get "muffin tops."
It seems that the hunger for celebrity is so fierce that people will exploit anything -- even their most embarrassing moments -- to attain some measure of it.

I'm not wholly clear on the link between a jellied green thing wriggling along a tree branch and the oneness of life, but Shinto Buddhist ruminations sound good in almost any context, and the film is entrancing.
Casino Jack is audience-friendly without turning into a Michael Moore-ish clown show.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Presents itself as an ethnographic meditation on the first year of life but is better approached as an "oooooh" and "awww" fest...
The music ties together all the pretty pictures, gives the narrative some momentum, and helps to induce a kind of alert detachment, so that you're neither especially interested nor especially bored.

movie_review_blurb: One of the lamest comedies of the year.
Intelligent, touching and, just maybe, a film to grab gongs come awards season.
Superbad director Greg Mottola casts an affectionate eye over the 1980s with a gentle but effective comedy.
An arty drama that's just a little too pretentious.

While both actresses deserve credit, it's Streep who dominates and deserves to be put in contention for her third Oscar. Deftly playing the dotty masterchef - complete with a brilliantly squawking laugh - it's an amusing but respectful imitation.
Warm and wise, it's a minor masterpiece.
Not just increasingly preposterous, it's also awfully dull since our two leads fail to generate even a hint of that spark so necessary for romantic dramas.
Like a 12-year-old playing their first guitar, it lacks polish and goes on too long, but you can't knock the enthusiasm. Great musical finale, too.
Aliens In The Attic is boring. Not just humdrum but deathly dull, as in stick-it-in-a-rocket-and-blast-it-into-space uninteresting.

So expertly put together, so beautifully written and filled with such brilliant and believable characters, it's no exaggeration to say we're in the throes of a golden age of animation not seen since Disney's heyday from the 1930s to the 1950s.
The jokes come thick but not fast before the sorry mess is put to bed with a dreadfully soppy ending.
A mirth-free endurance test, like holding your breath underwater.
Less a movie and more a series of sorry sketches, Dance Flick is about as bad as it gets.
Not only cheap looking and hard to follow, Shorts' big fault is that it's not funny - a major problem given it's meant to be a comedy.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: His latest is too long, too talkative and a touch too self-indulgent. But it's a heck of a lot better than anything he's done since Pulp.
Packed with awesome footage and revealing interviews, it's one to bust down the cinema doors to catch.
An energetic, enjoyable affair with plenty to say about unrequited love.
While a solid actioner, what makes it so special is a human heart that propels this wham-bam sci-fi film straight into deepest six-star territory.
Despite being entertaining, The September Issue fails to find out what makes Wintour tick, with the woman behind those ever-present shades remaining infuriatingly elusive.

Fish Tank takes you to places you never expected and, with pitch-perfect performances all round, makes for a beguiling and very real picture that conjures hope amid the most hopeless of surroundings. The best British film of the year.
Hobbled by a ruinously slow start, an utter lack of excitement and a twist ending that everyone will see coming, we're left with one of the year's worst.
In Jennifer Aniston's latest feeble romantic drama, almost nothing happens. Certainly not love or, indeed, much in the way of excitement.
The effects ring curiously hollow since the human side of the film is so undeveloped... Heed my warning and avoid this massive turkey.
An eerie, intelligent drama lifted into the realm of must-see territory thanks to Péter's gently nuanced performance, plus a haunting soundtrack.
[Bright Star] may have inspired some beautiful poetry but, here, provokes mere yawns.
A near-perfect blend of looks and heart.
While the idea's neat, there's no attempt to explore the weighty implications. It's a likeably quirky movie, mind, with Giamatti's hangdog features meaning a smile's never too far from your lips.
This limp biopic may inspire you to reach for the air sickness bag.
A gritty and exceedingly violent revenge thriller set in Broken Britain. It may be dour at times, but [Caine] turns in a very respectable performance.
While crisply shot and loaded with symbolism, chances are your intrigue will be snuffed out well before the credits eventually roll.
It takes a while to get going, but that only adds to the sheer terror of a horrifying final 20 minutes.
Whimsical but wonderful - and very worthy of those awards.
A piece of big, brash, brains-out popcorn fodder best savoured after last orders.
For a Christmas movie it's like waking up on Boxing Day and finding a toffee finger in your Quality Street tin.
Chaotic, self-indulgent and, most of all, hellishly boring.
A violent, egocentric but nonetheless fascinating character, it's a film to watch in horrified fascination.
Romeo And Juliet it ain't, but as a solid love story, New Moon gets the blood pumping.
A Serious Man may be the Coens' most personal film, but the humour's too oblique to truly trouble the funnybone.
By using such a typical family, it's a film most will be able to relate to, making it an inspiring, uplifting and, at the end, deeply moving mini masterpiece.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are amusing moments, but you'll need extra-sensory powers to spot the plot.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While zombie comedies have been done, ahem, to death after the success of Shaun Of The Dead, this time the laughs - and blood - flow thick and fast.
While George A Romero certainly won't be losing any sleep, failsafe ingredients - gore, guts and hotties making out with each other - make this a movie bound to appeal to teenagers everywhere.
Maddeningly slow and relying too much on shaky handycam footage - probably an economy measure - it's a promising debut from filmmaker Marc Price.
A visually inventive fantasy romp that's big on imagination, but almost impossible to follow.
The real mystery, mind you, is how a film this dreadful ever got made.
A fresh spin on the vampire myth resulting in a wildly inventive and blackly comic horror. Pity it's got more padding than the average fat suit.
Too much jaw, not enough gore.
A comedy deserving to be buried up to its head in sand, drizzled in cooking oil and then left to fry until crispy.

As an exercise in wringing every last penny from Jackson's legacy, the movie may be a success. But if you're looking for a tribute to the man who once took pop to its absolute zenith, this most certainly isn't it.
Get Carter meets Death Wish in an absurdly violent but lean and tense Aussie revenge thriller.

Veteran journalist Lynn Barber's memoir of a teenage romance makes a pleasing transition to the big screen. Yet, while it's well acted and tautly paced, you never quite shake the feeling you're watching a two-parter on BBC2.
While you long to root for 9 and his pals, it's hard to emotionally connect with such under-developed characters.
Alongside football hooliganism, mad cow disease and Joss Stone, the modern British crime movie may be the export of which we're least proud.
A stop-motion masterpiece sure to delight both children and adults alike.
Never letting up for a moment, you should go see - but prepare to be shocked.
This documentary is also as well made as anything released all year, blending hard facts, cold scientific reason plus the thrills of a Hollywood spy movie to terrific effect.
Like a dodgy old motor, this smutty comedy about car salesmen roars with life to begin with but putters to a stop all too soon.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Its high production values - not to mention the world's cutest poisonous spider - can't paper over a tepid and drawn-out plot.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While produced by the Wolf Creek team, the comparisons end there since it's more a humdrum hybrid of Cape Fear and Fatal Attraction, let down by few surprises and even less tension.
A romantic comedy so dull, so humdrum, they should give out free espressos at screenings.

Combining awayday punch-ups with bedsit brooding, the tortured relationship between the lads is generally lifeless. Things aren't helped by the film's sheer gloom, as if a layer of dust and grime lies over the camera lens. Missable.
A kind of anti-road movie, the first half is a genial rural snapshot but, when that bypass opens, the wheels come off and things take a turn for the surreal and boring.
Enjoyably gruesome, and with some timely comments about the recent craze for cyber-bullying, here's a horror perfectly pitched at its teenage target audience.
While mostly a straight-up doc, the film's enlivened by the occasional surreal flourish.
Fans of good old-fashioned storytelling will find plenty to enjoy, although the less patient may feel the film's title yawnsomely accurate.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The tunes are so bland it could be the same song on a loop, while the performances are spirited but nondescript.

Drag Me To Hell really is an unmissable experience, the sort of film that those with nerves of steel will want to see again and again. Scary, electrifying and very, very funny, you won't know whether to laugh or barf.
Beyonce's latest movie contains more laughs than the entire output of Jim Carrey, Will Ferrell and Eddie Murphy. Just one problem - Obsessed is meant to be a thriller.
It's not quite as good as the unfairly maligned first instalment but, for parents, this is a foolproof way of filling a slot over the Bank Holiday weekend.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing here we haven't seen before, the action is laid on thick and fast with plenty of explosions and car chases, making this Big Dumb Fun of the first order.
A pulse-pounding visual spectacle, given its bloodline this is the very least we expect. But when things aren't blowing up, T4 sags - and sags badly.
While not the most believable of screen couples, the pair's acting chops mean you won't notice that too much while the plot chugs along at a reasonable pace, helped by some occasionally amusing gags.
Prepare to gnaw you knuckles to the bone with this nerve-shredding French thriller that poses the question: How far would you go for a loved one?
A compelling and compassionate stranger-in-a-strange-land drama, it's a film brimming with insight, integrity and life. I reckon we're looking at one of the films of 2009.

A movie that has the same effect as a handful of Mogadon. It's so utterly dull they ought to give out prizes to anyone who keeps their eyes open to the end. Personally, I resorted to two carefully-placed matchsticks.
A big-hearted, earthy and highly amusing comedy, it's compassionate, feelgood fare of the very first order.
A sheer slog to sit through, Fireflies In The Garden might have worked if it wasn't so damn po-faced and the script actually had something to say about how families work.
It's a cerebral, smart and downright surreal trip into the far reaches of the mind. I'm still having trouble working out whether it's a work of genius or a self-indulgent pile of guff.
A relationships drama with almost nothing to say about relationships - except that they ain't easy - the only memorable thing about this is a supporting turn by former footballer Eric Cantona.
Bums and bosoms are in abundance, although there's not enough plot to go around, meaning you'll feel every minute of that two-hour running time.
Cribbing desperately from The Lord Of The Rings, Reign Of Fire, and especially Beowulf, it's a snorgasbord of awfulness.
A loopy comedy-drama every bit as mercurial as its protagonist.
It doesn't hit home quite like it should, but director Eran Creevy deserves credit for delivering something better than the usual Brit gruel.
The trouble is a twist ending that even a brain-dead centipede will see coming a long way off.
Even if you're not a superhero fan, Wolverine won't disappoint since, alongside some gloriously over-the-top action scenes, it's an intelligent, brooding movie.

The End could be criticised for being one-sided (none of the victims get a look-in). But that's missing the point, for at heart it's really a portrait of a long-gone era. In all, it's the best British crime film in years.
It's all good, clean fun but bland, corny and forgettable, too.
Alas, it swiftly ditches the pithy asides as it hurtles towards its treacly ending.
Witty, poignant and very touching, this is the British comedy of the year.
Overall, it makes for an entertaining, if uneven, couple of hours, although non-Trekkies may not find it the intergalactic go-see they'd hoped for.
There's little in this period piffle to engage or entertain.
Filled with backstage tears and onstage triumph, the film neatly captures the sheer awkwardness of being a youngster. Go see.
Little Ashes is an arthouse film filled with bare bottoms, full-frontal nudity and gay passion. You can practically hear Pattinson's army of girl fans weeping into their popcorn.

While there are punch-ups aplenty, it's less concerned with bruised knuckles and more interested in the bruised personalities of its protagonists, making for a thoughtful, if rarely electrifying, movie.
There may be a decent thriller here, but it's buried alive beneath turgid pacing and ream upon ream of dry-as-dust dialogue. Oh, and Ewan McGregor's in it - rarely a good sign.
Lewd, crude and exceptionally rude, the gags come thick and fast.
A chilling exploration of how our love affair with seafood is devastating the world's oceans while pushing species after species to extinction.
Predictable, pointless and pathetic.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So depressing, life-sapping and unrelentingly nihilistic, words have yet to be invented to convey the sheer awfulness of this so-called thriller. A contender for worst film of 2009.
Actress Melissa Leo rightly earned an Oscar nomination for her part in this downbeat drama.
While it's an occasionally unsettling piece - and comes with a big-name cast - the story never goes anywhere.
Predictable rom-coms can work if the comedy and chemistry are there. Alas, both have gone AWOL. There's a dry and silent desert where the jokes are meant to be.
It's ploddy, affected and ludicrously nasty but, for all that, Lars von Trier's new movie could well be the best horror film since the genre's 70s heyday.
Cracking along at a fast pace with a plot full of twists and turns, it's a first-rate thriller and one bound to get the Hollywood remake treatment very soon.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The linear A-to-B storyline gives the film a TV movie feel, with an overdose of melodrama not helping matters.
Tony Scott has made a film that, for sheer fun and breathless tension, leaves the summer's other actioners parked in the sidings.
The crude humour is as unfunny as it is ill-judged. Set to become a favourite of bad movie clubs everywhere.
The plot lurches joylessly from A to B, while the bored-sounding voice cast - Nicolas Cage, Penélope Cruz, Sam Rockwell - might have delivered their dialogue down a phone line.
The whole thing's about as enjoyable as a holiday to Guantanamo Bay. Less a movie and more a two-hour finger wag.
While visually gorgeous, there's little to engage the heart with few surprises within the linear storyline. Meanwhile, Tautou looks a lot like an actress who is out of her depth.
It's big, it's dumb and its cast won't be winning any acting awards, but for all that, the film delivers a two-hour blast of fun sure to delight the kid in all of us.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: While [Heigl] and co-star Gerard Butler give good performances, the film's the same predictable fluff we've all seen before - and seen done better.
A movie guaranteed to enchant all. Mind you, with a cast this cute, they couldn't really fail.
Like a feud between Dannii Minogue and Cheryl Cole, you don't care who wins, but it's fun to watch. Alas, the preceding 80 minutes aren't. Great title, lousy film.

Burma VJ (Video Journal) is as gripping as any Hollywood thriller - and as heartbreaking as any weepie as we watch the celebratory mood that briefly blossomed in Rangoon give way to appalling violence.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sticking closely to the conventions of the Evil Child movie genre, there are few surprises (or even scares) as we saunter towards that absurd ending. Just about worth a punt on DVD.
One space odyssey you're unlikely to forget.
It's all very slender stuff and very hard to care about the characters, most of whom whine rather than speak their lines. All in all, it's a life that should have stayed private.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Big, loud and definitely not clever, it's a giant, lumbering idiot of a movie that, were it not for all the explosions, would send the most devoted action fans to sleep.
Telstar is a rambling, chaotic mess that's got missed opportunity written all over it.
An indie comedy that's been kooked to a crisp. Wearing its quirkiness on its sleeve, the whole thing's just too self-consciously strange to engage.
While there's a good leading performance, after about half an hour you may notice your ability to give a damn also disappearing.
A touch hard to tell what's going on at times, the film comes into its own towards the end as it portrays with shocking candour the genocide that still reverberates in Eastern Europe to this day.
Ice Age part three - a competent water-treader which use a cast of cutesy animals to disguise their lack of ambition.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in pin-sharp high-definition, this is one amazing-looking movie, where even the most ordinary scenes crackle with energy and suspense. As with Heat, Mann's made not just the crime drama of the year, but possibly of the decade too.
A horror with a sense of its own absurdity, it's a cult classic in the making.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This illuminating doc looks back on the Philly singer's life and times. It reveals a vast talent who lost his way through a combination of drugs and bad business decisions.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A very satisfying, if emotionally draining, experience. Needless to say you should take a large box of hankies - plus a bottle of water so you can rehydrate afterwards.
Comprised of jokes that wouldn't amuse a five-year-old, and looking as if it was knocked together over a weekend, Year One delivers about as many laughs as I Spit On Your Grave.
It's a film so achingly average it almost deserves an award for mediocrity.
One of the funniest things you'll ever see.
As an in-your-face way of confronting ageism, it certainly does the trick, although I'm still feeling a bit queasy having just watched a granny drop her bloomers.
While Soul Power is bound to be compared to the Oscar-winning Ali/Foreman documentary When We Were Kings, it never scales the same heights.

A music film best appreciated with earplugs firmly in place, it's not just the unholy sound that's a turn-off but its inability to tell us anything interesting. The result is dry, unilluminating and, frequently, ear-splitting.
Not glorious. Not good. Just plain old-fashioned duff.
Like one of those Cosmopolitan cocktails, it's guaranteed to leave women everywhere with a warm, fuzzy glow. For men, it's like all your hangovers came along at once.
Boasting plenty of gore in some suspiciously well-lit caves, fans of the original will find little to complain about.
The film's attempts to not just humanise but to make us like the bombers undermines the comedy.
He's survived six sequels, a grudge match with Jason Voorhees and a terrible TV spin-off, but this remake may finally finish Freddy Krueger once and for all.
As far as time-travelling farces go, file this under John and Chev's Sucky Adventure.
The best thing you can say about Furry Vengeance is that it's kid friendly -- provided, that is, the kids are under five and a touch slow.
Like Das Boot, only on caterpillar tracks, it's tense and claustrophobic, with the soldiers not gung-ho beefcakes but scared and doubtful young men who'd rather be anywhere else.

Packed with interviews with his family and friends, some fine animation and plenty of highlights from his shows, it's an illuminating and often moving affair although not quite as funny as it should be.
It's not a movie -- it's a piece of product.
It's not just the subject matter of impossible love that recalls Brokeback Mountain, but the same aching sadness and pathos.

There's simply nothing good about it. The special effects are ropey, the plot creaks, the performances are indifferent and - worst of all - it patronises the viewer with dialogue that explains what's about to happen at every turn.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Cop Out marks a new low which is really saying something given that Smith's the man behind Mallrats, Chasing Amy and Jersey Girl.
As a police procedural, it's a generally dull affair. As an exercise in silliness, it elicits a fair few laughs. But whether the joke's on Herzog or on us is anybody's guess.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An hour and a half of globetrotting, things blowing up in slow motion and not a whole lot else.
An edgy and ambitious crime thriller that feels like a homegrown Tarantino movie.
A rerun of the first film only with less tension, more gore and characters who behave a bit more stupidly.
Ravishingly beautiful, immersive and with terrific performances from the two leads, it's a real gem.
Maybe it's time for Hess to go back to Napoleon Dynamite for a sequel. Although, on second thoughts, perhaps he should leave well alone.
While it's quite watchable, The Last Song doesn't feel like a film that's been made so much as assembled from standard teen movie clichés.
It's a slow-burning Austrian thriller with no stars, no special effects and, by the looks of it, almost no budget. But sometimes a little goes a long way.
It's not in 3D, you won't have heard of the cast, and I suspect the budget was in the low five figures. However, this tender little gem is as good as anything you'll see this week.
Beautifully animated, genuinely touching and with a terrific climax, it's the perfect family film.
Unlike most Hollywood teen product, here fulfilment comes not from what others think of you but from what you think of yourself. In short, it's Girl Power reinvented.
As an example of how not to make a movie, Repo Men deserves to be studied by film students.
Subtitled and with laughs of the subtlest kind, Ben Hopkins has crafted a deliciously funny cautionary tale on the perils of greed and how globalisation can be a heartless mistress.
movie_title: The Market: A Tale of Trade (Pazar: Bir Ticaret Masali) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The result is certainly Polanski's best film in years and one can only hope his current legal woes - facing extradition to the US over his 1977 conviction in an underage sex case - don't detract from a thriller that oozes intrigue and Hitchcockian menace.
Despite the genial banter of Steve Carell and Tina Fey, it's a comedy with so few laughs it could be prosecuted under the Trade Descriptions Act.
Aside from being not all that funny, Judge's droll-ish observations on the small-mindedness of corporate America never hit the mark while there are too many go-nowhere plot diversions.
A film that'll make you laugh out loud -- and then make you want to wash your hands.
While it never quite manages to shake off the E4 vibe, it's good to see Grint stretching his wings.
It's not a bad idea, but just as you think you're watching a biting consumer satire, the plot instead descends into melodrama and soap operatics.
While there's a terrific battle near the start as the Romans are ambushed by the locals, the realisation soon dawns that this is a deeply average chase movie.
Get past the togas and its somewhat stately pace, and here lies a movie with a timely message about the perils of religious intolerance.
Given the strength of part one, the sequel is not just a terrific failure but a terrific disappointment.
Recalling one of those exploitation flicks so popular in 70s drive-ins, everyone involved deserves a pat on the back for producing such a fearless British movie. If only it was better.
While Johnson's as fun as ever to watch, he struggles with a weak storyline, lame gags and enough syrup to melt your fillings.
Overall, it's better than the original -- although that's not saying much.
Stylish, sweatily seductive and boasts career-best performances from the leads. It's just let down by a plot that runs out of steam 40 minutes before the end.
Look for your kicks elsewhere.
That rarest of things, a big-budget actioner that's almost impossible to enjoy.
What should have been yet another unnecessary, not-as-good-as-the-original is actually miles, miles better.
A pedestrian Australian drama that's big on scenery and long, meaningful silences but short on story.
Kids will need to be positively subnormal to enjoy a film this dreadful.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The sheer imagination brought to the screen -- not to mention the tunes -- make this a film j'adore.
[Lacks] the balance you'd expect in a documentary.
While it's not a particularly imaginative movie, it's a great-looking one...
Plotwise, this is a slow dance indeed, with the players partnered-up with club-footed clichés and some deeply one-dimensional characters.
With its idyllic scenery, neat metaphysical twist and subtly-conveyed message, it's a weepy guaranteed to fill tissues.
It's a reasonable enough romp, but Tom Cruise with a gun still makes me uneasy.
If you're a kid whose summer holidays are starting to drag, this should kill a couple of hours. Just do your folks a favour and don't make them come along.
Outta sight!
The novelty quickly fades since -- you guessed it -- the story's just not there.
[A] slice of self-important nonsense that's actually pretty funny, although probably not in the way Shyamalan planned.

Having observed Seth Rogen's latest comedy, may I report that it's not very good. And if that seems like a tedious pun (even by my standards), that's because I've just sat through an hour and a half of them.
I doubt we'll see better all year.
Much better than you might expect.
It stars former pop queen Tiffany, who topped the charts in 1987 with I Think We're Alone Now. Visit a cinema showing this and the chances are you'll know what she was singing about.
It's a surreal little film with an intriguing Freudian subtext and a haunting blend of magic and gritty realism.
It's not half as bad as it sounds thanks to the likable, grounding presence of Baruchel, plus Nate Torrence as his chubby pal.
It's one of those films whose fun set-up is terrific, only to be offset by the muddled plot. Still, there are some decent laughs amid the mess.
Although slick and occasionally tense, it's also downright predictable and occasionally boring. In fact, top Gere it ain't.
It's hard to convey the sheer awfulness. And that's not just me being a grumpy bloke confronted with a chick flick.

Are you a movie star nobody takes seriously? Are you fed-up with being cast in dumb comedies? Do you crave the respect of your peers? Then call Noah Baumbach, a director with a knack for extracting good performances from the unlikeliest of places.
While rough and ready, this is a documentary that makes us come to care very deeply for these lost souls, even if you suspect all they need to do is move down to Foster's.
movie_title: Shed Your Tears and Walk Away (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is mostly plain hilarious.
It has a noticeably 80s retro vibe, while the sheer inventiveness of the slayings paper over a very thin and familiar storyline.
Ladies, here's a chick-flick best enjoyed with your eyelids actually glued together.
If we all loved the first film, enjoyed the second and were disappointed by the third, this fourth and final entry ends the Shrek series on a satisfying high note.
Very much a slow burner, the tension is ratcheted up to near-suffocating levels, while Huppert and co-star Christopher Lambert give flawless performances.
Bright, breezy and just a little forgettable.
Chiselled from the same block of unhappiness as The Ice Storm, Thumbsucker and just about every other movie made by a depressed baby-boomer, it's yet more well-acted retro anguish.
Unlikely to light your fire, or anyone else's.
In a decade dominated by the three dreaded Rs of remakes, reimaginings and reboots comes a truly original blockbuster.
While essentially a larky comedy caper, the film's undertones of lost opportunity and growing old strike exactly the right emotional notes. It makes for a tear-jerking finale of the very first order.

It's so dull. While some actors have praised the movie for its accurate portrayal of backstage life, if you haven't trodden the boards it's much harder to get caught up in the A-to-B dramas facing the troupe, or Richard and Sonja's affair.
What director Louis Leterrier serves up is a simple quest movie enlivened by some respectable if rarely spectacular special effects.
It recalls Guy Ritchie's back catalogue but, thankfully, without the self-consciously frenetic camerawork. The result is slick and enjoyable, but has a whiff of déjà vu.
What might be the feelbad film of the year makes an early but convincing claim to be the film of 2010.
A sensational and very moving documentary shot undercover in Zimbabwe. The result deserves to be seen by everyone.
Already drawing waggish comparisons to The Apprentice, a more suitable comparison for a film this drawn-out and sterile might be Eight Characters In Search Of A Plot.
Daybreakers takes the undead in an entirely different direction, melding smart sci-fi with a timely political subtext.

[Serkis] outdoes even himself with a blistering portrayal of rock 'n' roll star Ian Dury that's sure to be one of the performances of the year. Sweaty, wide-eyed and maniacal, it's a turn that deserves to put him in serious awards contention.
A witty satire on TV news? No. An inspiring lesson about following your heart? Nope. The worst comedy you'll see all year? Oh yes.

Meyers steers a middle course between saccharine and sentiment with her latest, a warm, witty and wise rom-com focusing on the mating habits of fiftysomething Californians. Think Sex And The City for seniors.
The problem is a ho-hum storyline that feels as if it's been strapped to a rack and stretched to breaking point.
Delivering his killer one-liners with a gently raised eyebrow, Clooney impresses at every turn and is fast becoming one of Hollywood's subtlest comedy actors.
While the current trend in documentaries is to take stories and wrap them into neat little packages, Crude runs merrily against the grain.

Brothers is a film that fails on almost every level, coming with no meaningful message about the morality of war, saying nothing about sibling relationships and with the worst case of miscasting I can recall.
An emotionally draining but soul-stirring classic.
An underwhelming heist-gone-wrong movie that, inexplicably, has avoided going straight to DVD.
Owen is sensational, providing a sensitive, soulful presence that lifts the film, making for a touching and inspiring trip to the movies.

Winstone is in typically ferocious form, alternating between a heartbroken husk and a snorting bull, while Hurt spews foul language through a set of ill-fitting false teeth. Not terrible then, but not sexy - and certainly no beast.
Like sitting under the dentist's drill for 100 minutes, there's not a single, solitary laugh in the whole damn thing. In fact, it's a film so bad you actually start to feel sorry for the stars.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Spread is as fluffy as you can get, while you wonder how anyone could fall for someone like Nikki who dresses like a cross between Julian Clary and a far-right thug. Ghastly.
While there's little to hate, there's almost nothing to like in a film this anodyne. The jokes aren't funny, the performances are middling and the storyline predictable.
The Box is based on a 10-page short story and, while it was successfully adapted for a one-hour episode of The Twilight Zone, there's not enough for a feature, let alone one lasting two-hours.

While pretty much a cut-and-shut of every animated movie of the past decade, this sci-fi comedy should achieve blast-off with the under-10s. For adults, however, this is as solidly so what? as you can get.
It's fatally undermined by the lead, Sasha Grey, a real-life porn star who absolutely, categorically cannot act.
The effects are spot-on, little Max Records is ace as the story's boisterous nine-year-old hero while the film mostly avoids the treacle that mars so many kids' pics.
Uninspiring and, crucially, not all that scary. There are no attempts either to explore the killer's motivation and none of the original's black humour.
Jarmusch gives us a film designed to test the limits of our patience.
Very much horror-lite, here's a movie crying out for more claret to ramp up the sense of dread. Still, when dealing with the awful life-or-death decisions the survivors face, it's grimly effective.
Avatar truly is something else, a wondrously-detailed visual extravaganza quite unlike anything you've seen before.
An intelligent, low-key look at male sexuality which is sensitively handled. What a pity, then, that the ending's such a let-down... or an anti-climax, you could say.

While revealing almost nothing new about Lennon, and sticking rigidly to biopic conventions, it's just about worth catching thanks to Scott Thomas, who's spot-on as the arch but affectionate guardian.
With an unengaging plot, flat jokes and shameless product placement, Alvin is a late contender for worst film of the year.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: St Trinian's 2 isn't just appalling, it's like scouring those final, last-gasp instalments of the Carry On or Confessions Of... movies looking for a laugh.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is alive with cinematic magic, played out in an expertly-recreated capital full of grime, grubbiness and occasional grandeur.
Some great numbers and stunning set designs are let down by a failure to make us care about Guido's plight.
A Mexican drama that, while nice to look at, is deeply boring.

Despite an insanely visceral opening sequence in which limbs are severed amid fountains of claret, we're all too soon left with a tedious police procedural, sprinkled with the odd fight scene that confuses more than thrills.
A celebration of music and friendship, and a document of the vacuousness of Cool Britannia, documentaries don't get any better.
movie_title: Blur: No Distance Left to Run (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Although entertaining, if workmanlike, for the first hour or so, it gets too carried away with its conspiracies - plus Gibson's faux Boston accent is just terrible.
Somehow all the trauma never overwhelms the characters who feel real, particularly Precious herself whose silence conveys more inner sadness than a million words.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Another cynically violent, casually racist action movie that even Michael Winner would disown.
A troubling portrait of a country shaken by repossessions, exploitation and the rich sucking the life out of the poor.
While the two leads try their best, it's a losing battle with a plot this hackneyed, a script this underdone and some woeful supporting performances.
Burton doesn't just hit the bottom of the barrel but drills through the wood and starts tunnelling. Its only saving grace are the arresting, if familiar, visuals.
It's hard to see why the target audience would want to sacrifice two precious hours watching their own soul-sapping routines played out on the big screen.
Despite the religious trappings, Legion is an old fashioned shoot-'em-up with satisfying gunfights, a pacey plot and barely a dull moment. Dumb fun.
Rather than recalling the master of suspense, it brings to mind a straight-to-video cheapie you'd find in Blockbuster circa 1992.

It's all been done before, of course, and Case 39 is let down by too many of those jolting boo! moments, ropey special effects - check out a badly-animated hornet attack - plus a plot even casual horror fans can predict.
There's no doubt that Marty's still got it.
Old Dogs is a milestone in the [Travolta's] career, the moment when he trumped Battlefield Earth to make the worst film of his life.
I'm actually yawning as I type this.
The results are always less than hilarious.
A cult comedy classic in the making.
While the performances are passable, the plot is much less impressive as it journeys into dark and increasingly improbable waters.
More intelligent cinema-goers -- or perhaps just those who like their bloodshed well done -- will love every minute, relishing the jet-black humour and drinking in the Tom And Jerry-style violence.
This loose-ish remake, on the other hand, is slick, fast-paced and as bland as a bowl of tofu.
It's beautifully shot, nicely acted and about as dry as comedies get. In fact, it's so dry it might not be a comedy at all.
Filled with Jeunet's zany humour, fans will be impressed, although beginners should start with Amélie.
Robert De Niro's latest would-be weepy, Everybody's Fine, may remind you of About Schmidt's less-interesting brother. In fact, the title says it all - it's neither good nor bad, just deeply OK.

The issue of race is delicately handled, though, leaving you to hum along to Randy Newman's excellent score, laugh at the screwball interplay between waitress and prince, and drink in the terrific animation.
A characteristically skewed but cerebral look at a dysfunctional family in a movie much easier to admire than actually like.
A film that works thanks to characters who aren't mere ciphers but come with deep, if hidden, emotions.
79-year-old Clint Eastwood delivers yet another tub-thumping classic - a sports drama that'll have all but the most cynical cheering from their seats.

A masterclass in psychological horror. Funny, terrifying and with a central character to be both despised and pitied, here's a movie that once seen is very, very hard to forget - not necessarily a good thing.
The whole thing's a terrible mess and Cera's star, once rapidly rising, is now almost in freefall.

Welded together with parts from similar but superior fare such as WALL-E, Iron Giant and The Jetsons, the much-loved Animé character flies into cinemas for a toon that should just about keep the kids amused.
Tom Ford delivers the surprise of the year with a startlingly beautiful and sorrowful meditation on grief.
Sappiness overflows in a rom-com possessing little humour and all the romance of a bouquet of garage roses. The intention is to put a warm, fuzzy feeling in our tummies. Often it feels like nausea.
While the Hogwarts saga may be getting long in the tooth, at least it has decent characters and a sense of humour. This has neither.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the déjà vu there's plenty to enjoy, and not just for kids, from an earnest environmental message to animation that comes alive when seen in 3D.
No bones about it, Jackson looks like he's spent so long in front of a computer he's forgotten how to tell a story.
While you can't quite shake the film's Channel 5 matinee feel, star performances lift Crazy I Heart above the ordinary.
A movie with an important message and is an impressive debut from Morton.
A movie you can admire but rarely enjoy.
If you've seen Lorenzo's Oil, you'll know how it goes, but you're advised to tone down your expectations.
State Of Play's portrayal of the fine art of hackery gets it just right which, welded to a cracking storyline, makes for a first-rate movie.
... as humorous as diphtheria.
Faced with the choice of watching Dragonball: Evolution again and perishing in a fiery apocalypse, I'd take Judgment Day every time.
Don't know about you, but I've seen enough weird women with long hair and heard enough of those screechy violins and atonal sound effects to last a lifetime.
There are far better ways of keeping the kids happy.
What we have here is one of those very long, very slow dramas that might just have worked if the inevitable twist ending had been worth sticking around for. But it isn't.
The funniest thing I've ever seen in my life.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Little Children is a movie that defies easy categorisation. It's not quite a drama, not quite a love story, not quite a black comedy but rather a little of all three rolled together.
You'll be shaken. You'll be stirred. Heck, you'll be blown away.
A couple of years ago, this might have been something special, but with so many talking animal films out there, it just ain't.

Both actors put in terrific performances while the film captures the grim, grinding cycle of dependence just perfectly. But for all that, it's very hard to get excited about a film with so little to say about [such] rich topics.
Something hackneyed, trite and boring, you mean.
Sure, Night At The Museum isn't about to win any awards for originality, but this is a flick that exhibits a fine sense of fun.
Grabs you by the throat and never lets go.
The Covenant looks less like a movie and more like an extended boy band video -- and with about the same amount of depth.
The movie's flat-footed nature means it's unlikely to put a spring in the step of anyone over the age of 10.
Sweet, sentimental and sickly.
... a film that aims for the lowest-common denominator and falls even shorter.
Comedy doesn't get much blacker -- or more brilliant -- than this.
The result is simply spellbinding.
Crackling with energy, featuring great actors sinking their teeth into the meatiest of roles and a plot that bubbles with tension, this is Scorsese's finest film since Goodfellas.
There's the odd giggle, but nowhere near enough to keep things going.

Almodovar infuses proceedings with a horrible sense of self-satisfaction and also has a disconcerting habit of lots of lingering, leery shots of his lead actresses' bodies, including a pervy close-up of a teenage girl's groin.
Slow-moving, tasteless and totally devoid of ingenuity or charisma, this is a gross one-joke monstrosity - and that joke wasn't very funny in the first place.
Not Yet Rated is a doc that anyone with even a passing interest in movie censorship, sorry, classification, should seek out.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first shocker in ages where you actually care about what happens to the victims.
It's a movie that only sci-fi nerds are going to enjoy.
The hunt for the best comedy of 2006 ends, I suspect, right here.
Movies about moral choices work if we can relate to the characters' motivations, but that never happens here.

Some of the jokes here are funny. Most are not, while the characters are simply too silly to make us give two hoots about them. Worse, the movie collapses under the weight of a ton of syrup in the second half.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Seven days that shook the Monarchy to its very core are explored in this fascinating insight into the Royal Family following the death of Diana.
Presented by former US Vice President Al Gore, this documentary is a cool, clinical examination of global warming. And if you thought the repercussions were years off, think again.
The Canada-set Snow Cake is clearly meant to be Weaver's movie, and people with first-hand knowledge of autism say it's the most convincing depiction they've ever seen.

A film that boys aged 12 to 15 are going to lap up thanks to endless shots of Valance and her curvy co-stars in their swimsuits. But with a plot even flimsier than the bikinis, there's nothing here for the rest of us.
Really, there are only so many fart jokes a person can take.
It's a reasonably entertaining movie, but it comes nowhere close to the sheer, heart-pounding terror of the ultimate 9/11 film, United 93.
None of the cast are going to win Oscars for this, but then they're not meant to. Instead, all involved expertly keep the plot moving forward towards a reasonably satisfying ending.
Christian Bale proves yet again why he's one of Britain's best actors in this nightmarish, nasty but unforgettable thriller.
We can only hope the next instalment will have a little more fire in its belly.
Bookended by the terrible tragedy that befell Ai Qin and her friends, this is raw, heartfelt stuff - and enough to make you choke on your salad.
Everyone's favourite arachnid returns in his slickest, smartest and darkest movie yet.
It's a bit of a McMovie.
Probably the best family film you'll see all year.
Self-pitying and saccharine, this big whining ball of dross drags itself across the screen for two interminable hours, climaxing in a twist ending that comes with neon road signs attached.
Apart from a few nerve-jangling moments at the start and some snazzy digital effects, this is about as pointless and unnecessary as sequels get.
Occasionally moving but mostly dry.
Just imagine, if this movie was really good, it'd get five stars (2 + 3). Instead it gets a two. Which adds up to very little.
Rubbish.
KAPOW! The world's most boring superheroes return to lull us back to sleep in a sequel that could put the makers of Nytol out of business.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With its chirpy score, lovable characters and Festival Of Britain flavour, Grow Your Own would have bedded in nicely as a TV movie. On the big screen, it starts to wilt.
With shades of Psycho and The Birds, Vacancy sure isn't up there with The Master's finest work but, given that we haven't had a decent horror all year, it's a pleasantly creepy surprise.

GEORGE BUSH loves to lecture us about how his war on terror is all about preserving freedom and spreading democracy. What he doesn't tell us is how for the past 50 years, the US has covertly tried to crush both in a bid to control South America
The film gets three stars because it's such an impressive production - and of course the soundtrack kicks - but it'll still probably leave you feeling strangely cold.

Although Lucky You was made nearly two years ago, it seems Warner Brothers didn't quite know what to do with it, hence it being quietly slipped out in a quiet week between blockbusters. Maybe they hoped nobody would notice.
Give your money to charity. Throw it out of the window. Set it on fire. Just don't waste it by paying to see this.
Unlike the original, this version is never sure whether it wants to go to the dark side or not.
For a film with such high Oscar hopes, you'll leave the cinema wondering what all the fuss is about.
Touches are just enough to earn The Good Shepherd a third star. But De Niro might want to stick to acting in future.
It seems certain Whitaker will get that Oscar nod for superbly conveying Amin's weird mix of buffoonery and cold-bloodedness.

Using the kind of snazzy flashbacks, blood fetishism and moronic villains that were so in vogue oh, let's see, about 10 years ago, the action revolves around an assortment of rival hoodlums all gunning for police informant Buddy 'Aces' Israel.
