Cho continues her exploration of the outer limits of raunch with considerable brio.
In addition to lively interviews with surviving Cockettes features a dizzying array of vintage footage of the troupe in action.
While this has the making of melodrama, the filmmaker cuts against this natural grain, producing a work that's more interested in asking questions than in answering them.
The sight of the spaceship on the launching pad is duly impressive in IMAX dimensions, as are shots of the astronauts floating in their cabins.
This is darkest drama reminiscent of Antonin Artaud's literary experiments in psychoanalysis.
A lot has happened in the 25 years between Rob Epstein's Oscar-winning 1984 documentary and Gus Van Sant's biopic, but the subject of the nation's signal gay rights leader is as relevant as ever.
In short, audiences may be buying a ticket to see Dean Cain kiss another guy, but there's a lot more to The Broken Hearts Club than that lovely sight.

Director Jamie Babbit and screenwriter Brian Wayne Peterson haven't attacked their target as effectively as they might, but as mild as it may be, Cheerleader underscores the fact that gender roles are ideological in nature.
... shows that there's a lot more to this sordid story than first meets the jaundiced eye.
In short, it's a moment, and a film, about compassion.

Sienna Miller captures much of Edie's physical manner and some of her voice (though she's nowhere near deep enough), but there's nothing she can do with material that requires her to mope and pout for the bulk of her screen time.

Although it spins in circles for too long before its climactic wheat-field shoot out, no other Taviani brothers film so vividly captures the prevailing ethos of their life's work: "Living may be tragic," Vittorio once said, "but life isn't."
movie_title: La Notte di San Lorenzo (Night of the Shooting Stars) (The Night of San Lorenzo) (1982)

movie_review_blurb: A rare reboot so foul and humorless it makes you question whatever attachment you might have to the original, this lazy retread of Harold Ramis's 1983 Vacation sours everything that's made that film such an undying fixture of basic cable.

Mistress America nimbly vivisects how we define ourselves in an age when Twitter allows people to broadcast their achievements so widely that every cell phone doubles as an EKG machine for our self-worth.
In the proud tradition of le cinema du Ritchie, The Man from U.N.C.L.E. is yet another film in which its aesthetics are both its greatest virtue and its most ghastly weakness.
I just can't take this film seriously.
The film's difficult approach allows for a singularly vivid expression of dementia.
All the gentle loveliness doesn't add up to much.
A sci-fi thriller so derivative of John Frankenheimer's masterfully paranoid Seconds it would be more accurate to call it Thirds, Tarsem Singh's Self/less is a generic waste of a clever idea.
A reinvigorating reminder of what indie filmmaking can -- and should -- do.

In the '70s, this would've been an unusually intimate tour portrait. Now, it's a newly unearthed time capsule, the remarkable clarity of Blank's portrait compounded by the distance from which we're looking at it.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Even the jokes that do work leave some laughs on the table, and the impulse to play things safe proves emblematic of a film that shrinks in the face of a challenge.
When you've got Benicio Del Toro playing Pablo Escobar, the rest is just icing on the cake.
Sally Draper leaps to the big screen in this slight, sumptuous drama about teleporting teens.

A vividly told but crushingly literal dramatization of an event that's in every psych textbook published during the last 40 years, Kyle Patrick Alvarez's new film is compelling and useless in equal measure.
Trainwreck is both the best romantic comedy of the year as well as its most crushing disappointment.
Sarandon's exuberant performance is delivered with care and conviction.

Riveting from start to finish and profoundly crowd-pleasing in its later stretches, The Keeping Room is a spare but unsparing film that empowers its women by allowing them to find a power of their own.
This spry, sharp and relentlessly clever middle finger to censorship is Panahi's boldest act of defiance to date.

A sweet, shambling, supremely enjoyable road movie about two compulsive gamblers of very different stripes, it could easily be confused for one of Alexander Payne's wounded comedies, albeit one with higher stakes and a lower thread-count.

MacFarlane's preference for quantity over quality results in a lot of dead air, but the gags that land are howlers, and all of its crudeness (and racism, and sexism, and homophobia, etc.), the movie beats with a real heart.
Heineman goes through the gates of Hell and comes back empty-handed.
Headland loves rom-coms too much to overly subvert them, but she spices things up at every turn, allowing for a degree of hedonistic dirtiness that movies like this seldom get to explore.
Charlie Kaufman is back. It's good to hear his voice.
Artless and unpleasant, this is the kind of late-summer swill that gives August a bad name.

Screenwriter Aaron Sorkin, who's written about America's Great Flawed Men with such fire and hyperarticulate pathos that he's threatened to become one himself, outdoes his work on The Social Network with an even sharper and more savage script.
Curiously, the more the film testifies to the unique velocity of Jobs's persona, the more routine his story feels.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's suspension of disbelief, and then there's the kind of doe-eyed romantic drama that's so detached from reality it asks you to accept Captain America as a brokenhearted busker in Grand Central Station.

This minor Rohmer may not have much to offer beyond the clarity of its perspective (and the soft beauty of Nestor Almendros's delicate cinematography), but its message will only grow more urgent in time.
movie_title: Die Marquise von O... (The Marquise of O) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Amid the rumble, Sniadecki's camera spies such a variety of life that it soon seems as though these trains provide a stage for the full spectrum of human activity.
The Mend finds the truths that bind families together, but it knows that everyone has to hack their own path to get there.

Crucially, the film never pretends that deejaying is a mystical (or even valid) art form -- Cole just wants to express himself, and Efron taps into the same sad tenderness that made him such a tragicomic revelation in Neighbors.

If Abrahamson were as gifted with a camera as he was with his cast (he inspires subtlety even from the tiny Tremblay), Room could have been truly worthy of the astonishing performances that provide its foundation.
While size may not matter (the movie runs a short 79 minutes), it's not even relevant to something this flaccid.

Hobson resists the temptation to spice things up with more traditional scares, and the film never allows its ghoulish window dressing to overwhelm the simple story of a father losing his oldest child.
The spectacle is big, it's the imagination that got small.
Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead's Spring is a clever and severely romantic creature feature that, not unlike its dim-witted bro hero, is in desperate need of a woman's touch.
As one of the film's many forgettable characters so eloquently puts it, "This stinks worse than an oyster's fart."
Hawke's first documentary is a perfect movie for a gray Sunday afternoon, a gentle and loving tribute to a man ... anachronistically convinced that talent is its own reward.
This is easily Dolan's best film, and it's exciting to think how many times we might have to revise that statement over the years to come.

A rare delight that's laced with melancholy and a suffocating sense of menace from its first scene straight through its shocking finale, Man From Reno is made special by the collisions between its characters.
Wenders's reverent enthusiasm for his subject is evident throughout the film, and he details every chapter of Salgado's life with an acolyte's inability to separate the wheat from the chaff.
The rare period piece that resists a helpful infusion of modern-day freshness, Effie Gray is entombed by the same emotional repressiveness that frustrated its namesake.
Though it's understandable that the melancholy Arielle is moved by Brian's passion for her, the contrasts between them always makes her seem like more of a babysitter than a paramour.

A heady psychosexual drama that's steeped in dense anxieties and rich European glamour (the film was partially funded by Chanel), Olivier Assayas's latest finds the French auteur at the very top of his game.
Kriv Stenders's film is unashamed to resurrect the laziest tropes of the Tarantino rip-offs that once clogged the shelves of every Blockbuster in the land.

Tsai's work sees generational defiance as a symptom of the ennui felt by their young subjects as they drift into adulthood, and Rebels' unusually sharp focus on that theme makes it an accessible primer.
A broadly moving portrait of the various roles that faith can play in a relationship.

Urushadze's excellent cast imbues their thinly drawn characters with a great deal of life, but the roles are so transparent that the film feels like more of an advertisement for peace than it does an argument for it.
Immediately joining the ranks of cinema's most bittersweet swansongs, this gentle but (literally) moving doc takes us along for a ride on the Empire Builder, Amtrak's busiest long-distance route.
The movie is clearly not interested in sugarcoating or sentimentalizing WWII, even though Clément has every opportunity to do so.
Sweden's Roy Andersson offers a singular take on the human condition in this triumphant trilogy-closer.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Carey Mulligan's commanding performance is an easy beacon to follow: her Bathsheba is caught between the vulnerability of youth and the strength of knowing her own value.
At its best, The Wolfpack helps us to see the cinema in the world, and not the other way around.
Maybe the angriest movie from mainland China since Li Yang's Blind Mountain.
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The tricksy plot allows McCarthy to explore the full range of her comic persona, and Feig is smart enough to get out of her way as the mild-mannered Susan starts wielding f-bombs as comfortably as Bond whips around a Walther PPK.
Campy but never campy enough and far too numbingly artificial to ever drum up any real suspense or sense of awe, the film has a scale that's squandered on visual witlessness.
In 2015, however, bros only come before hos alphabetically, and what once felt like an innocent tale of wish fulfillment now plays like the masturbatory fantasy of a men's-rights activist.
A film that's guaranteed to resonate for years to come.
The Citizen Kane of teen cancer tearjerkers, Alfonso Gomez-Rejon's funny and bruising Sundance sensation is like The Fault in Our Stars remade for Criterion Collection fetishists.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Wistful and stirringly humane, When Marnie Was There isn't one of Ghibli's greatest films, but it's emblematic of their collective greatness. In a way, that's the most perfect thing it could be.
An angular Western that sublimates the fading promise of the New World into a fairy tale of unrequited love, Slow West starts with "once upon a time" and ends with a crackle of incredible savagery.
Exhilarating... Pretty much the entire film is a screaming death race down Fury Road.
One of them is short and the other one is Colombian -- that's pretty much all there is to this milquetoast buddy comedy that ought to have premiered directly on seat-back airplane televisions.
The D Train ultimately generates so few laughs from its thin "be yourself" message that a commendable refusal to gawk at the gay stuff is all that keeps it on track.
Just because anyone would agree with its message doesn't mean this glorified Lifetime movie does a worthy job of conveying it.

It's here that Wiig's wallflower wit finally dovetails with a lead role that has the depth to support it, as the film evolves into an exuberant cross between Synecdoche, New York and Tim and Eric Awesome Show, Great Job!
Irrational Man can be seen as one of Allen's cleverest films, but even the satisfying tidiness of its ending contributes to the sense that we're watching a simulation rather than a story.

Yousafzai is undoubtedly an inspiration, but Guggenheim's attempts to make her more accessible to her peers (Malala struggles with math! Malala has a crush on Roger Federer!) render this doc about as insightful as her Wikipedia page and half as coherent.
In The Mermaid, Chow never forgets that the camera is the funniest tool at his disposal, and the only one that speaks in a language that everyone can understand.

Today, distanced from ridiculous controversy and dislocated from the provincial politics that drive its story, this immaculately restored classic of post-WWII Italian cinema often feels like a new experience altogether.
movie_title: Rocco and His Brothers (Rocco e i suoi fratelli) (1961)

movie_review_blurb: Davies has described Gibbon's novel as 'a story which deserves to be told.' Now it is a film that demands to be seen.
Unique for how it captures the urgency of a system that's designed to frustrate and confuse people into helplessness.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At a time when cynical, pandering 'faith-based' movies have gained an extraordinary foothold at the box office, it should be exhilarating to see a genuinely provocative movie about the trials and tribulations of Jesus Christ. It isn't.
This wonderful sequel leaves America in a pretty good place: Weed is practically legal, girls are people too, and Seth Rogen is the new Tom Hanks. Get used to it.
Cancer is some nasty business. Here, however, it's sterile and serene, as Medem disastrously isolates the emotional gauntlet of this terrible disease away from the physical ordeal that defines it.

Bad movies are a dime a dozen, but the truly pitiable ones are few and far between. Oliver Thompson's debut is spellbindingly awful, but most of it is touched with a guilelessness that makes it difficult to hate.

Na Hong-jin's spellbinding and scatterbrained new film is 156 minutes of demented occult nonsense that gradually begins to feel less like a linear scary story than that it does a ritualistic invocation of the antichrist.
This is an ill-fitting first for vérité legends D.A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus: an issue-based film.
Allen begins the film by describing this journey as a '22-year search for truth,' and while there's no doubt that he found more than he bargained for, Holy Hell fails to convey what that might be.
For years, we've been asking Adam Sandler to try harder. We've been making a huge mistake.
Conner4Real is funny, but Justin Bieber is funnier.
A once-in-a-generation disaster, and one of the most ill-advised and ill-conceived studio films of this modern blockbuster era.

Goofy where the previous installment was gritty, and graceful where the previous installment was chaotic, this sequel is such a huge step in the right direction that it may be more accurate to think of it as a mulligan.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Such a wonderfully uncynical movie that it almost doesn't matter that it isn't very good.
Jacquot's diffuse and unmotivated film will be remembered as nothing more than an extraordinary monument to Léa Seydoux's ferocious side-eye.
movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Felix Thompson's first film is a sensitive and self-possessed debut that clocks in at 76 minutes and doesn't waste a single one of them.
This flashy, brain-dead sequel turns 2013's dumbest movie into 2016's dumbest franchise.
You've been laughing at this movie for months, and the final product earns all of your worst preconceptions.
Hong is well aware of his formula, and his cheeky new movie pokes terrific fun at the tired criticisms.

Decidedly minor stuff for such a major filmmaker, but there's something remarkable about watching a master like Johnnie To reverse-engineer an entire thriller from one idea he just had to try - in this case, a shootout unlike any you've seen before.

It isn't easy to stage a Civil War story on a budget that probably couldn't pay for a day's lunch on the set of Glory (even before you adjust for inflation), but Zachary Treitz's Men Go to Battle is a triumph of resourcefulness.
Remaking a classic John Ford western might sound like a good idea, but there's just one problem: You're not John Ford.
An immaculate case-study in how far blockbusters have fallen.
Oh, what a deliciously horrific idea this movie was!
Unequivocally the best shark movie since Jaws.
Rawston Marshall Thurber's tepid buddy comedy is stuck between The Rock and a Hart place.

A fully erect middle finger to the idea of abstinence-only education, Eva Husson's directorial debut is the opposite of a cautionary tale - it's a salaciously soft-core movie about the upside of indiscriminate teen sex.
It feels as though West was so happy to be playing with classic Western tropes that he never bothered adding anything to them.

With his unusually accomplished directorial debut, Corbet delivers a strange and startling film that reflects the unique trajectory of his career, as well as the influence of the iconoclastic directors with whom he's already worked.
Pixar's best film since Up, and a compelling argument as to why we make sequels in the first place.
More rewarding for neophytes and casual fans than it is for the titular director's hardcore devotees, Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow's doc is nevertheless essential viewing for everyone.

Flowing like a miniseries that's been cleaved down to 145 minutes, and shot with the boxed-in functionality of basic cable television, it would be a misfire even if it weren't completely tone-deaf to the current climate.

This is safe, hyper-conventional stuff, lazy enough to make you feel bad that Middleditch had to go nude for it. The best thing you can say about the movie is that men have taken their pants off for less.
If nothing else, this spectacularly goofy and sporadically entertaining movie isn't afraid to reimagine human history.

It's a messy romp that's funny, hot, and horrifying in equal measure; and if it squeaks a bit whenever it tries to shift gears, that sound just becomes another instrument in Guadagnino's latest symphony of the senses.
The more we augment reality, Dickinson seems to suggest, the more we reveal what's true about ourselves.
Cemetery of Splendour is a whisper of a film that can only cast its spell if you let your breathing slow and give yourself over to the urgency of its spectral dimension.
La Sapienza  alternately feels like a self-reflexive love story or a haunted history lesson -- its best scenes play like both.
Written, directed, edited, scored, and partially lived by bipolar filmmaker Paul Dalio, this intense romantic drama solely exists to prove that his so-called "disorder" isn't a dehumanizing defect.

Plenty of movies have ensnared their white heroes in the green infinity of the Amazon, but Embrace digs so deep into the void that it eventually burrows out the other side, reclaiming the wilderness as a reservoir of lost memories.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Eggers' uncompromising directorial debut is a bracingly new experience that boils with the primordial fever of America's original sins.
Malick has moved from self-discovery to self-affirmation; he knows exactly what he's looking for, and Knight of Cups, for all its splendor, made me wish that he could take a swig and forget.
[Zoolander 2] trades its predecessor's absurdist joys for the same derivative bombast that made Anchorman 2 such a disappointing slog.

If the Coen brothers' dramas are cautionary tales, their comedies are veritable how-to guides for people who can't help but enjoy a mirthless chuckle at the humility of human existence. Yeah, the joke is on us, but that doesn't mean it isn't funny.
Bay doesn't always strike a solid balance between re-enactment and entertainment, but his successes in that regard are pivotal.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The indiscriminate apathy with which it was made sheds off the screen like a contagion.
Redmayne and Vikander, along with the film's dusky flourishes, allow The Danish Girl to reach beyond the awards it was designed to win.
As a Cold War film, it's strong. As a window into Spielberg's mind, it's essential.
At a time when everyone is talking about the death of the movies, Guy Maddin proves that we can always bring them back to life.
Despite its occasional slack, Southbound is still tightly knotted where so many other films of its type are frayed at the seams.

Just when it seemed as though Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind director Michel Gondry would be lost in the clouds forever, he comes back down to earth with a winsomely grounded coming-of-age tale that makes the most of his talents.
The most compelling questions it leaves behind don't have to do with its plot but with its creator: How much time should a young director have to make good on his potential?
Wedding Doll may be a difficult film to accept at face value, but it's an even more difficult one to dislike.

Represents everything that makes Audiard one of the most exciting forces in contemporary French cinema. It's almost too perfect a fit for a filmmaker who exclusively tells stories about people who suffer their way to freedom.
Rob Reiner's redemption, and his best film in more than 20 years, comes from a deeply personal place.
An asinine movie that has the premise for a thriller, the tone of a half-hearted neo-noir, and the plot of a daddy-daughter dramedy.
A mannered and milquetoast period biopic about the short life of mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan.

So profoundly bad that it represents the worst of two entirely different mediums, Ratchet & Clank doesn't blur the line between movies and videogames so much as it flushes them both in a toilet and watches as they swirl together down the drain.
Mother's Day doesn't feel like a movie so much as it does a cinematic adaptation of Walmart.

I'm sure there are knowing smiles of recognition that are reserved here for people raised in traditional Greek families, but it's hard to feel like you're missing any of the jokes when every punch line is practically written out on cue cards.
Marvel movies don't get much better than this. The trouble is, they don't want to.
It sounds like an interesting story, but Liza Johnson's asinine film will shock you with how little you care.
We're told that Simone gets back on stage because 'She has to deliver the truth again,' but Mort's film never feels remotely determined to do the same.
Once with a bigger budget and smaller actors, this is a winsomely entertaining musical tribute to how passion can pave the way towards a better life.
A moderately funny but uncommonly focused ensemble comedy, this isn't just a movie about the gun violence that plagues Chicago's South Side, it's a movie that was made in response to it.

A standout at Cannes 2015 (where Lindon deservedly won the prize for Best Actor), Brizé's ode to the working stiff is a sobering corrective for anyone who's ever said 'It's not personal, it's just business.'
movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Adderall Diaries is about nothing but itself. It's not fiction, it's forgery. It's not adaptation, it's erasure.
A sitcom riff on Wag the Dog with its satirical edges sanded away.
An original and charismatically honest New York comedy.
The Interview confirms Rogen as the most ambitious mainstream comedian in Hollywood.
The slickness of Kenner's presentation ironically distracts from the meat of his exposé.
A hyper-convoluted heist movie that's every bit as generic as its title might suggest.
Quite possibly mankind's greatest achievement.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Xavier Dolan's new thriller is a taut exercise in suspense that milks every moment.
Elevated from an above-average romantic comedy to a movie worthy of being embraced by a generation of twenty somethings because it refuses to let its characters off the hook.
Might have the scariest ending of any film ever made.
One of the best movies ever made about high school life in America.
A surprisingly warm abortion documentary that restores the human element to an irreducibly human dilemma.
Arguably Greengrass' best film, and almost certainly his most urgent.
Kind of like if Akira Kurosawa's Ikiru were remade as an 114-minute Super Bowl commercial.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A sensitive and genuinely curious look at programmed living and the follies of possessive love that unfolds like When Harry Met Skynet
Perhaps the greatest animated film ever made.
Perhaps the most fun you can have in a movie theater without risking permanent brain damage.
It isn't just Spike Lee's worst movie, it's practically his Wicker Man.
Insufferably boring, culturally hegemonic, and profoundly ugly.
Imagine if All is Lost were a great documentary starring Jennifer Lawrence.
A visually playful story of a girl finding herself from the inside out.
One of the best films to ever premiere at Sundance.
Like a stale Big Mac served in gold leaf, [Wolf ] offers up some central meat that never matches the aspiration of its textured flourishes.
Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors stubbornly resists a sense of intimacy, the film determined to express how communication can always be inclusive, even in whispers.
movie_title: Stand Clear Of The Closing Doors (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [The] film desperately tries to mine sweetness from the banality of life's endgame, but the falseness of its bittersweet storytelling only accentuates the misery.
Though A Night In Old Mexico won't be Duvall's last screen performance, it's as fitting a farewell as he's likely to get.

The Fake Case isn't an official sequel to Alison Klayman's 2012 documentary Ai Weiwei: Never Sorry, but it might as well be, as this fascinating and necessary coda picks up right where that earlier film left off ...
Transparent but never raw, slight but seldom undercooked, Chef is hardly the year's most satisfying film, but it's rare to find a movie that leaves the audience just as happy as it is hungry.
The film blinks too fast to maintain a coherent vision.
Cutting between the parallel stories, Decoding Annie Parker is exasperatingly slow to evolve into a misbegotten portrait of women helping women.
For No Good Reason is an absolute mess from start to finish, a portrait of an artist that's almost rendered redundant by his art

[...] The irresistibly dopey Make Your Move drops the spectacle endemic to most dance films in favor of a forward-thinking sweetness. [...] What the film lacks in authenticity, however, it makes up for in good intentions and simple pleasures.
The film is so busy attending to all its people that it never manages to adequately serve any of them[.]
The Railway Man is such a safe, respectful portrait of true-life catharsis that it feels afraid to reopen the same old wounds it exalts Lomax for confronting.

The Retrieval is hardly the first indie to transcend its budget, but it's one of the few to tackle the kind of prohibitively expensive period setting that has restricted such stories to prestige pictures.
Locker 13 isn't a film so much as a dire symptom of a culture in which the ability to fund a movie has become reason enough to make one.

As constrictive as the movie gets, it gets there organically, with Knight cutting with purpose between a limited grab bag of close-ups and medium shots, drizzling his images with artificial affects as the tension mounts.
Exhausting every trick in the book to illustrate the depravity of its protagonist, the film grows as out of control as its washed up anti-hero.
"Woody Allen's best film since 1994's 'Bullets Over Broadway.'"
A refreshingly uncynical and surprisingly practical portrait of two people learning how to take life at face value and embrace the joy which is made available to them.
The Beaver is ironically salvaged by GIbson's complete performance, and the film's commitment to his character ensures that it will endure beyond the controversy, resonating in spite of itself.
Of course, Bucky Larson isn't one of the year's worst films because its laughs are poisoned and problematic-rather, it's one of the year's worst films because there aren't any laughs at all.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A soft and sweet cancer drama that hits with the force of an ill-timed hug, 50/50 is the winsomely told story of a young man blindsided by his own body and the ways in which his inherently lonely struggle upturns his life.
While it may not be ground breaking stuff, The Rum Diary should register as a delirious ode to the 99%.
Chipwrecked is the sort of Sunday afternoon trifle that will mollify children and mortify their parents.
The Darkest Hour isn't just a dark horse contender for the year's biggest joke, it's the darkest.
Joseph Cedar's Footnote is a wry, wise little film that revels in the cataclysmic import of a life's most ostensibly trivial details.
It's official: Katherine Heigl will not rest until every last person on Earth is a misogynist.
With a title that's even more generic than the film's aesthetic, Gone will struggle to draw audiences. By next weekend, it'll be...wait for it... Not there, anymore.
Drew Goddard's giddily brilliant The Cabin in the Woods has a lot on its twisted mind.
Bernie is poised to be a tough sell for Millennium Entertainment, its mild star power likely incapable of offsetting a garish premise and mixed reviews.
A deeply unpleasant micro-budget indie that has no clue how to extrapolate a single location into an entire feature, Free Samples is an ugly bit of work.
Lola Versus never comes close to generating the sort of laughs or attitude required to fill out such a frail narrative.
Brave unfortunately wastes the studio's most winsome protagonist on their least interesting narrative.
The film's final silliness casts a pall over all of its previous successes.
Another genial but stubbornly generic comedy that breaches obvious material with ribald flavoring and rabid charm.
Don't panic, but Robert Pattinson may have been neutered.
"'Post Tenebras Lux' works so well because - even at its most random - it always feels like more of a single portrait of a man in crisis than it does an impish bouquet of provocative incidents."
Assayas' "Almost Famous," it's enormously entertaining for anyone who has lived long enough to realize that self-discovery is the only truly radical idea worth pursuing."
An essential portrait of a generation of people laughing so hard that they've forgotten the joke is on them.
An insufferable cross between "Inception" and the twisty heist noir of Jean-Pierre Melville, "Trance" is a shapelessly propulsive mess of pop psychology and poor drama.
On the Road just can't keep the beat
A throwback to a time when gratuitous nudity was the only kind of nudity, and when being a man meant dismembering another man
A rich (and even urgent) portrait of a society that has lost control of its culture, a place where aspirations have become the ultimate impediment to actual happiness.
Heaven's Gate for the Hunger Games generation
A bold and borderline insane adaptation that anoints Joe Wright as a modern filmmaker who reveres the old guard
"Do not go to Silent Hill!" That's one of the first lines of dialogue, but by that point you've probably already realized the magnitude of your mistake.
A gangster bromance that plays out like Tarantino riffing on 'Adaptation'
Resident Evil movies don't tell stories so much as they provide variations on a theme, and that theme is: a pubescent boy's wet dream recast as an antiseptic dub-step nightmare
A rare treat for anyone who's ever wondered what a martial arts epic might look like through the eyes of someone suffering from severe glaucoma.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Profoundly gorgeous stuff that appeals more to the senses than it does to the intellect
Lee's use of 3D -- the best since Hugo -- proves that while the format is pushed for the money, it's meant for the masters.
[As] a sequel [to Restrepo], the film provides an illuminating counterpoint [...] unpacking "survival" as a process, where it was previously just a noun.
A spirited, convincing, and eminently watchable bit of agitprop edutainment, Citizen Koch, directed by Carl Deal and Tia Lessin, is the latest liberal riposte to the conservative agenda.
A risible film but not an evil one, The Moment is made all the more painful by its seemingly earnest intentions.
Most of the film's pleasures will be reserved for Resnais die-hards ...
The immediacy of Poitras' film is so remarkable that, at least for the immediate future, her craft is likely to be overshadowed by her access, her storytelling overshadowed by her opportunity.
Low Down keeps the histrionics to a minimum, but the inertia of a good man failing to be a good father isn't enough to sustain nearly two hours of reflection ...
Exists is really stupid.
Nolan thrives in the limbo between logic and emotion.

Careening between genres and subplots like it's trying to outrun a second draft, the film is admirably held together by the cohesive power of Aja's steady hand and Radcliffe's committed performance ...
National Gallery is a sobering depiction of the enormous human upkeep required to invisibly maintain the collection's condition and identity.
The combined concepts are so high that the film resolves as Vigalondo reaches his Icarus moment, the corpse so mangled and unpleasant the project's ambition can only be identified via dental records.
Spy v Sigh.
The film's curiosity about the people who played for the Soviet's national team naturally unearths a reservoir of humanity.
Dumb and Dumber To may not be quite as funny as the first one, but it's the funniest thing the Farrellys have made since.

What makes The Kingdom Of Dreams And Madness more than just a simple artifact, or a glorified DVD bonus feature, is the film's clear-eyed ability to see Ghibli through the eyes of the people who work there.
movie_title: The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: All of Jason Bateman's movies are slowly starting to blend together.
The rare film possessed with the courage required to shine a light into that abyss knowing full well that down is the only way out.
Limited by the same arch tone and flippant jokes that suffocate every other low-budget indie about Gen Y confronting adulthood.
Trimmed within an inch of its life to 94 minutes, Dying Of The Light is left with nothing but the faintest echoes of whatever ideas might have inspired its making.
The ultimate takeaway is that if you can't finance a $140 million epic about ancient Egypt with racially appropriate actors, maybe you shouldn't make a $140 million epic about ancient Egypt.
Winstead is one of the most intuitive actors of her generation, and though her impressive range is easy to spot, it's her elasticity that makes her so rewarding to watch.
Dusting off the kind of screwball whodunit that the Thin Man series once perfected, this update cleverly clashes old genre tropes against the backdrop of modern Brooklyn.
The latest in a long line of condescendingly inspirational sports movies about a catalog Caucasian who learns that people of other races are also capable of being decent.
A direct sequel to 1987's Hope and Glory -- and the best thing that John Boorman has made since.

Fifty Shades of Grey is a sex-positive but hopelessly soft-core erotic drama that fails to be even a fraction as titillating as the E.L. James books that inspired it. And yet, that's exactly why it works.
Fading out long before it's able to cohere into anything memorable, Song One has its heart in the right place (on its sleeve) -- it's just in desperate need of a few strong hooks.
A road movie with no direction from French fashionista-turned-filmmaker agnès b.
movie_title: Je m'appelle Hmmm... (My Name Is Hmmm...) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is a bleak and bitter movie, but it knows the way forward, if not the quickest way to get there.
Reuveny's film unfolds with the amorphousness of memory, her family's story told in a way so personal that it feels more like a private genealogy project than a doc fit for the public.
Fitfully engaging but awkward from start to finish, Predestination bungles all sorts of potential in its attempt to balance the brains of "La Jetée" with the brawn of Timecop.
A dozen great movies could be made about the extraordinary life of Louis "Louie" Zamperini. The folly of this bland and broadly forgettable version is that it tries to be all of them.
Moore's film is so busy ladling on the sweet ethereal frosting of its world that Ben and Saoirse feel less like characters than they do ornamental toppings ...

Annie deserves credit for illustrating that old racial prejudices don't have to be preserved by new entertainments, but this remixed rendition doesn't speak to the kids of today so much as it does to their parents' wallets.
One of the most incredible chapters in the war between Israel and Palestine deserves a better movie.
As Match wilts into a trite portrait of people who are at the mercy of their pasts, Belber's menagerie of inexpressive shots leaves his film at the mercy of its own.
Distills a millennium of Japanese storytelling into a timeless film that feels both ancient and alive in equal measure.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Filled with light parkour, terrible speed-ramping, and frenetically edited combat, Ziman's film could easily be repackaged as The Asylum's ripoff of Lucy.
It's a film that swears by the golden formula of crowd-pleasing sentimentality: Let viewers laugh at the struggles and share in the triumphs.
Behaving Badly is 97 minutes in a search of a laugh, each of them so punishing that viewers are left to spend most of the movie trying to figure out what went wrong.
The politics are surprisingly complex, in the way that a jigsaw puzzle missing its biggest pieces is hard to solve.
Unapologetic mediocrity can be so refreshing when it's served by a master.
Has the distinct whiff of a quick cash-grab sequel even though it's been in production for more than four years.
The film's various episodes, while always endearing, are seldom funny or wistful enough to justify belaboring its purpose.
Graced with a hilariously definitive title, America is astonishingly facile, a film comprised entirely of straw man arguments.
movie_title: America: Imagine the World Without Her (2014)

movie_review_blurb: In many ways the perfect summation of [Cameron's] ultimate purpose as both a person and a filmmaker.
Me And You is modest and unhurried, at a pace with its ailing director.
Yves Saint Laurent epitomizes the mediocrity of a genre that often aspires to secondhand storytelling instead of first-rate art.
[Miss Lovely] isn't always appetizing, but Ahluwalia's commitment to accurately capturing the era's aesthetic almost compensates for his failure to mine a good story from a great setting.
Test is most effective when it prioritizes mood over psychological melodrama (which is often), but Johnson's approach is torn between Albert Camus and Brian De Palma.

Rossi's scathing (yet seemingly fair) documentary doesn't just illustrate the institutional ironies of modern education. It also strives to understand why tuition is at an all-time high when knowledge is practically free.
...a fun but frustratingly didactic look at the torpor of people tormented by the luxury of indecision. (That's a clinical way of saying "white people problems.")
A simple yet utterly bonkers battle of the sexes that chuckles at male chauvinism before castrating it completely.
Horrifically garish but undeniably fascinating ...
By the time the plot skitters completely off the rails, that Chappie is Blomkamp's best movie is compelling evidence that he shouldn't be the one making them.
Like a giant gob of peanut butter without any bread, McCarthy's film is an empty smother of tense disquiet that tastes fine, but sticks to the roof of the mouth.
Epitomised by Max Richter's beautiful but humourless score, The Congress is a mess of fascinating ideas that are drawn and quartered by the emotions attached to them.
I Am Ali is less a film than a mechanism for monetizing an icon's personal life.

Despite providing a sober and hauntingly frustrated glimpse into a world that most Western eyes will never get to see for themselves, this portrait of life as a Somali pirate is limited by what the camera can't see.

The fatal irony at the heart of The Giver is too hilariously blatant to ignore: here is a dystopian teen drama about the perils of sameness that feels exactly like all of the other movies in its increasingly crowded genre.

What makes Starred Up such a riveting experience is that, despite the often unintelligible brogues in which its characters speak, the film so vividly depicts the cutthroat culture of prison life that nothing gets lost in translation.
A tightly rolled cigarillo, the kind of thing you smoke on holiday while overlooking the ocean from your hotel balcony.
The antidote to the modern animated movie.
Miller introduces a number of fascinating characters, but the film refuses to dig any deeper than it has to, streamlining this demonstrably far-reaching drama into a banal legal thriller.
Ridley is forced into an anti-drama that feels emotionally honest even when it's spinning fictions.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Camargo maintains an odd relationship with the source material, his script lost in the limbo between 'inspired by' and 'adapted from.'
Keep On Keepin' On opts for a feeling of loose bebop jazz, keeping things fresh, unpredictable, and occasionally sublime.

A humble hybrid between The Thin Red Line and Gravity, Canopy embraces the challenge of making a low-budget World War II film, distilling Australia's involvement in the Pacific Theater into the plight of one unfortunate paratrooper.
Its supposedly percipient musings on modern love clash with the unshakeable feeling that the film feels like a relic unearthed from a high-school hard drive.
Who remembers the last good Luc Besson movie? Time to reset that particular clock, as he's returned with a stormer.
But not even the most garbled Tsui Hark joint is as unintelligible as 14 Blades, a film that's lost in its own backyard.
The radiant personalities of the women, and their penchant for giving new life to old platitudes, allow Advanced Style to get by without much of a narrative trajectory or shape of any kind.
A feral and staggeringly well-conceived revenge saga.

While Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates may not be a particularly convincing or memorable portrait of maturation, the fact that Kendrick's character even has an arc is enough to make you believe that bro comedies are finally coming of age.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A painfully inert sci-fi romance that commits the gravest possible sin of modern cinema: It (almost) wastes Kristen Stewart.
Part of you will wish this had been a Netflix show instead of a Netflix movie - part of you will wish Netflix had left it alone altogether.
The MVP here, the one person who's able to hold the movie together despite all the dodgy bits in its latter half, is composer Dario Marianelli... his score for Darkest Hour is a rare thing of beauty.
"Hostiles" finds its footing as it begins to reckon with the moral underpinnings of the Western genre.
These portraits don't have a hint of didacticism or preachiness, but "Ex Libris" achieves a certain emotional velocity all the same.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a film that admires - even awes at - Billie Jean King, but it doesn't share her commitment to the game.

"Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool" is a tawdrier, more tragic, but similarly superficial "My Week with Marilyn," devoted to the dying days of an actress who always lived in Monroe's voluptuous shadow.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Lean on Pete" is a small gem that covers a vast amount of territory.
An extraordinary (and entirely demented) labor of love that makes for a wan and uneven viewing experience, "Loving Vincent" takes the phrase "every frame a painting" to very literal new levels.
Cinema may be a machine designed to produce empathy, but this is the rare film that reckons with how hard it can be to sustain it.
A handsome little biopic that's sopping wet with the same clichés that its whiny hero so adamantly disavows...
Neither of the "Super-Size Me" movies is fine art, but there's a certain artfulness with which they're assembled.
Both Weisz and McAdams do a phenomenal job of negotiating who their characters are versus who their characters feel as though they have to be.
A torpidly slow epic with a script that moves at the speed of light, the film is pockmarked with incidents that never cohere into a clear narrative.
As a piece of tennis lore, "Love Means Zero" is absolutely vital. As a character study about a professional tyrant, it's almost as frail and leathery as Bollettieri himself.
"I, Tonya" will make you care about Tonya Harding for the first time in a long time. Moreover, "I, Tonya" will make you sympathize with Tonya Harding for the first time.
... Thelma's story sticks to your bones like a shiver, and sinks deeper for days after the credits have rolled.

... a typically staccato and silver-tongued drama that boasts a zillion killer lines, at least two of the year's most exciting performances, and a rare understanding of the difference between power and pride.
A dreary but diverting high-altitude romance that's superimposed onto a classic story of survival.
... "Super Dark Times" is visceral and gripping throughout, its probing compositions forcing you to peer deeper and deeper into the darkness.

Like so many of the movies that stem from McEwan's novels, "The Children Act" is a soulful and sophisticated adult drama that peers into the void between the beauty of ideals and the cost of living by them.
A listless but lustrously shot biopic...

Once upon a time we used to tell stories; now we just tell stories about how we used to tell stories. At least, that's how it feels to watch a consistently milquetoast, comfortably middlebrow bit of true-life fluff like this.
A [masterpiece].
Raw and compelling from its poetic opening shot to its gut-punch finale, Gook doesn't always find the best way to express itself, but it knows what needs to be said.
Fashion powerhouse Rodarte crosses over into the film world with a tedious but tremendously expressive exercise in subjective cinema.
It's beautifully acted and trembles with truth, but it never gives us enough information to arrive at those conclusions on her own or deepen our belief in them.
... Brie Larson's "Unicorn Store" is too adult for kids, too childlike for adults, and too muddled for the motley lot of misfits and dreamers who just want to think different.
Eschewing poeticism for an empty sense of prefab empathy, "Kings" is so determined to be hopeful that it forgets to be honest.

Told with the full texture of real life, Nicholson's second collaboration with "From Nowhere" filmmaker Matthew Newton is a close-up character study that explores notions of forgiveness and self-worth with surgical precision.
The result is a rare movie about a trans person that - for better or worse - feels of its time, and not at least a half-step behind.

What we're left with is a staid little movie that races around the court and rallies itself to exhaustion, a historical drama that enshrines the narrative underpinnings of all great sports stories without doing anything to upend them.
Every bit as irreverent, smart, and ridiculously entertaining as its predecessors, The LEGO Ninjago Movie works even if you have no idea what a 'Ninjago' is.
Our Souls at Night is a small film, and it's often such a placid one that it feels like it's standing in place.
John Trengrove's deeply probing debut feature is less interested in moral judgments than in the dynamic between strength and weakness.
A bracingly physical documentary about the true cost of cheap labor.
A soul-stirring and fiercely uncynical film.
A good bit of fun scrambling about in the darkness.
movie_title: Let the Sunshine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Ciambra is more successful when unpacking the cause of Pio's identity crisis than it is when searching for solutions.
Staggeringly well-shot but painfully strained.

Frustrated, lonely, and struggling to get over the feeling that he should just accept his brokenness, Danny is a vintage Baumbach man, and Sandler's mustached performances makes the character feel like someone you know, or someone you might be.
Sprawling and brilliant.
Coppola's film is told with surgical precision and savage grace.
This is Lanthimos' most scattered and sedate film, but it's his scariest as well.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Varda has always possessed a warm and compulsively watchable screen presence, and the pint-sized iconoclast still has more pep in her step than most of us have ever had.
Slight, contained, but ineffably soulful.

In an age where people are so preoccupied with the size of the screen on which we watch things, it's fitting that Kiarostami's final work reminds us that no screen is too small, and that no screen is ever big enough.
Sami Blood tells a very familiar story, but the hyper-specificity of its telling renders it a wholly new and quietly profound experience.

The lessons that Dean learns are pat and predictable, but this disarmingly winsome film is comfortable in the knowledge that universal truths can be the hardest things for people to discover for themselves.
For a movie that doesn't quite know what it's trying to say about violence, it sure knows how to say it with vigor.
Obviously the worst movie that Tom Cruise has ever made.
As it stands, the movie's power never pops off the screen.
As an act of preservation, Frozen Time is a marvel, a miracle, a complete good. As an act of storytelling, it's still a bit too cold for the nitrate to catch fire.
It would be great if a story about imminent nuclear warfare didn't feel quite so relevant, but this quietly powerful anime gives us reason to hope.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As sharp and savage as any breakup drama this side of A Separation.
The Only Living Boy in New York is a dumb male fantasy that's dead on arrival.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A Halle Berry vehicle with four flat tires, this is the worst movie of the summer.
Fancher is just one of those guys -- you know the kind. The word is usually "raconteur," but that doesn't quite seem to cover it, here. In fact, there isn't a word in the English language that does.
The Emoji Movie is almost as bad and brutally depressing as everything else in 2017.
An original summer movie that lazily forces all of its most famous actors to embody the most basic versions of their brands.
Soderbergh returns from retirement with a silly heist movie that packs real soul.
Byung's inability to string together a coherent narrative is nearly offset by his gift for staging some bonkers scenes of death and destruction.
Christopher Nolan's largely bloodless but profoundly harrowing war epic is the best film he's ever made.
A hackneyed romantic drama in dire need of anything that resembles actual human behavior.
No other film has so convincingly, or so urgently, illustrated the role that media will play in our fight for the future.
Luc Besson returns with a space oddity so high on its own supply that it makes Guardians of the Galaxy look like an Ozu film.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Marvel has finally started to figure out what the future of superhero movies might look like.
Kathryn Bigelow's harrowing docudrama is a bumpy but bracingly physical portrait of race in america.
Redgrave is wise to ground this portrait on a personal level.
An agonizingly boring remake of a movie about the danger of bringing things back from the dead.

Few movies have evinced such a specifically American understanding of the role that love plays (or doesn't) in becoming a man, or so openly confronted the notion that strength can only be passed down through suffering.
This is one of the boldest and most invigorating American films of the 21st century.
Maybe this is exactly the biopic that Kenney would want, silly and bittersweet and laced with regret. Unfortunately, the film is just good enough to convince us that he deserved better.
This might be the start of a long and winding path, but it's no small thing for A Kid Like Jake to so clearly illustrate how love is always going to be the path of least resistance.
[Charlize] Theron and [Mackenzie] Davis are dynamite together, the actresses playing off each other like two sides of the same coin.
The film isn't a jigsaw puzzle, where every piece neatly fits into a greater whole; it's more like a drunken night of people sitting around and remembering their old friend, warts and all.

As it stands, Yardie seldom amounts to anything more than a collection of vaguely related scenes, simultaneously both too muddled and too straightforward to have any resonance beyond the moment at hand.
While Gyllenhaal's work should be enough to satisfy anyone wondering why this movie needed to be made twice, Colangelo makes fine use of the story's new American context.

It's worth remembering that the Cloverfield movies were only able to successfully disrupt conventional distribution methods because they're good. The best thing you can say about this one is that it's free with your Netflix subscription.
You believe in T'Challa, you believe in Wakanda, and you believe - maybe for the first time - that the MCU actually matters.
Ultimately ... the most striking thing about Anderson's fastidiousness is that it's all in done in the service of chaos.
By the time it ends on a note of intimate ambiguity, it's hard not to wish that Black 47 had expressed more shades of gray.
The film renders each of Vittoria's mothers with such riveting and unvarnished empathy that you hardly even notice how their daughter is growing up before your eyes, stronger than the both of them.
Eva boasts little style beyond what its biggest star is able to bring to the table.

The answers to these mysteries are mighty predictable (a fact that Bekmambetov tries to obscure by reaching them through a string of silly plot twists), but Profile nevertheless sells us on how seductive these interactions can be.
The film's main gimmick - more successful than not - compounds the extent to which these characters were slippery constructs to begin with.
The more you see, the more you miss; 'twas ever thus. The poor director doesn't know what to do about that, but then again, who does?
It'll take you roughly five minutes to realize that Noah is going about things the wrong way; it'll take him more than 90.
Even at just 80 minutes, the story is stretched too thin.
[Klayman's] movie is so preoccupied with the idea of competitive advantages that its "Harrison Bergeron" analysis spares little thought for the people who just need some help to be themselves.
It's impossible to reason with hateful young American History X wannabes, and seeing Lough edit them into conversation with people on the other side of the spectrum only reinforces that fact.
Perhaps this movie is so striking because it's such a wonky and self-possessed experience, too much of its own thing to feel like it was tailor-made for anyone but the people who need it most.

Can a gaijin ever be trusted like family, or will his motives ultimately be self-serving? It's an interesting question in a story that's otherwise completely devoid of interesting questions, but The Outsider is too enamored with its foreign star.

Even when the movie ends, we feel like we're only scratching the surface. Still, how refreshing to see a coming-of-age story that's less concerned about a teen losing her innocence than it is in how she might earn some of it back.
Everything that Grace and Del might have meant to us, and everything they might have meant to each other, is thrown out as the script minimizes their plight into the stuff of a cheap morality play.
Even at its most self-conflicted, this is a fascinating reminder that some art wasn't made to be owned.
"Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?" is at its sharpest and most necessary when Wilkerson interrogates his personal connection to the past.
movie_title: Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun? (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It's very obvious that Roth doesn't really care about the film's political baggage - he just wants an excuse to have Bruce Willis shoot battery acid into a guy's sciatic nerve and watch the blood.
Still, there's an undeniable genius at work here, strong enough to survive the psychedelic sleaze that's been baked into every frame.

Much less consistently enjoyable than many Hong films twice its length, Grass compensates for its dramatic slackness and deviant sobriety by honing in on the ideas that its director's work often skirts around.

We're left right where we started, and with nothing to show for it but a fleeting reminder that peace is impossible without negotiation. It's a lesson that history has failed to teach us, filtered through a movie that doesn't understand why.
Fortunately, the gimmick pays off more often than not.
Submission is so desperate not to become a cliché that it ultimately wastes a golden opportunity to become something more.
Before We Vanish makes viewers walk a mile to reach conclusions that were only a minute away.
t beautifully articulates the need for young people to realize the validity of who they are, and even more beautifully crystalizes the moment when that starts to happen.
They're missing the small, desperate transactions of faith necessary to any believable romance.
The Foreigner may have been shot before the most recent rash of violence, but it's still too disposable to be this disturbing.
The problem with this hokey courtroom drama isn't that it says the right thing in the wrong way, the problem is that it ultimately doesn't say anything at all.
Sweet Virginia is riveting even when it feels insubstantial.

You might be laughing at the movie by the time you reach its go-for-broke final shot, but the look on Lively's face is enough to fulfill the idea that loving someone is not the same as needing someone.
This is a micro-budget movie, cobbled together from the corners that it's cut and riddled with rookie mistakes, but none of that will likely matter to the people who need it most.
Clear enough about what happened to be ambiguous about what it means, the film makes only one clean argument: Truth isn't always stranger than fiction, but it's often a hell of a lot sadder.

A handsomely furnished holiday movie that should have devoted more attention to its many ornaments and less to the tinsel at the top, this "Murder on the Orient Express" loses steam as soon as it leaves the station.
A problematic comedy sequel that's almost worth sitting through for the incredible cameo in the final scene. Almost.

The naked desperation of the skeleton characters provides the heart and soul of the movie, and it's genuinely touching to see Miguel partner up with family members he either misses or never got to meet.
Chbosky might yank us through the wringer like we're in a car wash, but it's nice to feel clean for a change.
It's a reminder that the 21st century is going to be full of coming-of-age films about 30-year-olds, and it's compelling evidence that that might be alright.
The film's lifeblood can be found in its connective tissue, as Alpert continually revisits the same memorable assortment of Cuban peasants and city folk.
Ostensibly a portrait of looking, the movie only sees its own reflection.
There's topical, there's timely, and then there's The Post, which feels less like a historical thriller set in 1971 than it does an exhilarating caricature of the year 2017.
The mildly amusing Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is further proof that even the stalest whiff of brand recognition has become preferable to originality.
By simply documenting Deja's humanity, For Ahkeem offers a vivid example of the incontrovertible fact that black lives matter.
This is a beautiful film, and an ugly one, and the tension between those two sides doesn't abate until the very last scene.
movie_title: Birdboy: The Forgotten Children (Psiconautas, los niños olvidados) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: People like Nadia can't fix the world, but this vital documentary is proof that it's heroic enough just to be heard.

The result is a singularly American riff on The Act of Killing, a fascinating and dream-like mosaic that's less driven by residual anger than by cockeyed concern, less interested in exhuming the past than in revealing its value to the present.
The film is consistently at its best when it's attuned to a quiet sense of harmony between all things.
It's striking to see such a proven actress [like Carey Mulligan] deliver what's so clearly the best work of her career, but it's unsurprising that [Paul] Dano knows what to do with his cast.
At first presenting itself as a tightly corseted Big Eyes set during the Belle Époque, Colette erupts into a fun, frothy, and unmistakably feminist biopic.
An immense, brave, and genuinely earth-shaking self-portrait that explores sexual assault with a degree of nuance and humility often missing from the current discourse.

Layton's attempt to complicate things only simplify them further, humiliating subjects who have already paid their debt to society. Spencer and co. haven't seen too many movies, they've just cast themselves in the wrong one.
The geometry of this strange triangle is always in flux, but it's always raw and engaging to watch the Grimes weigh the life they want to create against the ones they're in the process of living.
"The Death Cure" may not be able to fully overcome its fundamental childishness, but its director grows up right before our eyes. Here's hoping that his next trilogy is more worthy of his talents.
It's a good thing that [the] characters genuinely care about each other, because Proud Mary sure doesn't, and most of the people watching it won't either.

"Daphne" is a modest movie, one that feels more like a snack than a meal, but it's so vivid and disarming precisely because it doesn't try to reinvent the wheel or deliver its red-haired heroine unto salvation.
The Commuter forfeits a good movie about why an everyman might get ensnared in some lite Hitchcockian mishegoss for a mediocre one about how he might weasel his way out of it
Potentially a dark harbinger of things to come, Bright isn't only the worst film of 2017, it could be responsible for many of the worst films of 2018 and beyond.

"The Greatest Showman" is all about the dizzy pleasure of letting yourself be hoodwinked, and it's a testament to the movie's idiosyncratic appeal that it never loses its power to lower your defenses and take your breath away.
With Mary and the Witch's Flower, [Studio Ponoc has] come both too close and not close enough, resulting in an adventure that can never climb out of the uncanny valley it digs for itself.

If The Teacher fails to convey the particulars of its climactic uprising, Hřebejk's lesson plan -- a needle-sharp take on the perils of doing the wrong thing for the right reasons -- still touches a nerve.

In a year full of disturbing events, there's something uniquely unsettling about seeing Michael Shannon look as shaken as the rest of us. Maynard might save Christmas, but we all lose a little something along the way.
Part Game of Thrones, part Snatch, and almost all bad, Guy Ritchie's latest is one of those generic blockbusters that has nothing to say and no idea how to say it.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If nothing else, this loving concert doc makes a compelling case for the musicianship, artistry, and sheer athleticism of pop music.
Goodhart's brilliant cast elevates some very breezy material into something that will resonate with siblings of all sorts and sightedness, and even the minor characters leave a mark.
A skin-deep portrait of a story so interesting it feels like you could burrow into it for years.
The rare film that has the courage to stomach the reality of life after death.
You'd be hard-pressed to find a more lavishly staged staged chunk of pulp nonsense.
Burton doesn't reinvent (or even reanimate) YA movies so much as he layers a Tim Burton Snapchat filter over them, as though a surplus of big eyes might compensate for a lack of big ideas.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Why, at the end of Brendan Toller's intermittently fascinating but exclusively surface-level documentary, do we still have no idea who Danny Fields really is?
Imagine if Gone Girl had been directed by the guy who made The Help.
Convincing proof that Mia Hansen-Løve is one of the best filmmakers on the planet.
Two masters of naturalism deliver a coming-of-age story that dares to let its characters chart their own paths.
A sensitive and darkly hilarious true crime story that works from top to bottom.
Less twee and more textured than Beginners, this is the film that Mike Mills was put on this planet to make.

Ben Affleck plays an ass-kicking autistic man who travels the globe under a series of aliases and performs elite maths for some of the world's most dangerous people - this is a real thing starring real people and made with real money.
The King Of The Monsters roars back to life in his weirdest movie to date.
A woozy and wonderful queer teen romance.

Less of a movie than it is a monotonous two-hour supercut of Tom Cruise elbowing people in the face, Jack Reacher: Never Stop Never Reaching is a generic star vehicle that's been stripped down to nothing but an old engine and a rusty chassis.
Michael Moore In TrumpLand  is barely a movie, but it makes a strong humanist case for Hillary Clinton.
Washington doesn't try to improve upon August Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpiece, but he brings it to the screen with integrity (and a handful of incredible performances).
A heavenly cast coming-of-age story that's told with real consequences.
Andre Royo shines in a fabulist comedy that laughs at Trump's idea of Black America.
Jessica Chastain is bulletproof in a frothy soap opera about the other women in Washington.
This lifeless and lazy action-comedy only deepens our concerns about Netflix's feature-length comedy output.
movie_title: The True Memoirs of an International Assassin (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Anna Biller's Technicolor throwback is a spellbinding feminist delight.
Pick a god, any god, and thank them for this movie.
A wooly meditation on mortality, a movie about a man who sees his farm as an extension of his body and a reflection of his soul.
A giant middle finger to anyone who's ever forced Paul Schrader to compromise.
A corporate-sponsored disco rave from the happiest recesses of hell.
A 92-year-old Scottish woman refuses to let the Donald have his way with her in Anthony Baxter's maddening new doc.
Like spending two hours between Liam and Noel Gallagher, for better or worse.

If "Doctor Strange" can be dispiritingly safe, it can also be just as impressively bold - an hallucinogenic trip along a very familiar path, watching the film is like adding a large dose of LSD to your morning commute.
Nocturama is enthralling until the bitter end, but it's so hard to distill its purpose that you can't tell if the film is opaque or if it simply offers nothing to see.
Imagine if the Duplass brothers had produced Freddy Got Fingered and you'll be on the right track.
The movie flirts with the outline of a coherent plot, but the answers to its dramatic questions have all sunk to the ocean floor in a plume of beatific marine footage and Cronenbergian body horror.
Woody Harrelson's hammy performance almost makes this biopic worth endorsing.
Julia Hart steps behind the camera and delivers what is easily one of the year's most promising directorial debuts.
For almost 45 minutes, Yeon Sang-ho's new film is on pace to become the best, most urgent zombie movie since 28 Days Later.

[The film] thrives whenever it regards Headfort as a place suspended between an ancient institution and an overgrown home, one that fosters both the transient children and the adults who have become part of the furniture.
A profound failure of unprecedented proportions. An embarrassment for Republicans, Americans, and pretty much the rest of humankind.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A short, unfocused, but powerfully resonant impression of how America's past is sacrificed at the altar of its future.
Other movies have more powerfully exposed the corruption of contemporary China, but few have so articulately confronted how women always seem to be the first citizens to have their wings clipped.

Blisteringly cool one moment and ridiculously silly the next, this punchy and propulsive late summer surprise is able to capture the way we live now because it displays such a vivid understanding of the reasons why we live that way.
A warm, wistful, and wholly wonderful remake of a 1977 Disney musical that today's kids have never heard of and yesterday's kids have long since forgotten.
Rozema doesn't push the future feminism angle to its full degree, the ideas baked into her script never becoming nearly as dynamic as the characters who are desperate to bring them to life.

What makes this such a vital feminist film, even when its other qualities are often few and far between, is how defiantly it internalizes the idea that strong female characters have nothing to do with decency, and everything to do with depth.
Just when you think the summer movie season can't get any worse, along come the 'Worst. Heroes. Ever.'
Ira Sachs' latest is that rarest of beasts: a truly hopeful heartbreaker.
A strange, satisfying, star-studded adaptation of the kid lit classic.
Less funny than the average cat gif and approximately 1,000 times as long.

Despite the film's gripping final chapter, its heroic Czechoslovakian characters are completely disconnected from the rest of the country, much like their struggle has been omitted from the cinematic legacy of the war they helped to win.
Respectfully folding the symptoms of PTSD into a slick genre piece, Winocour's second film is more of a calling card than it is an arrival.
Sausage Party, for better or worse, is a movie that actually exists. And, at some point along the way, that fact will actually shock you.
Suicide Squad survivor Joel Kinnaman is aces in this otherwise iffy survival thriller.
Even when Trespass Against Us slumps toward the same generational conflicts at the heart of so many recent indies, these actors refuse to reduce their characters into any recognizable archetypes.

One of the most perceptive novels of the 20th century becomes one of the most ill-conceived movies of the 21st as Ewan McGregor tries his hand at directing with this ruinously streamlined adaptation of Philip Roth's 1997 masterpiece.

Try as she might to pretend otherwise, Smoczynska builds her story upon the foundation of a fairy tale, and all of her fantastically bonkers ornamentations are supported by the romance that blossoms between Silver and Mietek.
A fun and surprisingly fresh Western that takes aim at Donald Trump's America.
Derek Cianfrance can't quite thread the needle between John Cassavetes and David Lean, but it's fun to watch him try.

Elizabeth Wood's fire-breathing debut is an adrenalized shot of ecstasy and entitlement, a fully committed cautionary tale that's able to follow through on its premise because t's unafraid of being utterly loathsome.
A newcomer and a natural (and an Australian!), Terrell almost singlehandedly elevates "Barry" from a cutesy time capsule into something a bit richer and more alive.
The kind of toothless and emotionally counterfeit cancer dramedy that gives America's independent cinema a bad name.
A strikingly present documentary debut that traces how the friction between a government and its people can metastasize into a dangerous state of insurgency.
The good news is that the story of Ben-Hur is so rock solid that not even the director of Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter can screw it up completely.
Finally, a movie that answers the question: 'What if the director of The Hangover tried to make The Wolf of Wall Street?'
As a stand-alone film, this is a beautifully rendered bore. As an advertisement for the forthcoming video game, it has some merit.
This is Daniel Radcliffe's most promising performance, as it proves once and for all that he's capable of making his own magic.
Staggeringly beautiful and immensely true, this is the best animated film of 2016.
Joshua Marston's inert and hyper-literal new drama suffers from a fatal identity crisis.
A gritty moral thriller about the perils of doing the right thing.
An agile, vicious piece of work that's anchored by extraordinary performances from Rooney Mara and Ben Mendelsohn, "Una" maintains its grip even when swinging a bit too hard for the fences.
Two of the most watchable actors on the planet are stranded in a numb sketch of a film that doesn't know what to do with them.
A mega-budget reboot that's embarrassed of the TV show it's bringing to the big screen.
Hirokazu Kore-eda only makes good movies, but this tender, accessible drama is one of his very best.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A short, stressful, and utterly spellbinding debut that transforms the immigrant experience into the stuff of an early Polanski psychodrama, Ana Asensio's Most Beautiful Island is a worthy winner of the SXSW Grand Jury Prize for best narrative feature.

A wise and wistful love letter from one remarkable character actor to another.
This unclassifiable docu-joke has a pretty decent punchline.

movie_title: The Most Hated Woman In America (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film ties together in such a perfect bow that it's tempting to forgive all of the knots it took to get there.
The Boss Baby might pacify kids, but this dirty diaper of a movie is further proof that Hollywood animation is in need of a change.

Reverent and ridiculous in equal measure, Martin Koolhoven's latest epic is a wild pseudo-Western that trembles beneath the biblical weight of its comically grim story.
A bone-crunching Indonesian bloodbath that stars the same actor from The Raid and feels like it was cut together from that film's deleted footage.
A woeful wedding farce in which the cake is the most interesting character.

As perceptive as it is precious and predictable.
A bittersweet documentary about the woman who saved a jazz legend's life, and then killed him.

The rare period piece that feels observed rather than pretended, Stéphane Brizé's "A Woman's Life" finds the prolific French filmmaker applying his ruggedly naturalistic style to some very different source material.
An unforgettable and essential documentary about something that demands to be seen, even if it can never hope to be understood.
This is a studio comedy on auto-pilot, a movie that lets its title do the vast majority of the heavy lifting.
A touching (if slightly superficial) tribute to a great actor gone too soon.

movie_review_blurb: The rare modern kids movie that offers absolutely nothing to anyone over the age of five.

movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The listless, shoddy sort of remake where it feels like all of the characters have already seen the movie they're in, Sleepless reduces one of the best action films of the 21st century into one of the most benign.

2017's only good story about a self-obsessed cartoon billionaire who gets money from Steve Mnuchin.
