Woody Allen is a lippy guy, but what makes Match Point sexy is the converging, special lips of Scarlett Johansson and the special lips of Jonathan Rhys-Meyers.

An affront to PC maniacs everywhere, but a considerable gift to fanatics for comedy, Albert Brooks' Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World will find its Brooksian cult niche (if not in the Muslim world).
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... a riveting movie.
Even those of us not pining nostalgically for Mary Poppins can feel the slump of a long, downward trajectory. Nanny McPhee plops.
If Britain's demurely charming Ealing Studios had ever made a nudist comedy, the result could be close to Mrs. Henderson Presents.
When weak British comedies imitate bad American ones, all we get is mediocrity with more verbal velocity.
A Terrence Malick movie -- only four features in 33 years -- is such a visual splurge that you feel the film and its coffee-table book have arrived in unison.
Pulse is emptied and perplexing at trying length.
Jackson, the visionary, has a tin ear. The dialogue, even if you cut it some slack for camp, is awful.
McMillian and the big Coco are excellent, and Fletcher makes something scarily comical of dad's hardball glares and proudly Nixonian grievances.
The film is profoundly accomplished, entrenched in its period, timed with supple rhythms, cast near to perfection.
Mikael Hafstrom's film is rancid pulp that dares to invoke family values and use a sick child for sympathy.

If adults find a drawback, it's in watching the old home and its beautiful woodwork destroyed in serial blastings and smashes. But there are no dumb songs, small jokes slip in neatly and Zathura can please its market niche (mostly sub-12).
Black has finally got the hipness that his Lethal Weapon films pawed like apes, thudding with macho humor.
The movie isn't deeply about anything, even including tennis, though it has a smartly rancid skill in spearing phonies.
Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, fourth in the string, has a heated darkness.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Walk the Line comes alive intermittently.
Here is Nicholson's classic, post-Mitchum cool, but humanly exposed, providing the star punch in Antonioni's pensive dreamscapes.
Treasuring what Larson and his young cast did, Columbus has made it vital again, showbizzy but only sometimes corny.
In my movie fridge, The Ice Harvest packs in far beneath Iceman, The Ice Storm and The Iceman Cometh. It suffers freezer burn even below Ice Palace and Ice Station Zebra.
An irrefutable thesis against remaking old films.
Lucas has a smaller knife, and its edge dulls.
A seriously disturbing film.
At its best, fairly often, the movie rises above hammy devices.
The movie isn't terrible, many details are vivid, yet the depth is all sheen and display. It has some tough truths at heart, but its brain is a blurof fast cards dealt by an insecure croupier.
A chamber piece of subtle touches, finely acted, the movie has time jumps that are a little confusing.

This is the kind of movie normally confined to small, New York art houses or to film festivals. It will not set American box-office records. But anyone who finds it will want to raise a glass and share a Succot meal with it.
The World's Fastest Indian is a total charmer, one of those salt-of-life stories drawn from fact, inflected by humor and given robust respect by all involved.
Our eyes cram the stunning, dry, bare-boned mountainscapes of a Chinese/Tibetan Wild West called Kekexili.
By now, the panther has had a very long meow.
The story, though stretched, is cute.
This is one of the worst of the year -- both '06 and '66.
Watch it and light up, mentally.
This handsomely lighted movie has the craft to make the dances vivid but not too spectacular, the dancers eager but not just showbiz animals. Take the Lead merits taking the lead for a weekend or so.

There is a probing awareness and conscience in the Dardenne films, without schoolbook lessons tapped onto our thick foreheads, though the emphasis on ethics could put their work on a shelf near the elegant works of Eric Rohmer and even Robert Bresson.
This pilgrim's taste runs more to Martin Scorsese's Tibetan drama Kundun, and a third-act exit should not be taken by the pious as a skeptic's review.
The sense of speed, the thrill of competition and the awful awareness of danger are intense and unremitting.

Spaz Williams, no spaz, has the current prevailing formula nailed. Which is: Keep it moving constantly; heaps of bold color and diagonally extreme action; snappy quips and snarks for everyone; traumas immediately pacified by cute and/or musical moments.
Fire and freeze, flames and ice, it's all primal. And fairly prime as getaway entertainment.
Casey Affleck is Jim, maybe the least starring role ever to center a movie. In this wet doughnut, he is the wide hole.
Little of weight seems at stake and the ensemble hum is low-key.
The topics of American Dreamz are very broad, but the targeting is often lasered.
Mol and Harron neither put her down nor hoist her up. Rather than breaking Bettie Page into voyeuristic parts, they leave her mysteriously complete.
Devout but no saint, Sophie was one of those people whose moral gravity (helped by a wonderful family) bears witness for humanity when that is most needed.
Strictly in movie terms (after all, it's a movie), United 93 slips from suspense film to disaster film to horror film.
Stick It has a clunky script, a game cast and swell bodies in motion. It would have been better if [director] Bendinger tried to tell it more than sell it.
The movie is sweetly enjoyable, requiring only the ABCs of simple human identification.
The social, economic and personal stresses don't seem very surely addressed by the big swim.
Shaped by basic commercial instincts, with at least 17 distributors lined up to carve the yum pie in global release, this heavy-breather may prove Stone's last hurrah.
As a Spike Lee joint, this heist-and-hostage yarn blows some vivid rings but it lacks kick.
Tsotsi, which hits obvious marks, is not a great film. But it is a firmly memorable one, with or without an Oscar.
Jones holds it all together like old chaps glued by sweat, and if you want a modern offshoot of the Western even beyond the risks of Brokeback Mountain, here it is.
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Moore is moving, but the film is a flogging fiasco.
Eight Below can give you eight sniffles and friendly frostbite.
Not a lot new in this show, if you've read or seen Moore, or Gore Vidal, or Noam Chomsky. But Jarecki assembles argumentative elements shrewdly.
Ballets Russes, fondly uniting interviews of aged ex-dancers with almost fairy-spun clips from their youth, is a peacock reunion beneath a chandelier.
16 Blocks never makes much sense of its crammed geography or gives the actors more than generic options.
Matthew Sexiest Man Alive McConaughey ought to be in Westerns, but not many are being made. So he plays a walking, winky pin-up in Failure to Launch, which may launch commercially but is a failure.
This moving respite is their gesture that humans, face to face, can survive humanly.
Almost brazenly bereft of artistic shaping, The Boys of Baraka still has the core of direct, human interest that sustains many documentaries.
Depp is stuck playing a witty rake who isn't remarkably witty or even all that sexy.
Diesel owns it. He hits us in the eye with the whole pizza pie.
Nothing can upgrade pulp like a bunch of plush British accents.
It's Shakespeare For Absent Dummies, no cram notes needed.
As philosopher Mary Warnock says, with a nod to John Locke, [Doug] Bruce is 'certainly the same man, questionably the same person.' The paradox haunts a remarkable film.
Not just altering history but updating it, this is the best political satire since Joe Dante's The Second Civil War and the strong sections of Spike Lee's Bamboozled.
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: 'Coming out' films are now rituals, patterned like dances, and Marco Kreuzpaintner's Summer Storm hits its generic marks.
Don't Come Knocking lacks Harry Dean Stanton and the astonishing emotional trajectory of Paris, Texas (1984), but it reunites Wim Wenders and writer Sam Shepard in a raw, airy West.
Not a special pleader but is fairly special, because Sanders gives it the pressure of straight moral conviction.
This oddball wallow is both tonic and toxic, packaged in Egoyan's dishy style, so capably served by Paul Sarossy's images and Philip Barker's sleek design.
It is surprising to find quite a good Coast Guard movie. But then, it's surprising to find any Coast Guard movie.
A charm parade of serial death in the old, cherishable line of The Ladykillers and Kind Hearts and Coronets, though more cozily pastoral, the film rouses chuckles.
If a bit long for a cartoon feature -- probably a sign that its makers fell in love with it -- Ratatouille is the eighth and one of the best Pixar features.
Evening reaches for depth, at times plodding, never cloddish. The lessons about choice and loss and getting on in life have some decent heft, and there is a sunset magic in Redgrave's eyes.
You have to go back to the worst Hanna-Barbera cartoons to find gag material this excruciatingly contrived.
J.K. Rowling has a spirit of plenty. On page and screen, her vision is a deliciously human (not just mythic) triumph of fancy, a spreading of soulful wings to lift us high.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The writers and director Dennis Dugan conspire to be gutsy in a gutless way.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: From Mostly Martha to Mainly Comfort Food -- by way of the Hollywood microwave.
Always dressed and coiffed like perfect dolls, the Bratz reaffirm sisterhood by heading for the mall.
Moments of tension quicken almost unbearably, and no one is immune (the crowds are like nerves multiplied).
Ultimatum tries to stir sympathy for its indestructible hero. But Jason Bourne has all the charm of a howitzer. He needs some time with the Harry Potter bunch.
Rush Hour 3 is a traffic jam of clichés that doesn't achieve gridlock mainly because the stars, Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker, are too tireless to quit.
What Forman doesn't give us is drama of sure coherence or credibility, but the trappings entrance.
Atkinson is tireless, and a bit tiring. His facial contortions, weird grunts and malaprop moves almost never rest, and his holiday trip to Cannes from Paris is a twit's marathon.
As steeped in Russian flavors as a hot samovar, this fast, compelling story is also oddly Dickensian in its shadowy corners and twists.
Finally even Thornton finds his inner softie, at which point the film, after some OK gags, dies with a mechanical squish.
There is the squishy tension of a problem drama gone soft.
A movie that has only two major scenes for Streep and one for Arkin has talent to spare.
Stardust staggers with end-of-summer excess, seldom winning more than a weary gasp.
There are laughs, good effects, fine beasts and a mood of goofy apocalypse.

Seattle locales, some spry lines and tiny soundings of depth still leave us in the conceptual grip of 'love' as a system of endless bartering and vanity, with impulsive copulation treated as consecration. Oh, boy.
A grand mural of trauma, with superb colors, a great escape scene and fertile myth-probing about how masters and vassals together forged the hot core of Mexican Catholicism.
Extravagantly expendable.
A bar of soap is a repeated element in Georgia Rule, and rightly so. Suds rise in this capably acted fem-drama laced with slap-in comedy.

The movie has some vivid shock touches and the scenes of depopulated London are queasily strange. Still, this is really about a grimly ravaged couple and two kids put through hell. Your idea of fun? Munch on it.

Essentially the movie is saying to its loyal crowd: You bought this stuff before, now take it re-canned. There is nothing really happening but the breezy ricochet of gags, the rote sitcom types, the star voices that are phoning in performances.
Parker Posey is one of the indie queens used feebly by Hollywood, but in the hands of Hartley she is the star needed and right on schedule.
The third film is a startling cascade of climaxes, too long, but to complain about excess in such an exuberant bonanza is like complaining that Gibraltar has too much rock.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An attitude bazooka full of sex, drugs and raw language, yet so high on babies and family values that this must be the first R-rated film for both sleazoid slackers and earnest right-to-lifers.
Mr. Brooks does work up some clammy tension. The script has bite.

This more homespun film doesn't let down its story or the Shue family. Its plain integrity outshines predictability. It is feminist without cant. And Schroeder delivers perhaps the finest young female performance of the year.
Demeaningly patronizing to educators, cheaply dismissive of students, Chalk is a dunce. Erase it.
Paprika is a fertile delta of forms and colors, wildly inventive, shape-shifting, jiggly with fat jokes.
Many districts of the city open to as many directors, each finding vignettes of love or loss.

Plot pieces barely fit, almost nothing is clearly explained, the gizmos and twists are stupid, the wit witless. This movie smokes a fat cigar of assumption, smug that most viewers will need to feel like insiders.
Cartoonishly surging with liquid color, digital waves and jokes that even include gefilte fish, Surf's Up never forgets to have fun.
This Parisian fable is a talkathon, affecting a silly toughness, but the sights are good to see again.
If not entirely a downer, this is no topper.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A recent book on the Nancy Drew mysteries notes that Nancy came along in 1930, just as 'the first tampons went on sale.' News to Nancy in 2007? Her love life remains virtuously naive, and Betty Boop still thinks she's a square.
It's a soaper about a doper and a classy widow. Keep that in mind, even if you give way to seduction.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dynamic Spider-Man movie. Most of the familiars are back, the additions work well enough, the movie often looks terrific and excess length (about 15 minutes) is just the pad built into these piled-up projects.
This jabbering, photographed pamphlet might spark some discussion, but as a movie it suffocates on gas.
Get into the right and light holiday spirit, and you should be pleased.
Brad Pitt is at the top of his own game as Beane. Cocky and often nonchalant, he is gnawed by doubts that he tries to cover by grabbing a snack or pitching a grin.
The grand finish, if not always inspired, feels necessary. In a sustained, imaginative way, this is the best of any movie series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like Tiepolo, Miyazaki is a winged artist who flies in his own space, taking gravity with him. He can put us into a childish stupor of anticipation, then satisfaction. His vision is so free that it captivates.
It's very pretty (plus a song that is like a gumdrop melting in your ear). Girls may enjoy the sweet, rather wistful story more than most boys.
The acting marathon is adroitly blocked and paced by Polanski and impeccably shot by Pawel Edelman.
Through it all, Dujardin has great dignity, is hugely likeable, and pulls off touches of comic poignancy not far from Chaplin's.

The film is richly rooted, with splendid trappings, including pea-soup fogs. For all the pomp and protocol, it's an intimate story about a scared man who must find his voice if he is to rise, in regal stature, above his epaulets.
The finish, a rush of climaxes, can make you feel zoned at 3 a.m., trying to decide between TV and the wallpaper.
Here is your post-holiday depression pill: Children of Men. Not to relieve depression. To cause it.
Strong effects, good design, and an exciting use of nature help to empower Stewart and Theron, who inject a rich, double dose of feminism.
Devout fans will have to go. For the rest of us, the best rewards of this show were long ago, in a galaxy that now seems far, far away.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The story is a lurching carnival of budget blasts.
The makers are left, finally, a few cookies short.
A few tart, amusing lines echo the fabled Kind Hearts and Coronets, yet this British movie based on a French farce falls into morbid silliness.
With Walker and cinematographer Dudu Miranda, Muniz has a hawk's eye for the weird beauty of bulldozed hillocks of trash and the catador faces that he chose to star in photographic portraits.
Maturing performances are a bonus, but the show's the thing, and by now it seems much richer than any theme park that could ever be made from it.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its plodding tactics, the movie is an alarming witness.
Persepolis feels abstract, never deeply personal, because Satrapi offers only surfaces and push-pin thoughts while sharing here sincere but glib sisterhood with Iranian history.
Anderson is a gambler who likes wild cards.

What's not to believe? A lot. But asking for bolted logic and dramatic structure in such a movie is about like asking former Fed chief Alan Greenspan to open a mosh pit in Miami. Anyway, the money in the bank here is Keaton.
What is missing is the novel, its strange time shifts and lusciously compiled details and playful, god-like viewpoint.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There may be box-office gold from The Golden Compass, but panning for it while viewing is a real day at the mine.
It's a movie in which everyone wants answers without being able to formulate the questions.
The cast is game, the script is watered nog, the kids push their charm hard, Murphy is often excruciating, Union is pleasant in a sitcom mommy way, and Lance Rivera is a zero stylist.
Not since Election has a female star talent hit the screen with such a sting of arrival.
An amiable but also angry documentary.
It's a free-fall into total plastic. Kids deserve better. Alvin, Simon and Theodore deserve better. But 'tis the season to take what you get.
Atonement, a triumph of adulthood, atones for a lot of shoddy stuff at the movies in 2007.
The movie's energizing strength is intelligence. It is so entertainingly adult.
Coppola has conviction even with the airiest elements. The churn and sweep of time, memory, karma, the whole enchilada of fate, give the story a weirdly compulsive charm.
The movie greedily uses its rich cast.
Afghanistan is a nation tortured by history, but the core feeling in The Kite Runner is heartburning love of the place, its proud people and dusty, rugged beauty.
It would be inhuman not to empathize with the actual man's plight, but the movie is a sophisticated prod, pushing us inside its own Bauby.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The truly disturbing element is the heavy reliance on childhood loneliness, fear and sickness.
The Bucket List gets through its list while rarely seeming a chore. Its two great stars invite us into their company, often amusingly, always humanly.
Had Wile E. Coyote chased Jean-Luc Godard, the result might have been Diva.
The film 27 Dresses only seems like a lobotomy. In fact, this is public surgery to install a new vacuum tube for airheads into the generic chick flick, model 2008.
Old fox Lumet deals out some flash cutting and time frame back-and-forths that, if not the Tarantino tango, are fairly adventurous.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As was famously said, we'll always have Paris. Very few, even the makers of Amelie, have Paris quite like Gondry.
Sometimes you pan a deadpan comedy because it's effectively dead.
Director Edgar Wright, scripting with star Simon Pegg, winds it up and lets it fly. The result, even hitting its target, tends to splat.
It's watchable, but like gorging on every rotten issue of the old Confidential magazine.
Long, belabored, terminally solemn despite some vigor, and numbingly sentimental under a tough surface, this is a serpentine coiling of three modestly connected and episodic stories.
Despite all the sunny, Provencale charms, the plot is a wisp of wee gags, peeps of flesh, mildly charming repartee.

A buddy movie shot with artless rawness, yet highly implicative about the wastage of modern street males and the sort of men cultivated by state agencies to be disposable killers, Harsh Times is a B-film with A-level morsels.
At least N'Orleans got production dollars from this film. What do we get? Lack of originality that starts with the title, used for feature films in 1985, 1988 and 1997.
This is heartfelt but not deeply searching, not Dostoevskian. It's teasing, melodramatic and oversold.
To call Fur one of the year's best seems a little diminishing -- it's a classic.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: With our help, Borat can move the United States above Kazakhstan on the U.N. laff meter.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: How moved you are by this holiday fare depends, beyond basic human empathy, on your piety (or nostalgia for childhood readings and Nativity plays).
Apocalypto is a big load of sado.
Winslet, Black, Law and to some extent the others are often swell. But the script limits are still there, knots in the weave, and you need to be a goner for manipulation not to notice.
Director Edward Zwick, whose movies tend to preen, swell and stretch, pushes lengths past the obvious emotional closure and moral payoff.

This is one of the few American movies to deal with how people live and survive. It admires smart brokers but also feels for the many people down below, and we know that Chris will not claim his 'happyness' by becoming a cold fish in a glass office.
In this crafty version of the E.B. White classic, critters say the darndest things, humans are often marginal (and mom frying bacon is darn tactless), humor and warmth keep bubbling up.
The Painted Veil doesn't have quite the gripping pressure that Maugham built in his prose with such sober, masterly confidence, but it is strong work, honestly done.
[Director Sylvain] White has a good cast but directs the fiercely macho dances in a choppy, video-buzzed manner that breaks up patterns and fuzzes some steps.
[Byambasuren Davaa is] a sure talent, slipping into the life he observes unobtrusively.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Many hands, including many writers, applied themselves to Flushed Away (doesn't that usually require just one hand?). The result is committee animation: cute, fast, uninspired, softly consumable.
You can come away feeling bruised and half-deaf.
The movie is a litany of victims and a chilling indictment.
France's Claude Chabrol, venerable (76) chessman of suspenseful bourgeois rot, moves his pawns superbly again, though we see the checkmate coming.

Crime stories have become incredibly generic, and though this is not a pit like Miami Vice, some bursts of good staging and imagery only serve to remind us that Scorsese is a streak gambler who can get stuck with the wrong hand.
The key achievement, in this vividly shot and superbly cast drama, is to make us fear for the slightly contemptible Garrigan but feel mostly for Ugandans, even (a little) for Amin.
Ewing and Grady avoid prodding or sneering, giving Fischer and her young charges nearly all the scenes.
Even more soulless than Tron or The Black Cauldron, Renaissance seems less a vanguard advance than the rococo degeneration of an art movement for trippy nerds.
In this truth game, Capote is an ace and Infamous is a compelling queen, both in play for high stakes with In Cold Blood and Richard Brooks' scary 1967 film of it.

Robin Williams doesn't need to prove he can act, not after The Fisher King, The Night Listener, Good Will Hunting and Mrs. Doubtfire. What he does in Man of the Year seems a long way from actual acting.
Now, they are middle-aged, and (unfair to spoil small surprises here) embedded in life with some learned wisdom.
Tiresomely tireless escapade.
Funny? At times, but mainly sad, seasoned and alive to the test of a summer when a canny new PM met history through two remarkable women.
[Arroyuelo and Camil] are enjoyable, so is Martha Higareda as Claudio's patient girlfriend, though the coming of the band is treated like Jesus returning with the Beatles.
If not so witty as Coppola's Lost in Translation, this is like a funnier and feminine Barry Lyndon.
Flags has the guts to put honest quote remarks around 'the good war" and 'the greatest generation.' It honors the fathers and the lost sons by not simply raising a flag.
It is good for magic to be, in effect, confounding. It is not so good for a movie about magic to be confusing.
Lancingly funny, brash and alive, this hotsie-totsie peeper aches for love, and the gay fire of pre-AIDs partydom.
Julie Walters lets out the stops as this stooped bulldozer, pushing whole hogs of ham.
Concise, elegant, a tad scary, this is a treat for Halloween.
It is all so done and overdone, so regurgitated, so late-night TV and what-else-is-new-in-hell.
No doubt there was hope for a manlier, brinier My Big Fat Greek Wedding. But that had better food -- and better jokes.
Pan's Labyrinth, like del Toro's previous and related The Devil's Backbone, is a saturated vision, an artist's work. What it lacks is successful unity.
Basically a vivid meal of characters, plus coffee and wine and one gin tonic, Le Petit Lieutenant keeps true to its brasserie menu.
While a Feydeau farce fits well, and the salute to a Brancusi sculpture is sweet, Beethoven piano passages overload the souffle.
Camp out with Tears, a hoot, and your tent will be wet only from tears of laughter.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's all padded, contrived, gummy with sympathy given or denied.
As Bob Lee Swagger, marksman, sniper, death dealer, Wahlberg in Shooter has his most physically perfect role since Boogie Nights.
Not even Howard's genuine appeal, or his can-do kids, can keep Pride out of the shallow end of the pool.

Tends to bubble along as a plot-boiler. Chris' guilty fantasy about the past girlfriend, just as he works up nerve for some major action, is the kind of twist that one studies screenwriting to learn and then surpass.

On ice, the movie is often fairly funny. Off it, the garish outfits, the genitalia jokes, the beer-slob gags about gays, the women as cheap laughs, even the cute guest cameos start to shiver and melt.
The movie lays on gag situations that smack of fillers.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Giddily inventive, cute, charming, even wry.
Firehouse Dog has good fire action, an engaging cast and enough vividly shot turns, surprises and bowwow reactions to hold the firm attention of pet lovers from age 5 on up. Go fetch.
Robert Rodriguez bakes a load of stale if bloody pastry called Planet Terror, while Quentin Tarantino fries up a tasty mess of fun with Death Proof.
If you're going to remake (or salute) a Hitchcock classic, it's fine to start off like Disturbia. It is not fine to end up like Disturbia.
The animation is pastiche but impudently inventive, with pop culture eating its furry tail after a long lick.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Must the 13-year-old boy Hollywood seems most eager to please also be a sadist? First came Apocalypto, then 300, now Pathfinder.
Barry Ackroyd's wonderful imagery often gives a sense of vernal moisture, which adds to the sweaty tension.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Movies like this, side ventures of the John Grisham franchise, are meant to entertain with 'substance' that never risks actual depth.

Puerile prop gags slapped in without development, an inane score, dud reactions, Steve Carr's dismal direction, a Magic Johnson phone-in cameo -- it adds up to the question that keeps arising, which is (yep) the title.
Not exactly a thriller, never quite a chiller, hardly suspenseful, it is, at best, a Sandra Bullock vehicle made of vanishing vapors.
Implausibles become inane in this Godzilla Jr. jubilee, something just right for the DVD cheapie bins.
It is too dumb as drama, even as war spectacle, to be transporting, frightening or sickening. Just numbing.

The intended audience must be the fan club for Scarface (Pacino's), anyone who has made a superficial pass at Quentin Tarantino's work, and anyone who felt challenged by Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas.
Calling this a chick flick is maybe too easy. The film is for people who want to leave the house but watch TV without going to a bar or hotel. Bring along a remote and you can be fully comfortable.
Peter O'Toole is surpassingly good in Venus.
With Keaton in devastating overdrive, Moore can barely exercise her own brand of ginchiness.
The film's ugliness is less in its 'artful' death rituals, by now deeply generic, than in asking us to feel for Lecter because of his horrid, warping youth.
Norbit is not a thriller, action film or suspense story. Still, it achieves the assassination of comedy.

An A-list soaper on moral pins and needles, the film is urbanely textured, full of Brit glibness and plush layering. Minghella makes broodingly adult coffee-table movies, and sometimes we wish he'd just serve up the coffee.
Grant happily rummages through his role, Barrymore is splendid with gulps and goofs, and Campbell Scott is an impeccably pompous author.

The adroitly calibrated life lessons include a chill gulp of death, and Terabithia proves to be soulful, even healing. What most delivers is the efficiently just-right cast, the charmed bonding of kid stars Robb and Hutcherson.
Despite limits, the story has traction and grip. As Hanssen plays out his fate, truly worshipping nothing but his own importance, we enjoy the pressures so bracingly incarnated by Chris Cooper.
Factory Girl is weirdo weary, despite some vivacity spooned into it by Sienna Miller as Edie Sedgwick.
Peter Glenville's stage-plank direction creaks badly, but the acting still holds you.

This oddball has something beyond root-for-the-roots sentiments. Thornton, well into his own orbit, is very genuinely appealing as a guy who wires his big dream machine to a loose but glowing screw in his head. Rise up, farm bird.

Often vulnerable, more often inspiring, Gruffudd's Wilberforce not only stirs curiosity but also quickens your conscience. As Fox notes eloquently, he was a great man. One does not have to be religious to believe he had amazing grace.
Wild Hogs is an oinker. Feeding us slops of dud comedy are stars who ought to know better by now.
Christopher Quinn and Tommy Walker made this fine and never simply pleading film, its moving subjects including tall, gentle, tireless, prayerful and humane John Bul Dau.

Elysium may point with a singularly pulpy brio toward where we could be headed. But in terms of how its fictional heroes try to transcend such brave new worlds, it's not showing us a future we haven't seen a million times before.

You wonder why Salerno thought the man who created Holden Caulfield would be best served by an abundance of sentimentalism, a stock sap-tastic score and some genuinely cheesy dramatizations on a black stage (the director is no Hollywood phony, but still).
And how much of the marionette-like tug you feel leading up to that pay-off will color how you view this exercise in big-screen D.I.Y. wish-granting.
Despite the class-conscious genre pleasures, independent cinema's foremost Zinn master feels slightly off his game.

Even with the actors' laudable work-especially Simm, who finally shakes off the notion that he's a poor man's Simon Pegg-there's not enough going on past the temporal trick to make the humanistic elements pop.
Davies gives the book's - and its heroine's - sense of the agony and the ecstasy of growing up a gloriously personal touch.
It's simply that Dheepan's cultural clashes are richer than its man-vs-thug ones.
What Garrone & co. have concocted is a Grand Guignol pop-up storybook, full of metaphorical dark woods and morality plays.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Less fuse, more detonation might have worked wonders.
It's a movie to admire rather than enjoy. You'll put your hands together for the powerful performance---and clap louder once it's over.
More than anything, The Wave's ability to sustain tension out of its tired scenario makes it even more impressive than its Me Decade ancestors.
Krisha is many things: a nightmare, a cry for help, a cringe-comedy with sobbing instead of a laugh track, a cracked family portrait, an apology and a valentine.

[In] Jeremy Saulnier's near-perfect nugget of a siege thriller...[g]raphic scenes of carnage are doled out sparingly but unflinchingly, while cinematographer Sean Porter gives each high-stakes encounter...a palpable sense of vintage nastiness.

Drawn, per a disclaimer, from period accounts of strange phenomena and psychotic breaks among settlers, Eggers's impeccably crafted, historically accurate creepshow wears its deep-dive research on its tattered gingham sleeves.
What we have before us is a case study on how to do shoe-leather cinema-and smart, A-list American moviemaking-right.

What this extraordinary work does best is drop us into the mind of an actor beset by insecurities, vanity-project hubris, and that inner critic who simply won't shut up, whisking us up into a dazzling, dizzyingly subjective whirlwind.

The one real takeaway here is not that things are tough all over, or that movie stars equate slumming with authenticity; it's that no actor should be asked to do a sexy dance to Crazy Town's "Butterfly." Ever.
At its best, the movie works as a love letter to camaraderie-by-combat.
It could have been so much worse; we wish it was a lot better.
You'd have to go back to Edward Yang's Yi-Yi to find a movie that approaches marathon-length running times yet still makes you wish it were twice as long.
An airtight demonstration of the maxim that no good deed ever goes unpunished.
Stuart Murdoch's story of three Scottish misfits who start a band is rife with the kind of giddy thrills and hormonal flushes you associate with being a teen.
This is what contemporary Japan looks like, it says: Not pillow shots and sword fights, just a country populated largely by predators and prey.
It's melancholy, moving and unmissable.
Though the brothers have created the polar opposite of a formulaic ESPN 30-for-30 episode, they don't chart Cooke's rise-and-fall arc in a way that lets you into his story.

Carax does not want to tell you a story. He wants to express, in the purest way he can, his infatuation with storytelling through images and genre conventions, performance and voyeurism, cinema and cinephilia.
For 91 minutes, the pleasure of the Guiteauxes' company is ours. We are ultimately the richer for it.
The director goes after both old-media exploitation and new-media omnipresence, and the result is less than cutting.
Ping-ponging between grisly South of the Border carnage and Angeleno musician Edgar Quintero's growing success as one of the subgenre's stars, you start to see how this parasitic relationship works.
Imagine a cross between a David Mamet play and a violent UFC bout restaged in a music conservatory. You're halfway there.
The Good Doctor is far more content to creep you out than to offer a critique.
Bakri has charisma to burn, but the complexity of Abu-Assad's previous movies is traded in for weak genre thrills.
Markovics shows a keen attention to performers that you'd expect from a thespian-turned-director.

movie_review_blurb: What sounds like Huckleberry Finn on the page, however, ends up like a stock melodrama onscreen.
The standout entry of the Directors' Fortnight sidebar and the closest thing to a masterpiece that I've seen so far here in Cannes.
There are exchanges, ambiguities and a noggin-scratcher of a final shot that I'm still mulling over days later, but the sense that this ground has been trod over many times has shaken my faith a bit.
What Reality loses in satirical momentum as it slouches through its second half, it gains in substance by positioning celebrity as the new cracked sainthood.
Intermittently intriguing, wildly uneven.
Quote not available.
A frustratingly frothy film that says nothing about its subject.
Some will call The Color Wheel daring. Others will remember that it takes more than desperate shocks to add substance to the sloppy diddlings of a dilettante.
It's hard to tell where D'Elia's own psychotic cinephilia ends and the character's begins.
Too often, Honsa will simply let his talking heads ramble on without focus or foundation...
Only the mighty Fonda cuts through the claptrap; the rest is just a long, predictable trip.
An American remake is already being prepped. We suggest Hollywood simply cries uncle now and calls it a day.

Anyone still doubting that the Claymation studio behind Wallace and Gromit deserves a seat at the grown-ups' table only needs to see its pitch-perfect collaboration with author-screenwriter Gideon Defoe...
Wallops its points across with stunning, sickening effectiveness.
Whereas Stoller and Segel did wonders with the formula in 2008's Forgetting Sarah Marshall, a certain overfamiliarity creeps in long before the going gets rough.
For those who aren't burdened by such things, the loopy, off-kilter pace and frontal-lobe frying provide their own unconventional pleasures.
Titillation and tentative stabs at gender studies do not a cogent cri de coeur make. It's simply a provocation that's all hopped up with nowhere to go.
It doesn't seem to display much of a point of view at all.

Whither the filmmaker who gave us such memorable monsters as Patrick Bateman and Valerie Solanas, or such complex females as Bettie Page? Someone has apparently stolen the director's identity and is making movies under her name.
Like its performers, The Lucky One isn't bad, so much as achingly banal, the sort of instantly consumable and forgettable factory-produced love story that leaves you with no impression whatsoever.
No one's asking for a somber account of simian life, but perhaps Buzz Lightyear could keep quiet for a bit and let the monkey business speak for itself.
Genuinely transcendent.
May be more nuanced than the usual Left Behind fire-and-brimstone sermonizing you find in much contemporary pro-Christian cinema, but it still leaves behind a sulfuric stink.

It tries to examine the contradictions of recasting a flawed reality through fiction-a significant notion that the film's precious structure and borderline indie-quirkfest vibe often dilute to their own detriment.
Advocates of bad-trip cinema, you may commence cult-worshipping this warped nightmare now.
The result may occasionally be more of a journalistic scrapbook than a Wisemanian all-points portrait.
This attempt at an Altmanesque ensemble piece feels a little dramatically flat even as it's dazzling your retinas.
Canet's melodrama has earned the snarky sobriquet "the Gallic Big Chill" on the festival circuit, but that's giving this mush way too much credit.

It's only a slight exaggeration to say Kold gives what may be the performance of the year -- one that not only offsets the movie's momentary dips into self-conscious quirkiness but adds a genuine sweetness to the proceedings.
Feels like Nesher is simply mashing several stock elements together and gracelessly parading them around.
Nothing-script, performances, comedy, drama-works in the slightest.
"Your charm is quickly fading," quips one character to another. You'd think she was speaking to someone behind the camera.
Essentially a mediocre character study dipped in sci-fi conventions and Social Security-age sentimentality.
Phrases are misunderstood! Tolerance for Euro-libertine ways are tested! Tame encounters turn into terrifying humiliations, because the French are, like, so crazy!
Sugar may help the medicine go down, but serving up the glucose in such goopy portions (especially when the elixir is the intriguing part) doesn't help anyone.
The film thankfully resists being either a typical coming-out movie or an ethnocultural curio, but it doesn't offer much insight into the twosome's attraction, platonic or otherwise, to each other.
The bespectacled Ayoade is the odd man out in the group, and his offbeat, eerily cheery reading of every line lends the movie its single aspect of unpredictability.
These images of security, technology run amok and multiculturalism bump up against some serious class issues.
Both de Léan and Storoge give you peeks at the genuine anguish lurking underneath the characters' narcissistic bluffing and porno posturing, even if the script drowns their best moments in verbosity.
Kaige's historical epic favors drama over action (though he doesn't skimp on violence ...), yet everything moves like it's on wuxia autopilot.
You get to acknowledge how one-dimensional the male fantasies of hot nerd-messiah chicks are while basking in exactly the same thing.
My faith that a truly important piece can be gleaned from these tales of costumed champions has been broken.
As a memento mori, It's the Earth feels a little lost in space.
movie_title: It's The Earth Not The Moon (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You can see why Tinseltown took the bait, as the filmmaker is dirty and sleek in all the right places, even when he's being sentimental in all the wrong ones (notably in an extended, far too ambitious climax).
From elderly apparatchiks to cinematic continuity, nothing is sacred, as the director punctures the illusion of "civilized" society and viewer's frontal lobes.

This orphan entry in the Duplass oeuvre exhibits lots of their trademark amiable amateurism, but no amount of flabby guys flexing to a Chariots of Fire-like score or random camera zooms will keep their sloppy indie from exhausting your patience.
Ted ends up undermining both halves of its whole, as well as its creator's clear intent to add something a little deeper to his crassness.
Alex Kurtzman's debut feature can emotionally manipulate you before the narrative house of cards collapses and things go from sweet-and-sour to full-on NutraSweet.
As an oblique critique of cultural continental drift, it works better as a cinematic experiment than it does as commentary.
Any attempt to look at deeper-rooted causes behind these assaults is completely AWOL.
A piece of lyrical, sideways social reportage that still connects an astounding number of dots.
The wounded characters eventually slouch toward redemption; the movie they're in, however, isn't nearly as lucky.

Viewers get ample time to luxuriate in the landscapes while gritting our teeth over Peter Coyote's pseudomythic narration and the sort of WTF meta touches that a first-year film student might find ridiculous.
Schemel is a major rock & roll survivor; Hit So Hard is a minor rockumentary at best, as well as a seriously missed opportunity.
Infused with its namesake, this gentle tragedy is the filmmaker's least complicated work to date, a streamlined tearjerker that respects viewers enough to not jerk the tears out of them.
Only the overstylized, near-colorless cinematography offers any shades of gray (actually, nothing but shades of gray); everything else is rendered in the most black-and-white way possible.
As clunky subplots and soap operatics start to nudge their way into the mix, the filmmaker seems unable to maintain that early tone and focus.
Zhang's mixture of unsparing violence, mawkish sentimentality and garish flourishes creates one uncomfortable aesthetic.
The subject's legacy, rather than his currency, is the real story here.
movie_title: Corman's World: Exploits Of A Hollywood Rebel (2011)

movie_review_blurb: How Ritchie can expertly construct such set pieces as a train-bound assault, then thoroughly ruin every other action sequence with his signature self-indulgent slo-mo fetish and gratuitously stuttery editing, is an unsolvable mystery.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Simply showing generations of pasty, fat men pounding each other to a pulp shouldn't be mistaken for an in-depth exploration of Gaelic machismo...
The film's turn toward charcoal-sketch notions of good and evil only fuels a simplistic view of historical tragedy in the worst sort of way.

There's such a graceful sense of restraint in how this real-life tragedy is treated, one that filters any potential for ripped-from-yesterday's-headlines sensationalism through a respectful requiem of loss and grief.
The Yellow Sea is far less interested in character than in choreographing pursuit scenes spiced with Asia Extreme levels of violence.
The title is an understatement.
The movie too often resembles a repetitive cycle of tough guys shouting, shooting and shuffling off this mortal coil.

movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Anatolia wanders into an open-ended verbal bout between the laws of nature and the laws of man, yet the sense of actual musing, much less the mythic storytelling jokingly suggested by its title, dissolves from being to nothingness.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Harrelson's portrayal ... is perilously close to perfect; it's the finest, most harrowing thing he's ever done.

When Vincent Gallo's crazy-sleazy-cool act is the sole element of realism, there's a problem.
Innocence is lost -- as well as 90 minutes of your precious, precious time.
For now, Evans can take pride in the fact that he's set the bar for cinemayhem impossibly high.
Couldn't be more clumsily obvious in its narrative setup or more flavorless in its lo-fi Americana tone.
You'd swear Menkes were remaking Frownland in the Holy Land instead of tweaking a literary totem.
Unless you really dig Glee-level displays of high-school drama geekery, you and your date may want to quickly exeunt.
Only Kristin Scott Thomas channeling In the Loop's Malcolm Tucker offers a spark; the rest is simply hokum designed to land overly sentimental suckers hook, line and sinker.
The movie's multitasking creator seems to have bitten off more then she can chew. Her friends should have advised "baby steps."
Don't even try to keep up with the labyrinthine plot and triple-layered identity confusion.
All whimsical tunes and postcard scenery, while piling on enough ogling shots of nubile young women to make Hugh Hefner feel uncomfortable.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When the lovey-doveyness turns cloying and the atrophied message-mongering creeps in, you wish the threesome knew when to keep their traps shut.
Innocence was lost; so, apparently, was much of the insightful commentary.
While MacLean certainly has a keen eye, the rest of his storytelling facilities haven't quite caught up with it yet.

Anyone expecting an Arabic Army of Shadows will be disappointed; if a muted, moodier approach to the material befits the social-issue subtext, it also severely dampens the tension and pacing that makes these films thrum.
Every time the narrative's underworld schnooks and low-level lowlifes edge their way out of the periphery, a sense of snorting impatience takes over.
The tongue is in cheek and the tone is ironic and bleak, at least until the should-we-stay-or-should-we-go climax punctures the mood.
You're mostly left with facts, dates and iconic poses.
What you don't get is the sense that this pumped-up combat-fatigue chronicle is pandering-or, for that matter, particularly original.
Abandon hope, all ye who expect insight into what made this game-changing gent tick...
Donzelli has, against all odds, crafted a genuinely moving ode to both the tenacity of filial love under extreme circumstances and the toll it extracts.
Even the title dispenses with unnecessary frills: A man escaped. What more do you need to know?
movie_title: Un condamné à mort s'est échappé ou Le vent souffle où il veut (A Man Escaped) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Suddenly, the sneaking suspicion that you've merely been watching an extended PSA for the grassroots organization (Stand for the Silent) starts to take hold.
All but the most ardent 'toon fans are advised to skip the Animated program, which this year traffics in nothing but Pixarish whimsy .
Giant jungle creatures lunge and hiss into the screen, projectiles appear to whiz past your face, and the whiff of vintage cheesiness reeks from easy gotcha! moments.
By the time you realize how stealthy the film's critique has been, you've already fallen right into its trap.
The moment-to-moment textures of Syndromes and a Century are so densely real in their minimalism that they make you suspend all interpretation and simply exist in the present.

This epic film, eschewing dialogue and conventional narrative logic, tells a gripping tale of biological drama through a highly improbable series of evocative images, superb acting and editing, and haunting music.

The political landscape from which this film was born is apparent almost from the start, and though at times less than subtle with its agenda, it still manages to be an incredibly witty, emotional and entertaining movie experience.

Time has passed for the Portokalos family, but everyone is exactly the same as the first time we saw them. Such a regressive aspect is just one of many problems that dwell within My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2.
Set in Puritan era New England, The Witch is an atmospherically driven, religion-coated film that is, at times, both beautiful and terrifying.

Starring Saoirse Ronan in a career-defining role (even more so than her first Academy Award-nominated performance in 2007's Atonement), it may just be among the finer historical period pieces in recent memory.

With the same goofiness and self-referential humor as a character like Spider-Man, but combined with the graphic violence most often seen in DC comics; perhaps Deadpool is just the perfect clash of contradictions.

Starring the very talented Bryan Cranston as the titular character, the film is not only a successful character study and biopic, it is also an engaging and entertaining glimpse at a very dark time in Hollywood's history.

Although marketed as a supposedly progressive film about an important topic, it is, at times, almost unforgivably inaccurate. In addition to this, it is easily one of the most excruciatingly dull films I have seen all year.
Concussion does to the sports film what I was sincerely hoping it would avoid: it dramatizes its subject in such an unbelievable way that it becomes nothing more than mindless propaganda.
It is at once a thoughtful, witty, intelligent, tense, and emotional experience, as beautiful in presentation as it is delightful in spirit.
By simply presenting a true story in its most raw form, it ends up being an entirely believable portrayal of one of the most important cases of the past 20 years.
Though it is a mostly audience-accessible look at a devastating situation, it also does not shy away from the realities of just how something so drastic can change our reality.
Goosebumps finds that balance, managing to capture not only the charm of Stine's work, but the scares as well, without straying too far in either direction.

Black Mass attempts to be something great; yet, when thinking back to it, it's likely only the acting that will be remembered. The film is riddled with common gangster tropes and underdeveloped characters.
The film suffers from an uninteresting plot, poorly developed characters, and a rushed, anti-climactic final battle.
High Noon reflected the heightened fear of the Soviets in the '50s, now similar to the xenophobia that has been raised and further inflamed by our political leaders.
Whether a follower of the series from the start, or just hopping aboard, it's hard not to get a kick out of Rogue Nation.
In the Heart of the Sea is an all-around disappointment. The film suffers from poor direction, an unfocused narrative, and some very underdeveloped characters.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Part sci-fi, part chase film, yet mostly a story about an unusual father-son relationship, Midnight Special is a one-of-a-kind experience.
A Monster Calls stretches into the realms of imagination and dreams, yet it is very much grounded in the reality of life and loss.
Though I still have faith in modern Westerns as a whole, I realize that Jane Got a Gun is one of many that will likely be forgotten in time.
Slow West is the feature debut of writer-director John Maclean. [...] it is also among the more unique modern westerns in the way that it plays around with traditional western tropes and conventions.

Though with the talented Robert Zemeckis at the helm, Allied seldom showcases his trademark focused and proficient direction, which is therefore not enough to raise the film above its many aching flaws.
Though Moonlight employs a stylistic, arthouse approach as opposed to a traditional narrative, it is nonetheless an important one to watch for people of all walks of life.
In a Valley of Violence is a fusion and modernization of old genres, particularly Spaghetti Western, and though not without flaws, it is mostly an entertaining thrill ride.
At times overly violent, and with clunky exposition, Hacksaw Ridge is also remarkably realistic, as visceral an experience in a theater that you are likely to see all year.
Cynical and stylishly alluring, Nocturnal Animals is mostly a memorable success within the neo-noir genre and another indicator of the filmmaking talents of Tom Ford.
Passengers is yet another example of a film that falsely beckons a certain premise in its promotions, yet eventually delivers something far less interesting.
For a film that easily could have just been ripe with clichés, La La Land is instead refreshingly different, and is sure to be a hit with audiences as a result.

With some incredibly innovative action, some deeper, thought-provoking themes, and a plethora of dynamic characters, both old and new, Captain America: Civil War is among the very best of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
Though intimate in scope, Silence has much larger implications; it might just be amongst Scorsese's finest works.

Where The Girl on the Train distinguishes itself, though, is in its forthright presentation. With unbearably over-the-top performances and direction, in addition to an unfocused purpose underlying the story itself, it is an almost unwatchable mess.

It has few standout moments and, in addition, doesn't have anything too deep or thought-provoking to say. Yet, if you simply wish to see a gun-slinging Western with some of your favorite actors, it's a least a passable couple hours at the movies.

By showing too much in an unfocused manner, the grounded reality of the Blair Witch legend is peeled back to reveal the very obvious paranormal story at its heart, making the sequel a dull and listless venture to sit through.
Though Sully doesn't push too far outside the boundaries of its genre, it still manages to be a subtle, understated representation of a very grandiose achievement.

It's not entirely forgettable, yet in our current world where even big stars don't sell movie tickets, The Duel had to have something more in order to really be successful. The film is an unfortunate misfire.

Unfortunately, like many dime-a-dozen horror films, Lights Out suffers from an all-in approach, choosing to simply attempt to scare the viewer by any means necessary rather than working on making it genuine.
The Infiltrator just manages to stand out amongst modern films. Bolstered by a strong cast and an engaging, based on true events story, it is a surprisingly enjoyable experience.

Somehow, The Shallows manages to just surpass the murky depths that most of those films sink to. It emerges as a surprisingly tense and entertaining thriller, though not one without its own set of unfortunate flaws and lost potential.
With a convoluted basis and disengaging story-line, Rings fails to instill the same slow-burning, primal scares that made the first film such a memorable success.

With originality, lively animation, and some powerful heart-strung moments, it will make you feel the same way as the five emotions in Riley's head, at least for a time (it's mostly Joy, though, by the end).
Although mildly entertaining at times, especially in the beginning scenes when we first see Chappie come to life, the film suffers from an uneven storyline.
Miller has truly knocked this one out of the park. A home run if I've ever seen one, and one that I'm looking forward to experiencing again.
Not many movies really get under your skin like Lucrecia Martel's masterful epic.
As a movie about teaching, though, Madam Hyde works wonderfully. In contrast, the supernatural aspects of the film often feel tacked on and out of place.
Western is not a full-on, triumphant success, but in individual moments the film is just too delightful to ignore.
Last Flag Flying is a pleasant watch as a whole, yet it doesn't quite delve as deep as it could, and ultimately feels somewhat forgettable as a result.
Gerald's Game is a mostly faithful, almost entirely enjoyable adaptation of King's novel.
With such talent in front of and behind the camera, it's a shame that The Snowman's narrative and structural problems weren't properly adjusted before its release.
Three Billboards is yet another shining example of McDonagh's distinguished talent as a filmmaker.
Wonder is, in almost every conceivable way, a disaster. It's jumbled, unfocused, poorly acted, and undeservedly sappy.
In an age where 20-year-later sequels are often a disaster, relying too intently on nostalgic value of the originals, Jumanji: Welcome To The Jungle stands head and shoulders above the rest.
We may never know exactly what was going on in Tommy Wiseau's mind when he created one of the worst movies ever made, but The Disaster Artist is a valiant attempt at understanding just that.

The film is the equivalent work of an artist, who, though beginning with a solid, well-rounded image...just didn't allow it to find the proper balance. In the end, perhaps The Shape of Water's ambition just exceeded its grasp.

It attempts...to be a wacky science fiction, a humanistic love story with a sci-fi premise, satirical social commentary, and even dabs of race and white privilege discussions. But in the end, it's too loosely spread out to fully succeed at any of these.
Bogged down by generic action and characters, a confused plot, and an overall sense of been-there done-that, The Cloverfield Paradox, after a momentary burst of excitement, will likely fizzle out.

To conclude, Braven is a fine piece of genre fare. The story itself may sound all-too-familiar, yet its wintry setting, inventive action sequences, and a strong presence by Jason Momoa and supporting cast help it to rise above many like-minded films.

Quinn Shephard's Blame utilizes The Crucible in an inventive way, focusing on high school dynamics and the angst that comes with finding one's identity early in life while also avoiding the cliches that typically come with that subject.
he original Death Wish started a franchise; but this new version will likely be remembered as an unfortunate remnant of political sentiment gone wrong.
Alex Garland's Ex Machina is a chilling view of the future of AI, brought to captivating life through the performances of Isaac, Gleeson, and Vikander.
Despite being 2.5 hours long, The Square is often bitingly original, and as a whole well worth the watch.
Though It does perhaps fall short with scares alone, the film delivers in nearly every other way.

Death House unfortunately doesn't deliver. Its many references and horror icons don't contribute much to a story that is far too caught up in itself to be any fun. Its graphic and lewd nature don't much help either.
The Dark Tower isn't a loathsome film. It's just not praiseworthy either, with the only highlights really being Idris Elba's performance and some passable action sequences.
The Evil Within is far from flawless, but it's hard to argue with Getty's devotion to this singularly distinguished work of art.

Convoluted, messy, and over-stuffed, The Avengers: Age of Ultron also somehow manages to be an incredibly enjoyable ride. Each of the actors bring their A-game, and each of their characters has their own moment to shine.
If you're looking for a good time at the movies, with absolutely zero thinking involved, then you've come to the right place.

A Most Violent Year is a fascinating, intense, character-driven drama, which not only transports you to the state of mind of NYC in the 1980's, but will also show you just how entertaining simplicity can be.
The Imitation Game is a wonderful adaptation of his story, full of brilliant performances, an engaging directing style, and an exuberant soundtrack.

The Battle of the Five Armies is a lot more of the same, substituting mindless, even dull action at the expense of character development [...] there is just enough here to be passable, and it completes The Hobbit trilogy on a mostly positive note.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Theory of Everything is the type of inspirational story that is so often told in biopics. It is beautifully shot, emotionally driven, and a masterclass in acting.

Horrible Bosses 2 is an inferior sequel in nearly every way - it has less laughs, less chemistry, and a much less compelling story, which doesn't even get going until more than halfway through the film.
Telling the story of a boy from age 6 to 18, and filmed over that same time, it is a beautiful, poetic journey of life, with all of its ups, its downs, and, of course, everything in-between.
It is a wildly entertaining film, from the action scenes, to the sets, to the soundtrack, and in addition, it will likely be known as the comeback role for Keanu Reeves.
Logan is a perfect bookend to Hugh Jackman's years of playing the role. To see him go out on such an exuberant high is much more than anyone could have asked for.
Rather than stretch the capacity of the original's themes, this remake shrinks them down to eye level, becoming a forgettable and ultimately pointless endeavor.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is nearly everything you would have wanted from a Marvel franchise sequel.
In part due to a shoddy translation from book to screen, and little effort spent on expanding its themes in compelling ways, The Circle feels like lost potential.
It's the clear and defiant disregard for modern horror tropes that makes It Comes at Night such a refreshing watch.
Spider-Man: Homecoming is neither a full disappointment nor a complete triumph.
It is a wondrously beautiful movie, with intense sci-fi sequences, a solid and talented cast, and even some thought-provoking ideas. This is not one to be missed.
The Book of Henry might be brimming with talent, but in the end it's probably better left unread.
Director Jonathan Lynn cleverly combines broad slapstick, witty jabs at movie conventions, very dark humor, and wild sight gags into a lively mix that keeps the laughs coming.
Kids under 10 who love the cartoon, are apt to really enjoy this movie. Adults who remember the show with fondness, will find it easier to take than many kiddie matinees they have suffered through.
movie_title: The Flintstones in Viva Rock Vegas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderful surprise.
Smarmy sitcom material.
For boxing fans, it's a must see; and a solid video rental down the road for most everyone else.
What the animators lack in new computer-drawn technique, they creatively make up for with a fine artistic sense.
Stone simply attempts too much in Any Given Sunday.
Actually nails the epic feel it is aiming for.
Toy Story was the best of the Disney resurgence of the last decade.
Sophie Marceau is easily the best female foil Bond has had in years.
Laughably ludicrous.
This deliberately paced (to put it politely) drama, rarely kicks into high gear.
Dull turns to ludicrous, as action and plot twists fly at the audience from left field-- if not the bleachers.
This is one of the recent crop of British movies that relies heavily on whimsy and charm -- but very little else.
A mostly smart, well acted, and very well paced and atmospheric thriller!
Delightful!
The Legend of Bagger Vance has pretty actors, pretty words, and some pretty pictures, but is a pretty dull movie.
Reasonably entertaining.
The Muse will appeal to anyone who has ever tried their hand at a creative endeavor.
With bad acting, hillarious dialogue, and ludicrous plot turns that make this a future candidate for Mystery Science Theater 3000 mockery, The Omega Code lurches ahead in fits and starts.
Chill Factor is as fun as watching ice melt!
Nurse Betty is a touch more serious than Raising Arizona, but definitely lighter than Fargo. Best of all, it's in that league of movie making.
2 hours and 9 minutes of pure moviegoing pleasure.
Everything remotely interesting in this movie is overwhelmed by plot silliness and Basinger's terrible central performance.
An emotionally deep script!
Where else are you going get to see five Santas storm a bargain basement casino with guns a' blazin'?
Manages to get the setting, the characters, and best of all the spirit of Tarzan almost right.
It's the extremely natural performances by the three young actors -- particularly Heather Donahue, who deserves an Oscar nomination -- that brings it all together.
Bowfinger gives Eddie Murphy one of his funniest roles ever.
Unfortunately, the rest of the film is not as well thought out or expertly executed as the shocking conclusion.
The special effects may be state of the art, but ultimately, digital water looks like digital water.
Director Kevin Lima directs at a sluggish pace, gives us a few garish -- but not really interesting -- visuals, and the action scenes are amateur night.
The acting is quite good, with Banderas showing once again the charm and athletic ability he brought to The Mask of Zorro.
Russell Crowe is very good as the prickly, explosive Wigand.
Barely better than the pitiful Omega Code.
A stylish, witty and romantic romp!
Dey's pedestrian direction threatens to drain the fun from even the good stuff, by finding the least interesting way to shoot nearly every scene.
Director Sam Mendes presents some memorable images, and moments of Kubrick class clarity, but the whole does not hang together.
A.I. will have you leaving the theater shaking your head in disbelief.
This year, a summer would-be blockbuster that neither stinks, nor takes half the day to watch, is actually an improvement over most releases.
A rather tame flick intellectually, going for pop culture jokes and obvious political quotes, rather than the character-driven, satirical allegory of the original.
Funnier and faster paced than the slack Rush Hour.
Another wonderfully warm, funny, adventurous, and fantastic looking effort from Pixar.
A very good movie, and a faithful adaption of the book.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A great looking film.
In the last half hour, mystical ecobabble takes over, and the movie becomes nearly incomprehensible, plotwise.
Get thee to a theater and see what everyone is talking about!
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie that understands the American fighting man.
The best swashbuckler for most of the family since The Mask of Zorro.
... one beautifully made film.
When was the last time you were in a theater and the audience gasped aloud, not because an alien burst though a body, or someone's head exploded-- but merely because a character drew a gun?
The whole family will certainly enjoy The Rookie, but it's a special treat for fathers and sons getting ready for the upcoming baseball season.
This is one of the sillier Bonds, but the actors seem to be having fun, the pace is quick, and there's a lot to look at. At least it's not a bore like Tomorrow Never Dies.
Don't go to this movie if you've recently had hernia surgery, because the expression 'bust a gut laughing' might go beyond metaphor in your case.
Clever, funny, and even has a great lesson.
This movie is simply incoherent on every level -- emotionally, historically and politically.
That rarest of films --- a vehicle for two big stars that is also smart, deep, and well-written.
A clever and adventurous combination of The Princess Bride and Beauty and the Beast.
Ledger is an appealing hero, and the movie is harmless enough.
An uncommonly absorbing movie.
Will undoubtedly run alongside A Christmas Story on cable stations around the Christmas season for years to come as a staple of the Season.
At its best, Thirteen Days is as gripping as a good thriller and as informative as a good documentary.
Quite entertaining, and well worth seeing, if only for Hanks' sensational performance.
While the book has its share of contrivances ... This 95 minute movie rushes over everything so quickly, that the plot holes look an awful lot bigger.
Soderbergh deftly directs Traffic, keeping things moving with nary a jam.
Clooney's dumb version of his usual smart guy act works great, but his partners really steal the show.
Hip, furious, and darkly funny.
Hannibal should make everyone involved ashamed.
Instead of the swelling score and big Drama, Ememy could have used a little Three Kings sardonicism.
Not only terrifically entertaining, but has a great message, as well.
A very funny and likeable comedy of manners.
One of the most popular Westerns of all time, the heroic story of The Magnificent Seven has influenced countless other movies in nearly every genre.
The action-oriented, straight-up good vs. evil, moral- ambguity-be-hanged, Western star vehicle has never been done better than this.
A captivating, thoroughly enjoyable, romantic romp.
One of the world's greatest legends has been reborn as one of the year's greatest films; here's why it's true.
Jamie Foxx helms a warm-hearted comedy. It's entirely predictable, but it's a humorous good time.
It's thematically identical to its predecessor, but "Shrek 2" is still a hysterical knockout of a film. Fun, stylish, and totally irresistible.
Morgan Spurlock goes on an exclusive McDonalds' diet to prove that their food is high in fat & cholesterol. His experiment was as pointless then as his documentary is today.
Harry Potter fans, stand up and cheer for Alfonso Cuarón, who in taking the reins for the third film in the series, has finally infused energy and vitality into the franchise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This flick attempts to take its audience across the entire spectrum of Hollywood genres in 80 minutes (give or take a few)... bad idea.
"Two Brothers" is a wildly emotional, surprisingly delightful story of persecution, devotion and the triumphant determination of love.
Speilberg and Hanks make "The Terminal" an enjoyable flight, and not an interminable bore.
"The Notebook" is a story for those who believe that love is the most powerful force in the universe... or for those who merely want to.
"Don't See It" is the kindest phrase I can use to describe this film.
Frankly, I wanted to stand up, shout "Get a room" at the two characters, and do something more interesting... like watching paint peel.
Will Ferrell's commitment to sophomoric comedy is encroaching on religious zeal: "Anchorman" is Ferrell at his best.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The Ugly, The Bad, and The Good... totally in that order.
No matter what you read elsewhere, don't dodge this flick; it's by far the funniest movie thus far of 2004.
Braveheart meets the Round Table in this epicly atrocious version of the King Arthur legend. My advice is to follow the cast's lead and run screaming.
Tom Hanks and the Coen brothers revisit "The Ladykillers"... you'll either love it or hate it... I'm in the first category.
Folks, it's an instant gay classic that's bigger than a beehive... with heart to match.
"The Perfect Score" flunks its way right off the screen and right into the juvenile halls of film gone bad.
De-lovely might be decorous, but it falls significantly short of its own lofty artistic intents... in short, was should have been de-lightful is barely mediocre.
Disney has another hit on their hands with "Miracle"... it's not suspenseful, but it's great entertainment.
"Against the Ropes" has slim, sizzling Meg Ryan in its corner... but the film is a loosely-patched version of about twelve other movies.
If you're smart, you'll skip "Concessions of an Teenage Drama Queen" and buy $10 of stock in Comcast instead.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Gene Hackman and Ray Romano lead "Welcome to Mooseport" right into mediocrity.
Mel Gibson's personal vision of the persecution and death of Christ is relentless, brutal... and brilliant.
"Hidalgo" is a barely entertaining movie; what it does best is prove that Viggo Mortensen has legs
Intellectually demanding but ultimately satisfying, "Eternal Sunshine" plays to the strengths of its cast and well-bred creative team.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: "Scooby Doo" is back with an inconceivable feat: it's a worse movie than the first.
As far as the latest crop of repetitive superhero movies goes, Hellboy is heaven-sent.
Disney's latest epic is a solid, entertaining film - even if it adds nothing all that interesting to the legend of the Alamo.
Anne Hathaway's performance as a cursed maiden in this time-jumbled fantasy is enchanting... but the movie is not.
It's got enough cute love to keep the attention of teenage girls everywhere... but "The Girl Next Door" is too farfetched and contrived to be memorable.
Quentin Tarantino's unabashed revenge epic evolves into a full-bodied, daring climax in Kill Bill Vol. 2.
Sleek, sexy, savage and entirely too serious about itself... that's "The Punisher" in a nutshell... but three out or four ain't bad.
Will Smith is darker, sexier in his latest summer blockbuster... but despite an entertaining execution of Isaac Asimov's robotic visions, it leaves you cold.
Technically dazzling, thematically rich, and filled to the brim with holiday warmth, "The Polar Express" is an instant holiday classic. Climb aboard!
I was rooting for the sharks.
Dear Renée: We like your work. But if you put on forty pounds to recreate the moronic character of Bridget Jones one more time, we're going to take it personally.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It might feel like a Dan Brown bestseller. But Americans have an appetite for historical mysteries... and capitalizing on that appetite is about as American as you can get.
The movie is present, sexy and fun, but it's probably time to give this franchise - and Snipes' permanent scowl - a rest.
Surrounded by talented performances, DiCaprio nearly pulls off a trick as effective as the illusive world cast by Howard Hughes: it almost looks like he can really act.
An emotionally-potent, visually-arresting picture that makes for one of the most enjoyable offerings of the season.
Damn you! Curse you! Lloyd Webber's caustically commercialized but well-directed musical comes to the screen in a colorful, expensive, thoughtless and overacted translation.
Pierce Brosnan and Salma Hayek attempt to heat up the screen in the action caper "After the Sunset"... but despite effective pacing, the movie barely reaches a simmer.
Proceeding from a ridiculous premise, this fish-out-of-water tale manages to create a passably humorous film for kids.
Girlfriend should have stayed dead.
A powerful, stirring, necessary film.
It's a blast... literally.
Perhaps the movie should have been called "Four Bridesmaids and a Hookah."
Heads out of the treehouse at an abominable crawl, but once the honey starts to flow, it picks up speed and becomes the sweetest film of the series.
It's not a surprising film, but "Win a Date with Tad Hamilton" is irresistable - the first film worth seeing in 2004.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even Samuel L. Jackson's performance can't save this glorified press release from its "been there, done that" fate.
Keanu's back in black, and in a 'hell' of a fun movie... what's not to love?
It's funny, dramatic, even heroic: "The Incredibles" largely lives up to its name. But you'll still leave the film feeling that Pixar left something on the table.
"Ray" starts out well... and then falls into the entrenched paths of just about every other overwrought, over-long musical biopic ever filmed.
Matt Damon and Paul Greengrass have created a fiery, quick-witted film that presents compelling evidence that the action-suspense genre has been "Bourne again."
Demme's visuals are as captivating as Frankenheimer's were in the 1960s... yet the plot of this "Manchurian Candidate" lost quite a bit in the translation.
Thunderbirds are GO! Head for this high-flying frivolity for fun, not brain matter. For kids of all ages, it's F-A-B.
Michael Cunningham's film is an alluring look at how definitions of love, friendship and loyalty are ultimately self-defeating. It's got a few flaws, but a big ol' heart.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx give the movie tension and momentum, and director Michael Mann gives it something most action flicks lack: style.
Without a paddle lives up to its name; it sinks.
I suppose it could have been worse: it could have been longer.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The mythology of "Star Wars" with the stylized flair of 1940s film noir, digitally dreamed and superbly acted. Say hello to what could be the best film of 2004.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most entertaining part of Christian Taylor's "Showboy" is deciphering fact from fiction... and that's not a compliment.
Made me long for my free nights and weekends.
Filmmaking of least resistance, in which true heroism is exploited for emotional spare change.
Evokes "The Sopranos" under water, its lack of innovation akin to a boulder tied around its feet: "Shark Take" sinks to the bottom and quietly drowns.
Peter Berg's skilled vision and Billy Bob's retrained performance result not only the best football film we've seen in years... but also one of the best movies of 2004.
Its wit is played at the expense of unexpected targets... still, "Team America" is a descent into truly offensive, hysterical satire.
Cute. Waltzes right past "airy" on its way to the Sugarland Express. Keep your insulin handy.
Halle just hacked a hairball all over the summer boxoffice. And it ain't pretty.
"The Butterfly Effect" tries to prove that small actions have big effects... but it really proves that January movies tend to suck.
