Another sloppily concocted and naggingly non-controversial pretext for Sandler to pelvic thrust his way though a succession of increasingly wacky fish-out-of-water situations.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a dull, if competently made, film, which is done no favours by its earnest tone, a soppy orchestral score and a slew of artificial performances by actors clinging far too tightly to their lines. It would be far better suited to daytime TV.
Crump's film colourfully depicts Wagstaff's complex inner mindset and rarefied eye for imagery by allowing the stunning prints to linger on the screen.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It is impressively made, but leaves a nasty taste in the mouth.
Blindsight is a great example of the emotional dividends that careful photography, sensitive editing and an atmospheric score can deliver.

Making the farcical tenor of the recent Indiana Jones film feel like a paragon of dramatic and archaeological integrity, this phoned-in action threequel doesn't even have the good grace to deliver on its title and feature any mummies
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though the narrative is saggy and you feel there's nowhere left to go after the first hour, a much-needed dash of class from Jon S Baird's direction helps lift 'Cass' above its oft-reactionary genre brethren.
Overall an emotionally rich and tender film, beautifully played, with heart and head in massive abundance.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: They say sarcasm is the lowest form of wit. Well 'they' obviously haven't seen 'The Love Guru', an overgrown dirt-patch of clunking juvenilia.
Daylight Robbery...the exact expression that you're likely to utter if you pay for a ticket to see this utter garbage.
Quote not available.
You could hardly call it a paragon of impartial filmmaking, but this is still a compelling and immersive glance into the nature of competitiveness and the corrupting aspects of fame.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Light on both CGI and moral quandaries, [it posesses] neither the zip and sparkle of a Spider-Man nor the brooding existential subtexts of Batman Begins.
Simon DaVison's loopy labour of love succeeds where other offerings of pure homage (most recently 'Grindhouse') failed.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A stark yet comforting reminder that cold, hard cash is no substitute for cold, hard talent. 'The Hottie and the Nottie' is an execrable Z-grade eugenics parable moonlighting as a sexy, disposable date movie.
An exceptional piece of filmmaking, intricate, elaborate and exuding warmth and wisdom from its every frame.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: 'Semi-Pro' resorts to the bombast of brash 'infotainment' news and sports programming to mine its humour.
90 minutes of violence. No more, no less.
The magnitude of Gondry's visual ingenuity is consistently jaw-dropping.
Andrei Kravchuk's film is sensitive to the hilt and pleasingly attuned to the guileless outlook of its hero.

The one area where 'Walk Hard' does manage to hold its own against classics of the genre such as 'This is Spinal Tap' or 'Sweet and Lowdown' is the music, all of which is expertly written and performed.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A slightly meandering build-up is saved by a second half that really cooks, with Vargas ratcheting up the tension by flirting with genre convention in order to deal with Plutarco's unconventional psychological stand-off with a malodorous Captain.
Passes the time, but undoutedly one for the little 'uns.
Do anything: rob a petrol station, superglue your eyelids together, chew on broken glass, just avoid at all costs.

This overreaching, Lynch-lite comic drama is the mediocre directorial debut of screenwriter John August ('Charlie's Angels', 'Big Fish') and, if nothing else, demonstrates why some writers should stick to their laptops.
This is cinema for people who slow down at car wrecks.
Echoing Malick's 'Days of Heaven' in the way it captures the majesty of the American countryside, this is a small gem that's worth seeking out.
It makes for frustrating and unreasonably demanding viewing.
This playfulness, however, backfires massively in the second half when coincidence and unforeseen consequence conspire uneasily with bloody, messy results.
It's a familiar tale, but one told with gusto, wit and visual flare...
The stylishly mounted first half zips along at a rate of knots while the gruesome make-up work will keep your gag reflex in violent spasm.

This brilliant, desperately sad Steinbeckian fable from American director Kelly Reichardt. It's Reichardt's third full-length feature ('Old Joy' was in cinemas last year), but only her first masterpiece.
It just about works as an exercise in empty style, but that doesn't compensate for the small matter of its near-total incomprehensibility.
Saying that a film has too much insight is hardly damning.

The insight-neutral scrag ends of what feels like ten decent documentaries on censorship, semantics, social policy and broadcasting coalesce in this painfully self-satisfied and poorly made 'shock-doc'.
Tense and teasingly ambiguous...
Parker's film feels clouded by his obvious posthumous adoration of the enigmatic Sid. His witnesses are less than credible and his argument feels fumbled.
An extremely impressive and intricate family drama from Japanese director Kiyoshi Kurosawa.
The ironies are always cruel and never comic in British writer-director Duane Hopkins's striking debut, an austere, though empathetic, insightful and technically crisp slice of social realism.
It's a comically inept and unfocused piece of filmmaking, with 'This Is England'-lite period detail attained by what looks like a bring-your-own-costume policy.
It's never enough to establish any sensitivity or social pertinence beyond the trifling tiffs which are playing out on screen.

While it's not animated with the breathless pizazz of a Pixar, 'Despereaux' is all the more affecting and dramatically successful for its contemplative pace and measured delivery of information. A lovely film.

De Sica's neo-realist lodestone may have retained its vitality over the decades, but whatever sense of anger it whipped up in the disgruntled masses of postwar Rome feels lost to the excessively syrupy score.
Paramount's first film in (lavender-hued) VistaVision was this pornographically soppy but, nonetheless, hearty and humorous 1954 festive romp.

The Man from London' lacks the grandiose 'cosmic' intimations of the director's past work, and though it contains many moments of sublime cinematic choreography, this is finally good Tarr, but not great Tarr.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a familiar tale, but one told with gusto, wit and visual flare.
For a film about upholding personal ideals, its glossy packaging and derivative 'will he get the girl?' narrative sell any credibility down the river in favour of affected screwball larks.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A spunky, impassioned and resourceful doc on the cutthroat world of US college basketball made for a pittance by Adam Yauch.
It's possibly the Coens' least romantic film, which makes the cynical tone a tough pill to swallow, but chances are that you'll be too busy hooting and chuckling idiotically to notice.
For the most part, the affable, loose approach to filming works well in eliciting a genuine worldview from the film's (largely likeable) subjects.
At best, you'll be disappointed; at worst, you'll want to blow up a high school.
Enjoyable as it is to see Gervais trying (and often succeeding) to make something of the mediocre dialogue, it's not enough.

Pitt, toying with his death-wish like some private joke, is eminently watchable in a role with little developmental arc; while Affleck, as his unwitting nemesis, takes his own mysterious integrity right to the grave.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The finale, too, still feels as twisted, bizarre and down-right nightmarish as it did all those years ago.

This laconic artificially quirky debut from Japanese writer-director Fujita Yosuke settles for a rudimentary comic inspection of the dreary existence of a clutch of twentysomethings forced to reject their aspirations in order to face up to adult realities

'Choke' never manages to be as edgy, amusing, insightful or plain messy as you'd hope it would be, especially considering its 'naughty' promotional poster and the distribution of anal beads as a marketing device.
Slight but very pleasant to sit through.
movie_title: Dialogue avec mon jardinier (Conversations with My Gardener) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film that feels every bit the product of its purportedly ruthless and artistically corrupting milieu.
This frisky if long-winded and derivative French policier never gets off the starting-blocks despite some charismatic performances and intriguingly executed set-pieces.
Sending a flying v-sign right at the splendid Robert Wise original from 1951, this daft and pointless sci-fi remake has very little to recommend it.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While the genial comic tone and steady torrent of sharp one-liners and social faux pas are effortlessly carried forward from her past work, this is a more subtle, contemplative and mature film.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Depardon's palpable sense of respect for his subjects lends the film a geniality that would otherwise have been hard to fabricate.
movie_title: Profils Paysans: la Vie Moderne (Modern Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Opportunities to comment on the ethical grey areas of suicide are mostly squandered and, as the pointless digressions begin to pile up, your mind begins to drift from the action on screen.
A decent Parisian thriller that rides on the tails of a calling-card turn from Isabelle Carré as a lovelorn stalker-cum-social-menace who falls in love with her doctor.
There's little here for British eyes.
Nic Cage seems comfortable in the role of the flaming-skulled biker, but the plot holes are too deep even for his Herbie-like arachnid motorcycle to negotiate.
Lurches on a thin line between hyper-ornate space oddity and extended perfume advert.

It reserves singing and dancing for the stage until Jamie Foxx just randomly bursts into verse while strolling down the street. Dreamgirls wants to be Effie but ends up as Deena: thin, smooth, unburdened by a personality.
Essentially, it's a Koyanisquaasti for metal and meat fetishists, and that's no bad thing.
The film's whimsicality makes it a big step back for the director, who shows he has little handle over anything bar garish action set-pieces.

Take away a couple of neatly staged action sequences and you're left with a callously measured slab of US jingoism that deals with the most horrific human tragedies in the most lunk-headed and insulting way possible.
Clearly intended to be viewed through a haze of marijuana smoke, it'd be against the law for us to recommend this film.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: [A] sporadically hilarious assortment of weapons-grade idiocy.
... a film that never quite equals the sum of its many intriguing parts.

From its non-committal title downwards -- we're a bit worse than ankle deep, but not quite neck deep -- the film includes a final shot that is almost surreal in its implausibility. Waist Deep? More like Deep Waste.
Escapist dilettantes may find A Good Year light, breezy and charming but even the most rudimentary inspection will reveal the film's sickeningly rotten core.
The film says just as much about the state of American politics, the emergence of a mass media and the perceived sanctity of religion as it does about one of the world's lesser-known demagogues.
The film paints with swaggeringly broad strokes, the basic thesis being Lennon = good, government = bad.
Cuts a fine balance between the stylised and the austere.
movie_title: L' Amico di Famiglia (The Family Friend) (Friend of the Family) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As a whole the film feels trite in the way it trivialises and sentimentalises what it is claiming to be an inherently flawed system.
For a band whose music is suffused with such delicate irony, you'd expect at the very least for there to be a few laughs along the way? There are none. Nothing. Zero.

Beerfest is a film that appears to have been conceived on the back of a beermat and its trashy direction, nonexistent plot and dismal comic mugging would seem to suggest that preparations progressed no further.
A fantastically executed assemblage of animated flotsam punctuated with moments of dry humour and a heartbreaking final montage which gives the film its message - make every moment count.
Very silly.
As 85-minute testosterone binges go, you could do a whole lot worse.
Favreau gratifyingly prevents the film from becoming a mere maelstrom of CG effects by pushing the brothers' amusing bickering to the fore...
[A] steely 1964 study in the cruel mechanics of illicit love.
One of the great musicals.
This is an undoubtedly modest yet wholly pleasurable tale about the difficulties that come with letting go of youth.
Thoroughly different from To Be or Not To Be but just as exhilarating, it's one of the few films truly justifying Lubitsch's reputation for a 'touch.'
The film is all the more interesting for remaining an eccentric one-of-a-kind that feels every bit the product of its writer-director's unique sensibility and worldview.

Mixing early-'80s nostalgia with mild social anthropology, the film successfully crystallises the optimism and vivacity of the early New York hip hop scene and suggests that film and TV portrayals of the Bronx as a savage and inhospitable hellhole were pe

At once a lament to the ravages of age and an examination of those tiny foibles which separate reality from dramatic artifice, it's a baffling and intricate film which, although light on conventional pleasures, still manages to provoke and beguile.

The numerous, unflinchingly filmed scenes of public and gang rape make this a visceral, if gruelling, experience, especially when juxtaposed with sprawling, beautifully photographed vistas of the Indian deserts and mountain ranges.
Incredibly rich and satisfying. Would easily stand up to multiple viewings.
The shaky camerawork and naturalistic performances mark the film's kinship with quasi-realist sitcoms like The Office and Curb Your Enthusiasm.

Director Mike Binder has twigged on to the fact that if you root Sandler's genially churlish moron act into a more sober foundation, a vulnerable, believable and even lovable character can begin to emerge.
A veritÃ (C) riff on the â~Police Academyâ(TM) series is the idea behind cult US sitcom â~Reno 911!â(TM), which, here, is stretched to breaking point for this puerile punt at cinematic glory.
The paper-thin characters make it feel less like a rounded feature and more like a TV pilot with the promise of more adventures to come.
A nuts-and-bolts document of the annual Air Guitar World Championships which take place in the rural outpost of Oulu in Finland.

With its themes of social displacement subtly and skilfully enmeshed within a pleasingly straightforward shaggy-dog narrative, this is one of those films that runs at you with open arms, and you'll find it very difficult not to succumb.

The photography is of the sort you'd find in any half decent nature documentary, with cloying emphasis placed firmly (and sometimes clumsily) on the idea that our neglectful, selfish and not to mention rampantly capitalist ways are destroying the planet.
Christopher Lee's Dracula is a menacing and complex presence who never lets his fangs and cape dominate.
Sure, the rage is palpable in every cell, but poise and rational thinking are sadly lacking.

The film's best moment by far comes from Eddie's under-the-thumb buddy Mac (Rob Corddry), who advises that the key to a healthy marriage is to 'plaster on a smile and wait patiently for the sweet embrace of death'.
It's a slow, sometimes grating process for an hour or so, but once everyone wises up to their shared heritage, a euphoric celebration of what it means to be a gypsy takes flight.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Done no favours by its camera-phone aesthetic, Tough Enough doesn't have much of a sell-by date.
A waste of time. A waste of celluloid. A waste of talent.
An expertly crafted thriller which offers a pessimistic, though deeply rewarding, glimpse of a society being haunted by its own past.
Buckling under the weight of its own hubris, the potentially scandalous premise ends up feeling like a Dan Brown knock-off.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's teary-eyed conclusion is clearly intended to have you punching the air in elation, but the message it delivers will actually leave you feeling quite cold.
movie_title: In the Hands of the Gods (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its undeniable thematic richness, 'Legacy' marks a slight return for Georgian director Géla Babluani.

With its series of tonally awkward plot developments which seem to have been engineered specifically to meet Radcliffe's various portfolio needs, the best that could be said of this is that the actor's next move should be to talk to his agent.
An intriguing set-up spoiled by a clever-clever script, Christophe Beaucarne's migraine-inducing cinematography and performances which are decent, but never gel.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Performances and script are both first-rate, but what really rivets is how scarily /familiar/ it all feels, from the listless rebound romances to the forced insularity of post-breakup bachelorhood. Superb stuff.
What a poorly developed and resiliently stupid piece of work this is.
Thematically, though, this is an improvement on its forebears, mainly due to the way it deals - much like Scorsese's best work - with the archaic nature of the criminal set.
This wannabe highbrow horror-thriller is a graceless, unfocused piece of work with a central narrative as tonally schizophrenic and wayward as its lead.
Even though the precisely layered, Jenga-tower narrative becomes tiresome towards the end, punches that could have easily been pulled in the final scenes make firm and full contact.
The Seventh Seal is an existentialist masterpiece packed with stunning symbolism and mordant humour. It's also far more accessible that you might think. Go see it. Or else.
Hardly a groundbreaking work, but still a worthy addition to the singular Ghibli canon.
A brave, thoughtful documentary.

French- Algerian director Tony Gatlif shows great skill in capturing local colour and texture, sourcing a rogues' gallery of memorable images from the fog-shrouded environs. He's less successful at giving any direction or meaning to his central pairing's

The direction from Polish New Waver Agnieszka Holland feels more like she's testing a new camera than attempting to capture the nuances of the artistic process, and if we're to believe the script, then all great art derives 'from the gut'.
A deadpan delight that offers further proof of Romania's cinematic ascendance.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Feran favours intellectual showboating over subtlety, slathering this poorly paced and cripplingly long film in primitive symbolism, meaningful gazes and pensive longueurs.

Though the film falters in terms of its lack of a streamlined narrative, there is no denying that it is packed to the rafters with meaty ideas and characters who are charged with a satisfying moral ambivalence.
It's an admirable first feature from writer-director Niall Heery, but one that never really says anything broader about Irish society or the shackles of fame.
The direction smacks of sadism, especially the obvious glee Gilbey gets from filming violent scenes in close-up and, in the case of the bloody shotgun-to-the-face denouement, in triplicate.
A charismatic and charming film with lots of delightful turns of phrase but it also ends up feeling as frivolous and fleeting as its main protagonist.
Over-extended but nonetheless thought provoking and humorous documentary.
Making no effort to be original, exciting, witty or even vaguely plausible, it may pass the time as sparkly fodder for 12-year-old boys with plenty of sugar in their bloodstream.
This bruised and brilliant fairy tale is one of the year's true originals.
Assayas returns with a hulking, seething, intermittently sublime, five-and-a-half hour film in which he manages to draw together elements from both of these distinct styles.
Beneath its light exterior is not only a neat, if unsubtle, political undercurrent but a rebellious streak about how the allure of firing an RPG outweighs the prospect of retirement.
The camera lingers on the soldiers' smiles and tears and shows the human face of military tactics which reduce people to chess pieces.

If someone laced Wallace and Gromit's stockpile of West Country cheeses with hallucinogens, they might start to show some of the free-associative abandon of the characters in this trippy debut feature...
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Reeves's direction lunges more resolutely for the mainstream jugular, but that's no bad thing.
Feels all but indistinguishable from the thousands of similar films that have blazed a trail before it.

Moving but never sentimental, ambient but rigorously focused, this is an assured, refreshingly simple film where the dramas and responsibilities of parenthood exist inside a bubble of blissed-out tropicalia.
The film is made up of half-formed sketches in which Phoenix comes across like a childish crank who's escaped from his soap box at Speakers' Corner.
If there's a problem with the film, it's the idea that two people would instinctively choose to immerse themselves in unbroken role play.
[A] snarling but predictable survival tale...
Again, it's worth the price of admission alone to spend time in the company of Sweden's premiere bisexual emo-sleuth...
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The focus here is less on creating a credible set of characters and motives than on manufacturing an excuse to have Jolie leapfrog between high-speed lorries.
Tati thought anything could be funny, and while Chomet runs with that idea as a director, he challenges it as a storyteller.
If you like watching men with no necks thumping each other, this could be your Citizen Kane.

The vitriol and hurt coursing through this prickly, scandalous pre-code melodrama from 1932 may wrong-foot those who had director Frank Capra pegged as head cheerleader for good ol' American democracy and cheery, affirmative humanist values.
Sly, understated and ruthlessly focused, the functional yet elegant photography by Sabine Lancelin enhances the film's ironic kick.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Imagine if you salvaged a grubby VHS tape off the roadside only to discover it contained outtakes from an amateur Jackass knock-off.
It's cheeky and confident, maybe one of the director's finest, and its loopy final line is the cryptic cherry on this oddball gâteau.

Nothing feels like it's been properly thought through, highlighted by the fact that Nighy's 'super assassin' goes about his business by merely opening fire on a crowded market place (using a silencer, of course!).
The film's big strength is its unwillingness to dish out easy answers
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The one element that lifts this above utter tedium is the presence of Stephen Merchant as tooth-fairy administrator Tracy. That he manages to come away with his dignity intact is testament to his skill as a comedian.
Palestinian director Elia Suleiman's most eloquent and moving feature to date.

With its excessive levels of casual racism, sexism and homophobia, the film feels like nothing more than a rejected 'Derek and Clive' sketch that's been stripped of eloquence and irony and calibrated instead for cheap, leery laughs.
The movie has vim and spark in abundance and the filmmakers are canny enough to let the cast play to their strengths.
An astute study of amour fou and a cautionary tale about how the worship of false idols can lead to personal and national collapse.
Even those who shrug at his combative style of humour won't be able to deny that this is a model of detailed and distanced biographical filmmaking.
This latest from writer-director Jared Hess is another unsavoury stew of kitsch juvenilia that furthers the rot that set in between his first two films...
La Danse is an example of cinema at its most musical, an awe-inspiring celebration of body, mind and movement.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: More than ever, Bujalski comes across like the natural heir to someone like Eric Rohmer, an artist who creates intricate, perceptive and artful cinema that rejects unnecessary style and contrivance.
Deftly moderating her patented eye-rolling poseur shtick, Page delivers her most charismatic and least divisive performance to date as Bliss Cavendar, aka Babe Ruthless.
Tetro is a movie filled with splashes of brilliance rather than being a plain brilliant movie.

This cliché-ridden war story from Indonesian director Yadi Sugandi suggests that the Dutch occupation of Indonesia in the post-war period played out like a tawdry TV movie made with the help of a dressing-up box and lots of fake blood and fireworks.
There is a sweet chemistry between Depardieu and Casadesus, but their wry interactions are lost within a rambling, frothy non-story that aims squarely for the heart over the head.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Perfect hokum for those who don't mind having their heart strings strummed like a banjo.
While the context of Matthew Vaughn's slick 'X-Men' origin story feels like it's been filched from the notepad of a GCSE History student, there's no shortage of breathtaking spectacle elsewhere.
Terrible orch-rock soundtrack aside, it makes for an engrossing if hollow romp.
You'll end up baffled that a film built on such shaky foundations can end up being so impossibly sweet.
The film is built as a long crescendo, opening at a level of considered, Zen-like reflection and ending with a prolonged cacophony of elaborate, town-wide annihilation.
Manages to say more about man's relationship with dogs in a single, lush frame than 'Marley and Me' would if it were to run on a loop until the end of time.
So-called 'slow cinema', if executed with delicacy, has the power to exert a trance-like hold over us, but this one falls flat at every dreary hurdle.
Loach has made a film uncluttered by an obvious director's stamp, peopled by sympathetic characters and driven by a desire to say something about the world without losing sight of human experience.
Delivering an absolute minimum of context, the film dares us to forge our own reasons for rooting for or despising this savage.
Offers a rousing reminder of the power (and eccentricities) of the pissed-off proletariat.
It's scatty and fast paced, and director Neil Burger employs some Gaspar Noé-style, bad-trip CG effects to heighten the mood.
A tougher and more genre-inspired work that we'd expect from social-realist doyen Loach.
There's plenty of ambiguous intellectual heft lurking behind the curtain of mediocrity - so it's a pity it feels like it was dashed off in a few hours one afternoon.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing, unhysterical thriller that largely rejects the clichés of the genre.

The usual string of hackneyed and largely laugh-free set-ups involving vulgar chat-up lines, hash brownies and a mad, jealous guy with a crowbar, all seemingly purpose-honed to appeal to devotees of 'The Hangover'.
The performances of the young cast attain an affecting blend of reticence and hope, but it's Tran's fastidious technique that nudges the film into the realms of greatness.

Nolfi began his career as a writer, which perhaps explains why he tries to keep the action character-driven: the sweet chemistry between Damon and Blunt does at least make their romantic, potentially existence-threatening bond credible.
With no culture-clash cliché left unplundered, Andy DeEmmony sets his camera to autopilot for a film which never decides who or what it's about.
Apichatpong doesn't use his camera to stress what we should be looking at, thinking or hearing. He uses long takes and subtle edits to generate moods, atmospheres and feelings.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A more apt title would be 'The Girl Who Sat Quietly in a Dimly Lit Room'.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For a film whose stock in trade are tongue-in-cheek reversals of comic-book cliché, it too often settles for trite audience-pleasing.
Its rambling structure, peppered with lyrical, magical-realist asides, may not be to all tastes, but there's a sense that Gondry wants this to be more than an eccentric personal portrait...
[A] workaday psychological thriller which, although decently crafted, lacks even a scintilla of subtlety or ambition.
A pleasant movie, but no more.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It blazed a bloody trail for the much-loved slasher cycle, but it also assured us that a B-movie could be A-grade in quality and innovation.
It's perhaps asking a bit much to read it as anything more than a claustrophobic portrait of sexual danger, but it still fulfils that highly specific brief with blood-splashed gusto.
The title is marketing 101: how to sell a schlocky, throwback genre picture on the back of the past glories of a director who once dealt solely in amped-up, literate and ballsy entertainment...
That the finale ends up being trite is a shame, but the long, gentle jaunt to arrive there is a pleasurable one.
Contrived, mawkish and mirthless, this feels like it was made by people who haven't had any meaningful human contact for years.
Small details are magnified by Philibert's long, quiet takes, and Nénette's mundane human characteristics make us consider our own lives and how we relate to the natural world.
Even if it doesn't quite gel, it's admirable that a film made of such weird ingredients is even vaguely palatable.

It's a hilarious and informative movie, and in the pantheon of films about filmmaking, it strikes a neat balance between the operatic neuroses of '8 1/2' and the warm, pastel-hued nostalgia of 'Singin' in the Rain'.
[Gondry] has done a stellar job of putting his wacky auteurial stamp on a comedy which is only semi-coherent but still very funny and impeccably fashioned.
The film's nostalgic design is subtle enough not to dampen the seriously sinister atmospherics.
This is imbecilic hooey of the rarest breed.
A comic potshot at the arms industry that makes for a hearty, if modest, return to form.
As a director, Gross paints in big, emotive strokes, and though his dialogue often feels too tied to historical fact, this old-fashioned, patriotic war movie has its heart in the right place.
Unlike its more lively predecessor, this is more interested in dissecting the criminal mindset.
The film has a lot to say about the effect of technology on teenage interaction, how schools repress individuality and how sexual awakening causes, rather than relieves, teenage angst.
A luminous musical about dreams, romance and destiny which lovingly reworks the classic Hollywood 'putting on a show' template into an essay on the emotional rollercoaster ride that is movie-going.
movie_title: The Young Girls of Rochefort (Les Demoiselles de Rochefort) (1968)

movie_review_blurb: Cassel injects a jolt of wild energy and ambiguity into what could easily have been another flatulent, apologist gangster epic.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This charming, affectionately crafted and gleefully unfashionable comic miniature from writing/directing troupe Abel, Gordon and Romy slips down a treat.
Any one of these stories, if properly fleshed out and shorn of contrivance, would have made for a perfectly serviceable film. Instead, we have lots of hysterical little bits of nothing much.
'Once Upon a Time...' now looks like an over-cooked mess of style, metaphor and reference.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)

movie_review_blurb: They may as well have called this one 'Mis-Matched Sham Wedding Comedy #57513' for all the effort it makes to shake new life out of a tattered genre.
Occasionally marred by contrivance and a crude internal logic that doesn't bear close scrutiny, 'Frozen River' works best as a knuckle-gnawing, blue-collar genre thriller.
With its hokey, flashback-heavy plotting, unadventurous camera use and a clutch of cloyingly earnest performances, it comes across like an irony-free, mid-season episode of 'Xena: Warrior Princess'.
Poignant, lightly philosophical and beautifully performed.
Jeffs makes a good fist of the direction and Blunt proves that she can do comedy, but it's Adams's comforting, charismatic central turn which really gives the film its lift.
It may tickle a type of hardened horror connoisseur, but most will want a shower after seeing it.
movie_title: Encarnação do Demônio (Devil's Reincarnation) (Embodiment of Evil) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Johnny Kervorkian sets up the film nicely, but by the end, your worst fears are realised when it climaxes in the most anodyne way possible.

As well-intentioned as it is deathly dull, this moody, London-set indie attempts to fuse a sprawling, right-on social agenda with a tenderly wrought mismatched romance and doesn't manage to say anything interesting about either.

Here is an artist who has gone back to the drawing board and pared down his act to deliver a stark and complex humanist message with technical brio and a broad knowledge of cinema, demonstrating real poise and originality.
Writer-director-actor Jacques Nolot (below) delivers a bold, searching and open-hearted turn as the subject of this confessional study of life as an elderly gay gent in the French capital.

It's a small, well-rounded movie that you'd be hard pressed to find fault with, achieving its modest goals with subtle aplomb while whipping up humour and empathy from Antoine's rapport with his doddery clientele.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a terrible film, so blithely wrong-headed in its execution that some scenes are quite entertaining in an 'is this really happening?' kind of way.
While Cyrus's droll performance (Miley's not Billy Ray's) deserves better material, this is still amply entertaining.
Mundruczó generates a moderate amount of intrigue from the build-up but stubbornly resists handling his themes in any direct and digestible fashion.
Awkward pauses and gestures and moments of self-examination give it a rich texture. It's a lovely work, sad and funny. A melancomedy, if you will.
There's no denying that this is a single-note film, but it's a note of considerable emotional clout.
Troell's film meshes scenes of high drama and silent contemplation while the milky, sepia-toned Super16 photography lends the images an exquisite, tactile quality.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The maths element of the film, which on the surface is its USP, feels like dressing on a taut but tawdry genre thriller.

Though not without its moments, this latest tale of wartime derring-do rarely dares to enter uncharted territory.
In 'Sugar', the pair skilfully dismantle the timeworn themes, characters and story patterns of the conventional sports movie and then reassemble them as a rich, socially astute realist drama.
The film is raw and confident, but it's a little shallow, too.
A wild-eyed, everything-in-the-pot cross-processing of artistic, cinematic, political and personal concerns, where the story stutters, splinters and infuriates its way to an explosive finale.

Shabbily filmed and poorly acted, its lone positive is a compellingly awful turn by Alfie (brother of Lily) Allen, whose bumbling, velour-tracksuited date-rapist is the sleaziest thing youâ(TM)ll see this year.

movie_review_blurb: With its unlovely DV aesthetic and cheesy midi-synth score, the film has clearly been put together on the cheap. Yet it's also severely lacking in the fundamentals.

movie_review_blurb: Bowers's play-it-straight attitude towards the material combined with the crisp, if unspectacular, animation doesn't allow 'Astro Boy' a moment to bob its head above the ever-swelling digimation pack.

Seeing the film ten years later - and in the mighty shadow of Pixar's recent masterpieces - the film feels a little chaotic, safe, tired on its feet.
A garish and poorly filmed chop-socky frolic that makes about as much sense as an Escher painting viewed through Vaseline-smudged Ray-Bans.

Koreeda's almost sage-like understanding of what makes modern families tick places him and this wonderful film in the league of Japan's grand master, Ozu, and you can't ask for higher praise than that.

Tonally, the film is a shambles, clumsily veering from cheeky romance one minute, to crass 'that bloke just spunked on my windscreen!' japery the next.
A work of dazzling formal discipline that riffs on the simple notion of repetition and variation.

A menacing pseudo-horror thriller with arty aspirations.

Silly and stupid, but reasonably entertaining if you just sit back and accept it for what it is.
"Midnight Special" is a bleak, joyless film that's not for everyone, yet I give it kudos for originality.

Physical humor is where McCarthy sparkles, but there is not enough in this movie to satisfy. I would like to see a Melissa McCarthy film with more sight gags and less spewing of profanity and bathroom-related references.
Cheadle turns in his finest performance since his Oscar-nominated role in "Hotel Rwanda"
Like fine wine or aged cheese, 80-year-old filmmaker Woody Allen keeps getting better.
On the strength of its all-female leading cast, this remake of the original "Ghostbusters" (1984) will likely be a box office smash, but not because it's an upgrade.
Roger Ross Williams should make room on his mantle for another statuette.
Without the exceptional performances from Sam Neill and Julian Dennison, "Hunt for the Wilderpeople" would likely devolve into an outlandish situation comedy-wannabe.
Despite its shortcomings, "The Secret Life of Pets" boasts terrific animation, and the soundtrack by the superb Alexandre Desplats is just that --- superb.
While it is very well constructed and photographed, that doesn't necessarily make it 100% entertaining.
if Ray (Harryhausen) were alive today to see what Steven Spielberg's crew has accomplished in "The BFG", he would be astonished.
Skarsgård, with his chiseled features and six-pack abs, will become this generation's epitome of the storied ape man.
The film is a captivating example of superb acting and writing, not to be missed by serious cinephiles.
With genius executive producer John Lasseter's stamp of approval on "Finding Dory", what's not to like?
Wan keeps his audience on the edge of their seats the entire time.
Tugs at your emotions without being sentimental, mushy, maudlin or corny. It's a beautifully conceived story, wonderfully acted and well written.
The documentary doesn't delve deeply enough into Anthony Weiner's psychological makeup. But the film is entertaining on some level that satisfies our tacit fascination with celebrities who implode.
Crowe and Gosling do exhibit an on-screen chemistry, but I would like to see them together in a better film.
Won the Audience Award at Sundance last year, and it's easy to see why.
"High-Rise" is a puzzling debacle of debauchery that is showcased on many levels. If this constitutes entertainment at the movies, count me out.
There is no denying the apprehension that builds in this movie. But thanks to numerous lighter moments, I was able to unclench my fists from time to time.
Suffice it to say that if I can find this sort of thing entertaining, true fans of the genre should be handsomely rewarded.
There is not a dull moment, not a single false step in this picture. "The Man Who Knew Infinity" is a powerful story that will stand on its own merit.
"Captain America: Civil War" has some surprises, but the battle scenes --- here we go again --- are far too long.
"Mother's Day" doesn't go for the cheap laughs right out of the gate. Instead, we are given the opportunity to get to know the characters.
I'm loathe to report the movie doesn't stand up to their past work --- obviously it's much harder to be funny for 90 minutes than thirty.
It's a shame they couldn't find a better looking actor than Hemsworth to play the hunky huntsman.

The last straw has Costner's character simulating Pope's sign of love for Jill by tapping the end of his nose. A better gesture would have been Jerico holding each side of his nostrils with thumb and forefinger.
Favreau has masterminded a film destined to be a classic, something moviegoers will clamor to see again and again.
"The Danish Girl" is spellbinding...it's a quiet film that allows its viewers to feel the raw emotions of people caught up in a personal perplexity that few of us would ever experience.
At the risk of inciting a riot, I found the movie to be a crashing bore.
Ms. Stevenson is effective and credible in the role. And "The Letters" is worth viewing for people of all faiths.
Its extraordinary cast keeps us riveted to the screen in an authentic portrayal of investigative journalism.
Small kids will giggle at some of the antics of the stop-motion animated figures, while adults will marvel at the exceedingly clever attention to detail the filmmakers achieved.
"The Gift" is a nail-biter, a movie that appears to present to its audience one cliche after another, but continually surprises us with the unexpected.
Pete's snow white standard poodle is a delight, and should have had a more prominent role.
"Fantastic Four" had a final budget of $122 million. Good luck to 20th Century Fox making that investment back.

This is not necessarily a movie for lovers of action or high adventure. It essentially qualifies as an art film that will finds its audience based on glowing critical reviews, and the celebrity attraction of its two captivating stars.
"Best of Enemies" is a riveting, often quite funny, viewing experience --- in black and white, no less.
"Samba" manages to be hugely entertaining, featuring a superb cast and expert direction, without abandoning its important message about a universal problem.
It is vastly superior to all the bloated superhero movies with their extended, tedious fight scenes and unnecessary, overused 3-D effects.
You know you're in trouble when a movie starts off with a note scribbled indelibly on a guitar that says "I have a vagina".
With the "Saturday Night Live" stamp of approval all over it...we deserve better, much better.
"Southpaw" is unequivocally the best boxing film in almost 40 years ("Rocky", 1976). It's a true crowd-pleaser in the "Rocky" vein.
"The Man From U.N.C.L. E." is a dull affair.
I suspect many moviegoers, whether Woody Allen fans or not, will find the pacing frustrating, the philosophical meanderings unnecessary or incomprehensible, or both.
"Mr. Holmes" is one of those small films that grows on the viewer ever so gradually. The three main characters are all people we care about.
It's fair to say that Schumer's first major entree into feature films will project her into major star status far greater than any tenure she might sustain on Comedy Central.
I found my heart pounding as Heineman, often with bullets flying all around, manages to film sequences straight out of a fictional movie or TV show.
For one day, at least, the optimists among us could revel in the good-heartedness of people the world over.
"Minions" does feature a "groovy" soundtrack, but it's not enough to overcome the movie's lesser elements.
The movie has several surprising twists, and will tug gently at your heartstrings, a la Warren Beatty in the 1978 remake of "Heaven Can Wait".

Thanks to a highly-skilled group of comedic actors with years of experience --- largely honed on television --- and the absurdist humor of writer/director Jason Strouse, "Teacher of the Year" is a film I can heartily recommend.
At times "Infinitely Polar Bear" seems like "Mr. Mom" on drugs.
With a totally unique premise, a wealth of voice talent, and the usual attention to detail, "Inside Out" is a must for multiple viewings.
"The Farewell Party" manages to make us laugh amid dire circumstances, yet the film is a serious reminder that Alzheimer's is no laughing matter.
With its capable cast, Spielberg's hand-picked director Colin Trevorrow, and marvelous special effects, "Jurassic World" may be the best of the lot.
"Lila & Eve" is a taut thriller for much of the film. It suffers a bit from a couple of flaws, but they're not deal breakers.
Heller's film is a totally realistic and honest achievement that captures how some teenage girls think about sex and relationships.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "No Escape" is a fast-paced thriller interwoven with quality down times. It delivers on its message that anything can happen, at any time, anywhere.
An entertaining nugget of a film that examines friendship and self-awareness represented in two very different cultures.
Peter Sohn, a voice actor in previous Pixar efforts "Monster University" and "Ratatouille", has stepped way up as he writes and directs "The Good Dinosaur", his debut feature.
Hopefully word will spread about the incredible dual performance by Tom Hardy that could, and should, propel him into the Best Actor competition.
Aside from one major surprise, at least to non-readers of the books, there is nothing else that breaks the tedium of sitting through two plus hours of this franchise that has worn out its welcome.
"Brooklyn" is intelligent, warm, funny and endearing.
As emotional as the rescue effort was, equally fascinating are the technical challenges that the crews had to overcome to bring the men to the Earth's surface.
With its deliberate pace and a running time of two hours, moviegoers have a right to expect more of a payoff, and when it does come, it's neither surprising nor satisfying.
Any male out there who has ever had to make that dreaded phone call for a first date will appreciate Charlie's reluctance when he goes to the Little Red-Haired Girl's front door to return her pencil.

Despite some well-choreographed sequences --- the movie's opening in Mexico City is typically frenetic of Bond films, and the helicopter episode is harrowing --- Agent 007 needs to retire. There is nothing unique or original left to do with the franchise.
"Suffragette" suffers from an overload of extreme close-ups and jittery hand-held camera sequences.

With so many Americans apathetic about our own politics --- Donald Trump aside --- why would anyone care to watch a film about a Bolivian presidential contest, and one campaign guru pitted against another?
"Room" is a powerful, emotionally-charged drama that should be an Oscar contender on many levels.
"Bridge of Spies" is another in a long line of films, based on actual events, where the outcome is either well known or easily predicted. Yet it still manages to hold us firmly in its grasp.
At the heart of the movie is a mesmerizing, iconic performance by Michael Fassbender, certain to be Oscar-nominated.
Although I don't think Guggenheim's documentary is a technical marvel, there is no denying its sheer power, centered in the heart and mind of a diminutive teenager.
Cusack does his best to evoke compassion for his character, and he is quick on his feet, whether trying to woo Anna, or outsmart his captors. But none of it is enough to highly recommend "Shanghai".
It's a film that makes "Gravity" look like a junior high science fair project.

At a minimum, the film is unsettling. Early on, we are teased by what is to follow. Like an effective horror story, we may dread what is ahead of us, yet anticipate it with guarded enthusiasm. "The Walk" is the ultimate vicarious experience.

Of all the movies about drug trafficking, and the authorities who battle the problem, I would rate "Sicario" somewhere in the middle. It is extremely violent, of course, but only intermittently suspenseful.
The potential for this film to fall apart due to a saccharine script or overacting was high, but Meyers and her cast never let that happen.
A poignant story with an accomplished cast.
"Everest" is most like the old Cinerama movies where you could experience the world's highest roller coaster, without actually leaving your seat.
"Captive" is simply proof that not all true life stories make for compelling entertainment at the movies.
Depp has completely vindicated himself with an electrifying performance as the vicious, snarling, unpredictable hoodlum who ruled the city of Boston for many years.

The film's combination of post-climb interviews and real-time footage provides the moviegoer with a unique perspective of these men. In a mere 90 minutes, we get to know them on a strangely personal level that other documentaries rarely achieve.
A delightfully funny trek through the wilderness, with occasional stops in civilization, lavishly strewn with droll exchanges.
"The Revenant" should be seen for its exquisite scenery, its realistic portrayal of men living 200 years ago in an unforgiving environment, and for Leo.
"Spy" is a total gas, not something you can readily say about most comedies these days. It is built around McCarthy who is almost never out of a scene, and she appears to relish every minute.
Despite its weaknesses, I can recommend "Jason Bourne" as a decent summer diversion. But this fourth entry in the franchise should be the final one.
It is possibly the most ambitious animated film ever conceived.
Stiller renders a remarkable performance --- subtle, thoughtful and sympathetic, but never pathetic, silly or incongruous.

"School Life" is not a documentary in the traditional sense. No one is interviewed, nobody offers their opinion about any subject while looking into a camera. All we see are ever-changing snippets of life at the Headfort School in Ireland
"Rebel in the Rye" may inspire a whole new generation of readers to pick up a copy of the book, and even more remarkably, it may encourage older generations to re-visit the novel of their youth.
"Polina" captures the sheer joy of dancers performing --- not for an audience --- but for themselves.

I had never heard of the band The Smiths, or Steven Patrick Morrissey, --- however, I learned enough about his formative years, coupled with the near-hysterical reaction from the jam-packed screening audience in L.A., to recommend the film.
Soderbergh again proves his mastery at this sort of comic crime thriller.
Director Patrick Hughes falls prey to the belief that the more explosions and gunfire in a movie, the more entertaining it will be. Not so much.
At least it doesn't overstay its welcome at a crisp 88 minutes. And there is always that toe-tappin' soundtrack.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a powerful emotional roller coaster about how love can have a firm grip on even the most dysfunctional families.
"Detroit" is Bigelow's powerfully told vision of yet another dark time in American history.
To borrow from another current release --- "meh!".
While "Stronger" is an exceptional story, it's a travesty that it had to be told.
"The Emoji Movie" won't win any prizes for animation, but at least it's an adventurous idea that will appeal to a variety of people.
The film is not a thriller or a great mystery. But it does sustain our interest sufficiently.
No doubt that "Dunkirk" is technologically well conceived and crafted. Unfortunately, a clever idea and expert editing cannot compensate for a dearth of human emotions.
Unleashes a brilliant young actress to the world of cinema.
"War for the Planet of the Apes" is easily one of the year's best films. ... a truly exciting and superior cinematic adventure.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jon Watts and a mostly familiar cast have managed to put a fresh face on the franchise, one that's entertaining to boot.
As it turns out, "Despicable Me 3" is the best of the franchise.
"Baby Driver" is the "Bullitt" for a new generation of moviegoers almost 50 years later.
Excellent writing, superb acting, expert direction, and more --- it is easily one of the best films of this, or any other, year.
Eventually "The Beguiled" shifts into a horror show/thriller with at least two major ironies that will resonate long after you leave the theater.
If one were to edit out all the insipidly stupid stuff in "Rough Night" --- the film would be a half-hour sitcom.
"The Hero" could have devolved into a maudlin melodramatic heap, but the writing has Lee handling his life challenges realistically and sympathetically.
"Brigsby Bear" crushes the big blockbusters for entertainment value and for eliciting real human emotions.
Stanton carries "Lucky", his next-to-last movie. It is likely the crowning point of his long and illustrious career.
"Mark Felt" is Neeson's film, and he doesn't disappoint. The veteran actor displays all the grit, passion and uncertainty of what the real man must have experienced.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Breathe" is a beautifully told story, anchored by two exceptional performances.
If "Jack the Giant Slayer" isn't in line for technical wizardry awards in 2014, it would be a bigger injustice than trading a horse for a handful of beans.
A reasonably entertaining dark comedy with a solid cast and some genuine laughs.
This latest effort from director Ava DuVernay is too scary for little kids, and too inept for adults.
Lawrence has now rendered the most challenging role of her career, and her best performance, by far.
How refreshing to see a feature-length film in only an hour and eleven minutes --- less than the average blockbuster and more entertaining.
I truly loved this film. It deserves a chance at wide distribution, and I believe audiences will appreciate its pathos, heart, and good humor.

My heartiest laugh came at the very beginning when a volcano erupts, and a bird atop a cliff watching the whole event suddenly dons a pair of sunglasses. Why couldn't there have been more of that type of silly, but funny, humor?
The set designs are extraordinary, and the movie features a surprise ending --- especially for those who left the theatre prematurely --- with a timely message about international togetherness.
Fanning delivers a resplendent performance as the central character, and her co-stars are equally deft in their roles.
Alas, "The Leisure Seeker" is neither funny nor poignant, and without those two attributes, the finale has no emotional depth.
"Paddington 2" is a sweet and fun family adventure, full of laughs, some surprises and a glittering array of actors.
Streep manages to thrill us with mere words. And it doesn't hurt to see a strong woman stand up to a room full of condescending white men.

What happened to John Paul Getty III? Were the kidnappers ever convicted of the crime? What about Gail? None of these questions were addressed, which would have made "All The Money In The World" that much better.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I can say that the film is visually spectacular, with another superb soundtrack from John Williams, and mostly well cast.
This fertile product of del Toro's vivid imagination is a fabulous beacon of hope contrasted to the turbulent era of 1962 in world history.
"Call Me By Your Name" is not simply a movie that will be embraced by the LGBT community. It is a story about love and friendship that should be appreciated by everybody.
It's not a stretch to speculate that this movie --- while a lock for a Best Animated Feature nomination --- is a legitimate contender for Best Picture.
Did the world really need yet another version of Winston Churchill's first few days in office? With Gary Oldman portraying the crusty Prime Minister, the answer is yes.
Watching Dan Stevens in the lead role feels like we're witnessing the real man in his lifetime. It's an awesome performance, and "The Man Who Invented Christmas" is top-notch entertainment.
Keeps you guessing until the climactic ending, ... it's worth the wait.
I imagine the story speaks to untold numbers of families who have suffered --- and continue to suffer --- from unsolved tragedies involving loved ones.
Linklater's editing partner, Sandra Adair, calls the performances "an embarrassment of riches" --- 100% correct about the lead players and their exquisite portrayals.
We can always depend on Hemsworth's style of not taking himself too seriously, and it works well.
"Novitiate" has no weak moments. It is flawless --- especially for a novice director.
I found the plot a bit confusing with its myriad of characters, then and now.
There is nothing in it of redeeming value for any adult cinephile. Drop your kids off, find something to do for 89 minutes, then pick 'em up.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Florence Foster Jenkins", without much in the way of pithy character development or historical context, comes off as a bit of a repetitive one-note joke. But Streep pulls off the very difficult task of intentionally singing off-key.
Brian Cox floored me with his portrayal, Oscar-worthy it is.
I can't recommend this film to anyone but "Pirates" diehards, and Johnny Depp devotees.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: First and foremost in this movie is a career-best performance from Michael Keaton as Kroc.
"Paterson" is decidedly not the tedious affair that was "The Limits of Control".
Like other films of its ilk, "Patriots Day" holds us in its grip despite the fact we all know the outcome.
Jones' portrayal is quite different from what we have come to expect from the Oscar nominee, and she proves she can handle the role of an action heroine with surprising ferocity.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The two A-Listers have so much on-screen magnetism --- and they make a nice couple --- I'm willing to overlook their singing shortcomings.
While "Office Christmas Party" has a lot of hilarity early on, it struggles to sustain the humor for the full running time.
Portman's turn in "Jackie" may end up to be the defining one of her career, even though she's only thirty-five. The more the film moves along, the more convincing she becomes.
Huppert excels in projecting the opposite of what we expect. That was true with "Elle" and continues in "Things To Come".
Zemeckis just keeps churning out the hits.
This movie has a little bit of everything, much of it perverse, all of it mesmerizing.
Based on just the sheer magnitude of "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them", far be it for me to not give the film a positive rating.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Hackford has managed to pull off the most difficult challenge in filmdom, to make a good comedy. It helps to have a talent as large as Robert De Niro as the driving force.
How can you not like a feline who high-fives on command? It matters not if you're a cat or dog lover, you should find this movie as irresistible as its four-legged star.
A great score by Oscar winner Michael Giacchino ("Up") and dialogue rife with a sense of humor, coupled with truly spectacular visuals, adds up to what will surely be a hugely popular movie.
This is amazing footage unlike anything you've ever seen
Howard has provided moviegoers with some of our best films over the past four decades. "Inferno" is not one of them.
The funniest thing about this star-studded comedy are the billboards promoting it.
See "Jack Reacher: Never Go Back" for Cruise standing up to the bad guys, and for his always entertaining action sequences. But don't expect to see anything you haven't seen before in this genre.

"The Accountant" lacks the electricity and urgency of his best movies. Then again, Affleck doesn't direct here --- that's left to someone else who lacks the star's ability to create tension and completely immerse the audience.
Taylor and his screenwriter Erin Cressida Wilson faced a daunting task living up to the standard and hype of the novel...they accomplished their goal.
I wasn't expecting much of this remake, other than to determine if it should have been remade in the first place. And the answer is a clear "no" -- not the greatest use of $95,000,000.
"Bridget Jones's Baby" survives a shaky opening 45 minutes by redeeming itself with a charming second half .
If you are old enough to remember the classic battles between Duran and Leonard, "Hands of Stone" is a respectable homage to that time.

If "War Dogs" was not based on a true story, it would be regarded as just another silly script. But it is real, it is relatively recent --- the events took place less than 10 years ago --- and it is entertaining.
A totally entertaining and immersive film.
"A Dog's Purpose" is well done. It's suitable for children 10 and up, especially in its unabashed love of dogs while showcasing the people who unconditionally love their four-legged companions.
The movie is full of twists and turns, and should be seen on the big screen for its striking cinematography alone.
Peck's film is rife with stunning images of the rampant racism that characterized parts of the U.S. at the time. And it is almost astounding how Baldwin's ideologies are relevant today.
Thomas Vinterberg, in his film "The Commune", has created some spectacularly bland folks to populate his communal family.
Through the efforts of 40 directors and a vast array of writers, "Train Station" immediately evolves into a thriller, rife with surprises and sometimes shocking sequences.
it was up to director Doug Liman, screenwriter Dwain Worrell, and actors Aaron Taylor-Johnson and John Cena to create a scenario that would hold an audience's attention. They succeed.
Was he brilliant, or crazy, or maybe some of both? One thing is certain from watching "Burden" --- he was definitely not cut from the same cloth as most people.
"Paris Can Wait" is a charming little sojourn that also looks splendid on the big screen.
It will take five astounding performances to keep Hawkins off Oscar's short list.
Without a few decidedly funny sight gags, "Snatched", Amy Schumer's new comedy, would be hard-pressed to hold an audience's attention.
Its ambiguous conclusion should lend itself to animated post-movie discussions.
Seeing the massive Drax coddle and protect Baby Groot is typical of their love for one another, and that translates into a "family" we can all admire.
"The Promise" is a stirring epic of a sordid time in world history. Its love triangle provides just the right amount of apolitical intrigue the movie demands.
It's not a bad film, it simply doesn't offer up anything new in the genre of "embittered divorcee seeks revenge on innocent new love of ex-husband".
"Heal the Living" is a sensitive and powerfully emotional film showcasing an amazing science.
A thrilling film .
"Cézanne et Moi" is a beautiful film in every respect --- acting, music, cinematography --- and an intriguing story about the turbulent friendship between two 19th century French artisans.
The Boss Baby" gets kudos for its originality, its quality animation and its editing. However, the overall story is a bit of a one-note theme, and after the first 45 minutes or so, it gets tedious.
"Mean Dreams" is a decent diversion, and just knowing it is one of Bill Paxton's last movies is reason enough to see it.
If Wilson wasn't so appallingly annoying, he might be a sympathetic character. But he is, so he's not.
This film is a treat for anyone who harkens back to the glory days of musicals.
King Kong is as likeable and sympathetic as any of his predecessors. And his battles with the island's predators are spectacularly staged.
I went to a screening of a documentary and a horror film broke out.
Everyone in the movie agrees on one thing: it's okay to make fun of the Nazis --- oppressors yes, victims no.
Where have you gone, Irma La Douce??
In all fairness, director George Mendeluk had an almost impossible task of telling the story of Stalin's reign of terror in only 103 minutes.
There's a good reason to see "Logan", and also some good reasons not to see "Logan".
This sequel is content to key on a super hero defending his megalopolis against super villains. And that's what makes "The LEGO Batman Movie" a dull sequel for much of the time.
Gadot more than lives up to the challenge, and is as good at delivering her lines as she is handling a magical lariat.
A big-name cast doesn't necessarily translate into a good movie.
If watching handsome men with perfect bodies perform suggested sex acts on obese women is appealing to you, go see "Magic Mike XXL".

"The D Train" has to be one of the more schizophrenic movies in recent memory. What starts off as an amiable comedy turns into a dark string of events that purport to be funny, but they only serve to change the whole character of the film.
The movie lacks the tension it desperately wants to provide, and is loaded with too many plot flaws that sabotage the story.
Jones is quite good and reason enough to invest a couple of hours in this film.
Outside of a few action sequences, "Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit" is boring.
"The Nut Job" is a movie for parents to avoid sitting through with their kids.
For battle-worn returnees of the struggles in Afghanistan, I suspect this film will trigger deep-seated memories of the military brotherhood they experienced, and the unspeakable losses they endured.
"August: Osage County" is not particularly uplifting, but the writing is so superior, and the cast so engaging, I can heartily recommend it.

Jonze's film could probably have been condensed into a half hour "Twilight Zone"-type episode, but I will admit that Phoenix, and especially the sultry voice of Scarlett, keep this feature length film intriguing.
"The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug" is a marvelous film that deserves Oscar consideration on many fronts, not just technical achievements.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Director John Lee Hancock manages to induce great performances from his cast.
"American Hustle" is marginally entertaining, and ultimately not a satisfying movie-going experience.
Leo's overall performance consists of an amazingly fierce array of emotions, and must be seen to be believed.
Clooney does not wisecrack in his usual manner, he actually treats the subject matter with the reverence it deserves.
Filled with richly comic human events, and deeply emotional scenarios, "Philomena" is one of the best films of the year.
Vaughn again finds himself in a comedy that doesn't click on all cylinders, and its attempts at poignancy come too little, too late.

Lawrence exudes a certain combination of feistiness, confidence and beauty that could not be embodied by any other young actress working today. She is clearly the glue that holds this film franchise together.
It's apparent to me that this is one of those cases where the film version just can't match up to the (presumed) brilliance of the book.
One of these days Shia LaBeouf will find a script that is worthy of his considerable acting talent. "Charlie Countryman" is not that vehicle.
McConaughey's earlier career consisting of fluff films seems like ancient history.
The best part of "Thor: The Dark World" was watching Jeanne almost falling off her seat when the handsome Hemsworth doffs his top to reveal an amazingly chiseled physique.
Radcliffe is clearly the headliner in this cast, but it's an admirable acting tour de force by a solid ensemble group.
If one can believe this supposition, then it is possible to buy into the idea of a scrawny, 98-pound weakling to be the planet's savior.
"All is Lost" is a unique cinematic experience that should be seen on the big screen.
The dialogue is crisp and refreshing, and even though the story is largely predictable, it still maintains its suspense and shock value.
Despite its mostly frantic pacing and considerable ambition, it lacks true entertainment value because the aforementioned dilemma is not presented as a dire situation for the viewer.
A slate of characters the Coen Brothers would admire.

Adults in their 40's today should find the film very satisfying. However, the jokes and sight gags arrive in such machine-gun fashion that young kids and many adults will be hard pressed to keep pace.
It is deadly dull --- the level of emotional detachment, at least by this critic, was palpable.
It's a fresh, original and beautifully acted fantasy.
When the best part of a movie is the music, something isn't right.
Personally, I was expecting much more of an impassioned reaction given the story line...yet I wasn't bowled over by the film.
"Transcendence" is too slow, too technical and ultimately boring.
Corum is so credible in the role, speaking the words of the real Colton, that moviegoers will be hard pressed to deny the veracity of it all.
Casting Mulligan in this role might seem like a curious choice. But her character combines the smarts, spunk and a sly sexuality that is difficult to ignore. And she is eminently likeable.
Saldanha's sequel is infused with spectacular scenery, toe-tapping music, and a myriad of creatures and colors.
First time feature film writers Scott Rothman and Rajiv Joseph could be this year's version of Ben Affleck and Matt Damon penning the Oscar-winning "Good Will Hunting".
Once you accept and get past the mayhem and slaughter --- there's a story there, and a good one.
Jeanne was particularly taken with the fact that females dominate the males, making all the key decisions in their island exploration. She could hardly contain her glee at our screening.

I still can't shake the peculiar casting by von Trier since neither actress looks remotely like the other. He also cast Belgian Michael Pas as the older version of Jerome, but Pas looks as much like Shia LaBeouf as I do.
It (her dress) deserves to be memorialized in the Smithsonian Institute as a symbol of a brave woman standing up for her principles.

The heart and soul of this film is Pena. His magnificent performance punctuates Chavez' struggle to maintain a non-violent approach to achieve his goals --- which included a 25-day fast that nearly killed him --- and keep his large family intact.
The real strength of "Noah" is that it transports the audience completely, so we believe we're watching a real event in biblical times.
Once the initial shock of the graphic material fades, "Nymphomaniac: Volume I" is quite a compelling story.

Outside of a chuckle here and there, I didn't laugh. Neither will you.

Given that the film paints The East as a mostly sympathetic movement, made up of likeable individuals, makes the movie an ambiguous quandary for moviegoers. But as a political thriller "The East" hits on all cylinders.

Malick's films are more self-indulgent than other filmmakers. He is enamored with his own camera work, and whether or not his subject matter is germane to the story is largely up to the viewer.
