Hathaway is a lock to win the Supporting Actress Oscar. Bank on it.
Think of this as Tom Cruise's chance to play a Jason Statham character, and that alone should tell you what to expect.
If you think about it long enough, you'll realize that the movie is asking you to root for a disturbed sociopath who ruins people's lives for sport. Are we having fun yet?
Bryan Singer's name carries quite a bit of clout in Hollywood, this despite the fact that the man's last good movie turns 10 years old this summer.
Something predictable will work if it's well executed, and Burt Wonderstone benefits from three things: a top-notch cast, a damned funny script, and a healthy respect for its subject matter.
Insert your own joke here about the caveman movie suffering from a lack of development.
A 2013 Evil Dead should have a healthy dose of self-awareness and adrenaline. This movie lacks both.
It's nice to see a science fiction film that doesn't patronize its audience.
For anyone familiar with Shane Black's work, it's not long before a strong case of deja vu sets in.
A bunch of clueless people ruining their lives by making bad decision after bad decision; it's like a Mike Leigh movie, with money.
There is virtually nothing original about the premise of Premium Rush, but its execution is immensely entertaining.
The characters themselves tell you that you're too close to see the big picture. As it turns out, the movie is the same way.
Never tell a studio that their golden goose is finished laying eggs.
The Dark Knight Rises is arguably Christopher Nolan's weakest movie, but let's put that in perspective: it's still better than the best Transformers movie.

Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol is good, and occasionally brilliant, but the plot is threadbare, lacking the layered story lines and emotional core that Brad Bird's big three animated films have in spades.
The title sequence alone is the single coolest thing you will see at the movies all year.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Man, could this movie have benefited from a little misdirection.
If director James Watkins had kept things quiet and let the visuals speak for themselves, it would have made for a completely different, and far scarier, viewing experience.
That Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds are able to make the movie so watchable is to their immense credit.
At the very least, the film makes up for the (awful) live action adaptations that Universal thrust upon moviegoers a decade ago.
It's easy to be fascinated with how John Carter looks, but it's difficult to get emotionally involved.
The movie survives its sizable flaws thanks to a lot of heart and winning performances by its lead actors.
As remakes of '80s properties go, you'd be hard pressed to find one so self-deprecating, yet ruthless.
This is only the third movie that Gary Ross has ever directed. That is just all sorts of wrong.
American Reunion is better than one would have the right to expect.
As entertaining as this movie is, it could have been even better.
On paper, Dark Shadows is a home run, but they don't play the games on paper.
They probably shouldn't make a fourth Men in Black, but then again, they probably shouldn't have made this one either, and it turned out all right.
A culture change is clearly taking place at DreamWorks Animation. Hallelujah.
Noomi Rapace will no longer be referred to as the original Girl with a Dragon Tattoo after her work here.

Rock of Ages feels like one of those movies that studio executives keep hidden in their vaults and only pull out at stag parties, a work of excess and wrongheadedness so far off the rails that to release it would be a P.R. disaster.
Brave has its good points, but they cannot make up for what amounts to the weakest story Pixar has assembled to date.
You can almost see director Steven Soderbergh at odds with himself, torn between making a mainstream film or a gritty indie, and ultimately doing neither.
How much you enjoy Hope Springs will depend largely on how much you enjoy watching old people have sex.
This Is the End is to Rogen and his crew what Grown-Ups is to Adam Sandler and his buddies: an excuse to get paid to play with his friends, only this one is actually funny.
Burton apparently worked on this at night while directing Dark Shadows during the day. Both movies would have benefited greatly from his undivided attention.
White House Down should not be as enjoyable as it is. And yet, it finds a way. Pass the popcorn.
Hats off to the sequel that begins with poking fun at its inherent shortcomings - in a musical number, no less - then proceeds to surpass its predecessor in nearly every way.
Holy cow, is this movie safe. That it manages to still be entertaining is to its great credit.
Everything about Neighbors screams bro... and then a funny thing happens: Rose Byrne comes along and wipes the floor with every man in the cast.
It speaks to the importance of loving the game that you're playing, and that is never a bad thing, even when it takes an extra 20 minutes to say it.

There is certainly another side of the Sleeping Beauty story to be told, but it looks as though the idea of Disney villains as the next franchise opportunity overtook all efforts to make a solid, stand-alone film.
It's entertaining and gorgeous, but disjointed, veering between wildly emotional scenes on both ends of the spectrum without much thought for how they should flow together.
It's a movie that acknowledges cynicism, but shows a more hopeful path. It's hard to get too down on a movie like that, even a mediocre one.

The rule for animated films should be that a good joke for adults is one that is both funny and can be explained to children. Here, we have a female airplane talking about her rack. John Lasseter, I expect more from you than that.
This movie could use some teeth, and it's surprising that they didn't use the ones that the book provided them.
If there is anything good that comes from Sex Tape, it is the age-old lesson that you shouldn't make one, ever. Ever. No, really, ever.
The story line is too slight... but thanks to a showstopping performance by Chadwick Boseman, Get on Up is quite entertaining.
Pierce Brosnan is a better spy here than he ever was in the Bond movies.
If God Help the Girl were any more precious, Gollum would steal it.

Good for Shawn Levy for going outside of his comfort zone, but as much as he may dislike being typecast as a director, he should keep that 'mindless family movie' door open as long as he possibly can.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Annabelle deserved a story of her own, not one stitched together from the carcasses of others.
It's no Up or WALL∙E, but it's better than Pixar's last two films combined, and for that alone, we should be thankful.
The trailer of this movie is the best version of it that will ever exist. Stick with that.
It's a pleasant distraction, nothing more.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: How ironic that in a movie about striving for greater intelligence, the takeaway turns out to be that ignorance truly is bliss.
You will learn virtually nothing from this movie, except that Eva Green has very nice breasts.
It's hard to imagine anyone else capturing the essence of Gone Girl quite like David Fincher does.
The acting performances elevate the material from 'predictable' to 'predictable but fun.'
The beats and twists may be familiar, but it's well executed, and director Jaume Collet-Serra wisely resists the urge to go turbo, as it were.
Turbo rises above its familiarity and makes for a charming, if predictable, experience.
There are lots of individual things to like about The To-Do List... but there always seems to be something that derails its momentum.
It may not have an original thought in its head, but it has Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg, and they sell the hell out of it.
In order to make his point, Neill Blomkamp resorts to painting with an awfully broad brush, and the complex issues... Elysium seeks to tackle are marginalized by half.
The fact that one can think of a movie about a guy hooked on porn as charming is high praise.
Gravity is magical, the kind of movie that will inspire a generation of kids to grab cameras and let their imaginations run wild, the proverbial face that launches a thousand ships.
With any luck, The Conjuring will lead potential future horror filmmakers raised on a diet of torture porn and slasher films to rethink their approach. One can hope, at least.
You will be hard pressed to find a movie this year as overly directed as this one.
Where action movies are equated with popcorn, Last Vegas is comfort food. It's not terribly good for you, but it sure tastes good.
It feels as it Hal from marketing had some input in the creative process. This is never a good thing.
Had they kept Vince Vaughn properly restrained, he may have delivered exactly what the role required. As it is, they gave him too much rope, and the movie suffers because of it.
It is encouraging to see Disney crafting women who are focused on something other than the affections of a boy.
The Desolation of Smaug is a lot of fun, but for the love of God, just end it already.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The trailer for Saving Mr. Banks resembles the film only slightly more than The Shining resembles that fake trailer for the film that made the rounds 10 or so years ago.
Her is smart, thought provoking, and one of the year's best films. Now please shut down your laptop and go talk to someone face to face for a while.
Grudge Match is funny, at times explosively so, but also uneven and flawed.
It's a LEGO movie for people who despise the very idea of a LEGO movie, which is pretty punk rock for a CGI movie made by one of the largest media conglomerates in the world.
My wife's take: "This is the first Jack Ryan movie that didn't put me to sleep." She's hoping the studio will use that for the Blu-ray cover.
While they absolutely stick the landing in the third act, getting to it is a bit of a chore.
Just watching this film offers its own rewards.
James Schamus' flat, arid screenplay only further undermines this intimate tale.
Hallström has given us John Irving defanged, and what's the point in that?
More than 20 years after Mr. Cobb's novel was first published, Mr. Kubrick reminded us that human folly is rarely checked for long. A half-century on, he is still right.
While this is eager-to-please Hollywood-by-numbers fare, 21 should provoke enough interest to make you pick up a copy of the book that the film cheats to get the real deal.
Growing pains have never been this excruciating. The Loved Ones is an instant horror classic.
Let Me In is one of the finest American horror films of recent years. It may be a remake but, when it's this good, who cares? Bloody great!
Preaching to the converted, fans of the book should be sated. Julia Roberts is easy to love.
Intelligent sci-fi with a monster-sized heart.
The truth doesn't hurt. Despite the fact we now know that Phoenix hasn't lost the plot, I'm Still Here is still an amazing piece of cinema.
Boy is the feel-good film of the year. This boy's life is a hilarious and bewitching reminder of what it's like to be young.
Action-packed and thrilling to the max but TWTWB is let down by its inexperienced cast and surprisingly clunky dialogue.
An Adam Sandler movie with a heart? Almost! This is no Punch Drunk Love or Spanglish but waft aside the flatulence and there is an adult film crying to grow up.
In a cinematic battlefield full of Inceptions and Expendables, Scott Pilgrim vs The World takes on all comers and kicks ass. One of the best films of the year so far.
Barrett returns in ship-shape fashion with an enjoyable tale of loneliness and remorse.
A hugely enjoyable trash fest. The perfect way for Runaways virgins to pop their Cherry Bomb.
Gory, action packed and full to the brim with rampant Predator action. What more could you want?
Ever wanted to know what it's like to be an actor? Somewhere is the intoxicating answer.
Says a lot about a film when a balaclava-clad suicidal ostrich is one of its only highlights. For Gyllenhaal and Arterton completists only.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Beautifully played and powerfully moving, despite the sugary clichés.
Super 8 is an unapologetic joy from beginning to end that will thrill and engage kids, both old and new.
A visually sumptuous, thematically astute, heartwarming triumph.
Feathery fun, you know, for kids. And penguins.

The challenge of reinventing Alice in Wonderland sees Tim Burton reinvigorated and refreshed. Visually stunning and filled with a delightfully deranged group of inhabitants, Burton's immensely enjoyable Wonderland is well worth a visit.
A fascinating, if workmanlike, insight into the life of a legend.
A vacuous but fun exercise in chop-sock style over substance.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Bright, colourful and fun.
A frothy French fancy with a warm heart at it's core.
movie_title: Les femmes du 6e étage (The Women on the 6th Floor) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An enjoyable chiller that isn't afraid to show less.
Rejoice, Coogan and Brydon fans.
Marvellous. The Muppets manages to revitalise the family classic to create a hilarious and life-affirming delight.
A nice slice to finish the pie.
A solid Aussie thriller that doesn't quite live up to its early promise.
If Downey Jr and Law team up for further adventures, it'd be a smart move to emphasise the shadows over the games.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For all its creaky-old-dark-house cliches, Insidious is a fun ghost-train ride, full of truly terrifying moments. But once it's over, it's forgotten.
Here it is, a solid and heartfelt debut.
A one-of-a-kind experience that will confound, befuddle and amaze.
Bright and breezy and slightly preachy, this modern Lorax entertains but never soars.
Gunmen, at the very least, does moviegoers the favor of instantly revealing how stupid and cheesy it is, thus sparing us the elevated expectations of fun.
A stupid movie. Stupid stupid stupid stupid stupid. If you pay money to see it, then you're stupid. I got paid to see it, and I feel stupid.
After hiring Benigni, it seems, Edwards flat ran out of good ideas.
Neither Max Apple's script nor Paul M. Glaser's direction succeeds in convincing you that these characters live, or that this story has anything to do with any thing.
This film is a frequently hysterical romp, packed with explosions, pratfalls and even a smidge of a history lesson.
True to the live experience - taking in tears, joy, sweat and humor - of one of the most influential and acclaimed bands of a generation.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A rare Alan Rudolph misfire.
A complex -- and thoroughly absorbing -- tale that juxtaposes the virulent beauty of Mexico with that country's seamier side.
The title says it all.
As a pre-historical/hysterical document "Ice Age" is more than a little suspect but its signature squirrel more than makes up for it.
Riveting and necessary.
The scant running time -- just 64 minutes -- makes one wonder if "Peter Pan II: The Death of Tink" might have originally been planned for the home video market.
There's extra cheese on this Big Mac.
Blazingly good anti-war sentiment.
Director Fessenden's inventive camerawork, staccato editing, and creative use of sound make "Wendigo" a creepy, entertaining ride.
A true "Birthday'" surprise by filmmaker Jez Butterworth (no relation).
Penn is brilliant and the refreshingly unprecocious Dakota Fanning shows oodles of promise.
Most of what we see on the screen has been done before -- many times before, and many times better.
Solidly directed, evenly acted, and nicely filmed -- no real surprises, really.
Powerful and disturbing.
Altman at the top of his game.
An extremely entertaining introduction to Tolkien's trilogy.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Feels contrived despite the worthy contributions of Channing and Stiles.
Convoluted and by turns mind-bendingly playful and annoying, Crowe's psychodrama is full of good intentions.
Wes Anderson's and Owen Wilson's wild, wooly, and wonderful follow-up to their surprise 1998 hit "Rushmore."
There's a decent heist movie hidden under all that smarm but you have to dig pretty deep to unearth it.
Talky and terrific!
Your appreciation of the film is likely to be colored by whether or not you've read the book(s).
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: What's worse than being trapped in a house with an angry ghost? Trapped in a house with 13 of them. But the real shocker here is that "13 Ghosts" is surprisingly decent.
Starts strong and keeps getting stronger.
Porno for the squatter set.
An unashamed gay interest soft-porn flick with lashings of sex, drugs, and dance music.
A stuffy murder mystery aboard a yacht.
Without a doubt Hugh Grant's finest on-screen performance to date.
It's not a film to be taken literally on any level, but its focus always appears questionable.
Anyone who quickly denounced Madonna's "Swept Away" as being the worst film of 2002 clearly hadn't seen "13th Child."
Why can't other filmmakers challenge, surprise, and excite us like this?
Vanity! Heresy! Madonna!
A breathtakingly magical animated fable that lifts your spirits and carries you away to a world far beyond your wildest imagination.
Fancy a little S&M? If so, then the kinky "Secretary" should be right up your alley.
"Igby'" insists on throwing one unsympathetic character after another at us until it becomes clear there's nobody to root for.
Less structured and, as a result, funnier than Margaret's first!
Julio Medem's sexy road movie is an "Y Tu Mamá También" lite that arouses the senses as much as it does the imagination.
"Signs" could have been a lot more satisfying had we not seen in the last reel what director M. Night Shyamalan so carefully avoids showing us in the first several.
The glossy "One Hour Photo" focuses our attentions on Robin Williams's sad and strikingly subdued performance as a photo finisher who snaps.
Soderbergh should be ashamed of himself for trying to pass this off as entertainment.
Like a convenience store frozen beverage, John Stockwell's "Blue Crush" is an exhilarating cool blue rush.
Michael Winterbottom puts the Manchester, England music/club scene circa 1980 under the microscope... and forgets to take the lens cap off!
An entertaining, slickly produced, and eminently satisfying biopic of movie mogul Robert Evans.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Better than the second, and almost as good as the first!
Passionate -- but mostly unremarkable -- filmmaking.
Squishy, buggin' fun.
A provocative drama.
It certainly won't win any awards in the plot department but it sets out with no pretensions and delivers big time.
I'll save you all some time: Mr. Peevely the janitor did it and would have gotten away with it were it not for those meddling kids and their darned dog.
Notable, alas, for providing the last film score from veteran British film composer John Barry (1933-2011).
A fine family film that hits all the emotional buttons.
Enthralling, exciting, exhilarating.
As subtle as any Michael Bay movie.
Funnier -- and scarier -- than "Gone with the Wind"!
An odd fish, this, although there's no denying the conviction the ruby-lipped temptress Liv Tyler brings to washing a car.
Hollow indeed.
Ultimately it's the director's confidence behind the camera that makes "Three Kings" a powerful piece of filmmaking -- as dry, bleak, and brutal as the barren Iraqi desert.
You can't take your eyes off Eamonn Owens or your ears off Stephen Rea (or, for that matter, either off Neil Jordan's entire film).
It must be excruciatingly difficult to make a bad film about a hip dance sensation but "Twist" manages it.
For all of the interesting possibilities inherent in Condon's source material, the single most important thing one learns about James Whale, according to the film, was that he was a dirty old man.
Strictly for kids.
Like a filet mignon served rare, "The Talented Mr. Ripley" is an exquisite sensory experience that's cold at the center.
The problem with the film, plain and simple, is that it focuses all of its energies on the dinosaurs themselves.
You know you're in trouble when you have difficulty telling Johnny Depp and Charlize Theron apart!
Christian Bale is at the top of his game here.
If you're a teenaged girl, then "Varsity Blues," which stars "Dawson's Creek" mega-heartthrob James Van Der Beek, might well be the greatest film ever made.
A playful, powerful, and very honest portrait of a profession we don't see all that often.

There's a lot of talk, none of it particularly interesting, and several colorful musical numbers shot unimaginatively from the Savoy Theatre stalls. But there's no real inspiration here, let alone drama.

With its gorgeous cinematography...lovely muted score, and sure-footed performances, especially by Frances O'Connor, Patricia Rozema's "Mansfield Park" sets a new standard for adaptations of Jane Austen's work.

There are times when "American Beauty" feels like it might be toppling over into melodrama, but Mendes grabs the reins and reels his actors in, generating power and a lot of perspiration in the process.
A Big Men Shouting movie that works.
More bore-dy than bawdy.
Beautifully filmed, but suffers from deliberate pacing and a shallow, uninspired viewpoint.
I can guarantee it will make it onto my best films of 2000 list.
Richard Spence's film doesn't have the courage to examine forcefully the issues at its center.
Stamp's all over this one, a rather routine thriller at the best of times.
Creepy and hard to dislodge.
Your enjoyment of the film will entirely depend on just how irritating you find McTeer's Mary Jo.
The pile of vomit left by a theater patron as they made a hasty exit was probably the best free publicity Ridley Scott's film could ever have hoped for.
If it's dumb humans crashing through the undergrowth you're after, rent a Rambo movie instead.
The best example to date of why mainstream movies don't feature explicit sex scenes.
A non-animated G-rated movie is a rarity these days but the rating here reflects the fact that all the guts, all the good stuff, has been exorcised from the finished product.
First-time director Alejandro González Iñárritu has taken an original story and fashioned it into a tale that is gritty, multifaceted, and brimming with edgy performances.
"Bridget Jones's Diary" belongs to Bridget. It belongs to Renée Zellweger.
Overtired.
Writer/director Pawel Pawlikowski strikes a wonderful balance between pathos and tenderness.
A remarkable film, totally absorbing from the first frame to the last. It's a marvel of simplicity and depth, comfort and compassion.
Not without its amusing moments but this animated Disney feature feels hurried and somewhat frantic in its approach.
The crossover hit that (quite rightly) started all those high-flying wire-fu action pictures. With the redoubtable Chow Yun-Fat and Michelle Yeoh.
Bullock's confident turn cannot, alas, save this Beautiful Women Falling Down entry.
Warm and soothing, "The Family Man" is not a perfect film, but it's a perfect film for the holiday season.
A feel-good movie that should have felt even better.
23 million cable viewers can't be wrong.
Wayne Wang's "The Center of the World" plays like a Mike Figgis film (and that's not always a good thing).
A cinematic confection.
A rarity this -- an older man paired with a younger woman that doesn't produce a loud, vulgar gagging sound from the back of the viewer's throat.
Somewhere within the scattershot confines of Barry Levinson's "Bandits" lies a halfway decent movie struggling to get out.
Not long enough.
The most disappointing thing about Stiller's film is that all it appears to be saying is that male models don't seem to have a lot between the ears.
Crammed with acres of quotable dialogue, the film plows along from one inspired bit to the next.
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Moodysson manages to make much of it charming, eliciting warm and vulnerable performances from his homegrown cast.
A nasty piece of work.
The dialogue is fresh and on the money.
As "Ghosts of Mars" movies go, John Carpenter's is probably the best.
Worshiping at the altar of Tilda never gets old.
Would somebody just give Steve Buscemi an Oscar already?
Another quirky, intelligent, beautifully photographed, and finely crafted movie from the Brothers Coen.
Eminem's compelling, assured, workaholic performance lifts "8 Mile" above its standard fare convictions.
Deliberately and devotedly constructed, "Far from Heaven" is too picture postcard perfect, too neat and new pin-like, too obviously a recreation to resonate.
"Die Another Day" makes you long for the days when Roger Moore played 007. And who would ever admit to that!
Beautifully crafted, daringly staged, and movingly scored, "AKA" is a triumph of British cinema (and cinema in general).
Steve ("Hoop Dreams") James's deep and singular commitment to his subject shines through in this compelling documentary.
Not for the politically correct or the sexually squeamish, but definitely for those who enjoy a bloody good larf.
Hey, it's better than "The Matrix Reloaded"!
Don't you mean Big Turkey, Tim?
A charming, one-of-a-kind experience, a breathtakingly drawn and uproariously funny film by French animator Sylvain Chomet. It's one of the most delightful films of the year.
Theron is clearly the reason to see the film, but even her impassioned performance is strictly by-the-numbers.
An earnest and enjoyable entertainment that remains loyal to its source if not to those hoping for state-of-the-art special effects.
Screenwriter Richard Curtis tries to direct, puts too many eggs in his basket, and winds up with a very runny omelette.
Move over the Coen, Wachowski, Farrelly, Polish, and Hughes brothers. "In America" belongs to the Bolger sisters.
Spendid!
Lavish but unnecessary.
Superb performances by Sean Penn, Benicio Del Toro, and Naomi Watts highlight "21 Grams," Alejandro González Iñárritu's electrifying follow-up to "Amores Perros."
Marred, somewhat, by overlength, occasional silliness, and cloying characters, LOTR3 is nevertheless a technical marvel... and a fitting end to a one-of-a-kind series.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Worth seeing... for William H. Macy's (naked) butt, I guess.
Any hints at sophistication -- and there are many -- are constantly undermined by smarminess and cornball predictability.
With its near-perfect blend of live news footage and expository interviews, "Bus 174" grabs you by the throat and threatens never to let you go.
Not since "All the Presidents Men" has journalistic integrity been so entertainingly scrutinized.
Drunk and disorderly.
Strong performances highlight this Ron Howard western.
The poetic build-up is frustratingly undermined by a hurried finale that presents too little information while imploring us to make sense out of it all.
Eccentricity never struck this close to home before.
Dante favors the everything-but-the-kitchen-sink approach to this Warner Bros. nostalgia trip when funny-and-affectionate would have worked better.
"Under the Tuscan Sun" goes for the picture postcard look-and-feel and it succeeds admirably, a flighty contrivance that's thin, lightweight, and instantly disposable.
When a murder mystery stars Sean Penn, Tim Robbins, and Kevin Bacon you're gonna have a hard time picking the killer. Eastwood directs without a trace of showiness.
Ben Stiller's latest comedic vehicle is amiable but strikingly underwritten.
A harrowing indictment of the atrocities performed in the name of organized religion.
A brooding, smoldering study of sexual intensity grittily realized by McGregor, Swinton, and Mullan who slip, almost unnoticed, into these roles and make them their own.
Cuarón's involvement should have made this the best of the series, but "'Prisoner'" once again falls prey to author Rowling's tendency towards a lack of sophistication.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Evil might have but one name to fear but intelligent, discerning moviegoers have two: "Van Helsing."
Legally bland.
Amid the bloody pulp that is cinema this season, the director of "Italian for Beginners" offers a fresh look at the old death wish.
More is less in this needlessly talky, surprisingly unstylish, and disappointingly dull affair. Yet stitch together Vol. 1 & 2 and you've got a different story altogether.
Sure it's anti-American but it's also anti-Hollywood and that makes "Dogville" edgy, thought-provoking, and daringly original.
Sly humor, restrained violence/language, and a terrific -- and very crimson -- Ron Perlman position "Hellboy" as a cut above your average Mutants vs. Nazis flick.
Significant performances from Carrey and especially Winslet highlight Charlie Kaufman's latest brain tease, which might have worked a little better with concept set to medium.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: "When there're no more original ideas in Hollywood, the studios will opt to remake." And, in first-time director Zack Snyder's case, poorly.
Although it ultimately winds up as grotesque as the reality TV shows it lampoons, Whitney's film offers up a sly and occasionally uproarious look at uninhibited New Yorkers.
Any resemblance between the original -- and fun! -- 1970's TV series and this in-name-only Todd Phillips's dud is entirely accidental.
Mel's rockpile is akin to taking Oliver Twist (another well-thumbed literary tome) and focusing entirely on the scene in which Bill Sykes bludgeons Nancy to death.
"Secret Window" is taut, credible, and thoroughly entertaining, and features another eccentric -- and uncommonly good -- performance from Johnny Depp.
In "Taking Sides," Harvey Keitel has interpreted "powerful performance" as loud, aggressive, and singularly one-sided, despoiling an otherwise thought-provoking film.
A truly great film, one that puts a human face on adventure by starkly dramatizing the power of man's indefatigable resolve.
Virtuoso documentarian Errol Morris once again brings out the best (and a little bit of the worst) in his subject, this time former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Worth watching for Toni Collette's typically complex performance, but even she can't distract us away from the unending schmaltz that is the third act.
A little gem.
A valiant attempt to bring a difficult book (Philip Roth's 'The Human Stain') to the screen that's undermined by the added distraction of Nicole Kidman as a char lady.
Taking themes and ideas from Kurosawa's "Ikuru" and Kasdan's "The Big Chill" (to name a few), director Denys Arcand still manages to make this film his own.
Lucky Mckee's film works better as a misfit character study than it does a purebred slasher flick.
Brutal and brilliant, Meirelles's stunning "City of God" virtually redefines the word storytelling.
Lovely to look at, engagingly acted, but empty and... well, "cold" pretty much sums it up.
An emotionally powerful ending aside, "Pieces of April" should have been a warm and fuzzy Thanksgiving treat. Instead, it's mostly just fuzzy.
With the undistinguished "Brother Bear," Disney seems to have forgotten it no longer monopolizes the animated feature market.
The scariest thing about "Scary Movie 3" is that it's actually pretty funny.
When the opening scene makes you feel as though you've already missed about an hour of the plot you know you're in trouble.
An intimate, uplifting tribute to our fine-feathered friends who weather incredible odds in their quest for survival.
Real people, real situations. "Laurel Canyon" is a keeper.
F. Gary Gray's "The Italian Job" isn't Art, but it is rather Cool.

A pleasant diversion, but not much more than that.

Surprisingly good of its kind... if you like gross-out gore, that is.

movie_review_blurb: Not as record setting a motion picture as, say, "Titanic," but more haunting and ethereal.

This is a film that's as difficult to watch as it is to dismiss.

Disney's "Pirates of the Caribbean" is a rousing action/adventure yarn highlighted by another truly eccentric performance by Johnny Depp.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: More interesting than arresting, perhaps, "Charlotte Sometimes" is an intelligent piece of filmmaking that promises more than it delivers.

One of the sweetest movies you're ever likely to come across.
A conversation-heavy movie that benefits from typically astute writing from its director, Whit Stillman.

A pleasure to behold.
Unbelievably funny!

movie_review_blurb: Deserving of its classic western status... although for a movie predicated on its titular twelve o'clock showdown, the gunfight itself is oddly anticlimactic.

movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Together, Bier and Jensen totally devastate us. This is what they do.
Nicolas Cage and Elijah Wood co-star as inventors of the medical apparatus consisting of a pad usually supported by a belt for maintaining a hernia in a reduced state. No, wait. That's "The Truss."
Now *this* is more the Tom McCarthy (Director) we know and love...
Cinematographed within an inch of its life (and death), "Mark of the Witch" (aka "Another") would have worked beautifully as a silent picture.
Tightly scripted (Tony Burgess) and directed (Bruce McDonald), but Stephen McHattie's Mazzy is the star!
John Carney's "Sing Street" is a pint-sized, new wave--and similarly crowd-pleasing--version of "The Commitments."
A risky and revelatory documentary weakened only by its awesome source.
All Hail the Republic of Pilgrim!
Aren't we yet done with all this cheap 'n' cheesy hand-held, wobbly-all-over-the-place, found footage so-manic-you-can't-tell-what's-going-on POV movie stuff?
A small yet satisfying psychological drama, dripping with atmosphere and surreal beauty.
This Noah/Waller picture, featuring stuntwoman-turned-actress-turned-stuntwoman Zoe Bell, is neither taxing nor terribly potent.
Bear jokes, poop jokes, bear poop jokes--this movie's got it all.
With "The Visit," M. Night Shyamalan might well be coming out of his 12-year sophomore slump.
"The End of the Tour" made me want to try reading "Infinite Jest" again, so compelling a portrait Jason Segel paints of its troubled author.
First-timer Forbes's earnest resolve to demystify bipolar disorder prevents her film from establishing a satisfying story arc. Ruffalo is good though.
A technically brilliant, sweaty-palmed account of the man who walked between the Twin Towers.
Even now, some twenty years on, this iffy production still remains questionable.
Richard Shepard's loving, 39-minute tribute to the influential performer who was taken from us all too soon.
movie_title: I Knew It Was You: Rediscovering John Cazale (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Highlights include the post-apocalyptic near-monochromatic look, intriguing sound design, and Schwarzenegger, who taps into an emotional vein he's rarely considered before.
What a voice. What a waste.
This Texan crime drama wears its heart so high on its sleeve that light bruising is inevitable.
As a contemplative view of a contemporary religious family, and how their ideals shape the unfolding drama, Jerry Ciccoritti's "A Prayer in the Dark" is refreshingly faithful to its core.
Leading man Kirk Douglas has himself referred to "The Big Trees" as a bad movie. Bad is perhaps a little harsh, but just a little.
Matthew Barney makes Peter Greenaway look like Joel Schumacher.
Temple University film grads Chaim Bianco and Steven Saylor's "The Pope of Utah" is a wacky, colorful, and savagely funny deconstruction of the American Dream.
Ron Howard's film is one of smoke-eaters, crispers, and torches... and it bestows a renewed respect on a profession all too often taken for granted.
A nice change of pace, with a genuine chemistry between the two leads.
Not to put too fine a point on it, but "Bulletproof Monk" is a rather large piece of garbage.
"Kinsey," like the pioneering sex researcher profiled therein, reduces its subject to a bit of a dry academic exercise.
Blandly acted, idiotically written, and incomprehensibly directed, "Eye of the Dolphin" is quite possibly one of the most incompetently made films I have ever seen.
An out-and-out triumph for the Brothers Affleck.
Begets the less than ringing endorsement, 'Yeah, whatever. It was OK I suppose.'
The allure of Chet Baker's stage persona compared to the shambles of his personal life is staggering in Bruce Weber's fitting elegy to a genius who lived hard yet made it all look so easy.
Think Jerry Seinfeld's "Comedian" x 4!
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: About as funny as Ross on "Friends." David Schwimmer (Ross on "Friends") directs.
To paraphrase Nigel Terry in "The Lion in Winter," "The Guard" is a stinker and it stinks.
Slow moving, even pedestrian at times, yet this Dennis Quaid vehicle strikes a lot of genuinely heartwarming moments along the way.
First with "The Station Agent" and now with "The Visitor" (aka "Muukalainen"), actor-turned-director Tom McCarthy has quickly proven himself a master of the delicately-observed social drama.
This experiment in minimalist filmmaking succeeds in part because of the tight, controlled performance by one of 'People' magazine's sexiest men (buried) alive!
Josh Peck and Ben Kingsley make for an oddly engaging couple in Jonathan Levine's audacious comedy about sex, drugs, and unexpected friendships.
Jolie is alternately distraught and outraged (in good ways) but Eastwood's film is an odd mix of genres that never quite settles into the one we want to watch.
Brutally well-conceived... for about 40 minutes, and then "Martyrs" flips on its own bloody axis and falls apart, existentially.
This Bond -- number 22 if you're counting -- is ruthless, efficient, and tough as nails.
Part alien invasion flick, part social commentary, Neill Blomkamp's chilling, thrilling "District 9" is a wholly original work. And it features a star-making turn from Sharlto Copley.
Scarily real.
Unashamedly old-fashioned and corny, if not quite up to the director's usual high standards.
An infectious documentary about a ragtag band of diehard soccer fans rooting wildly for a team that doesn't yet exist.
You have to credit the Rasmussen Brothers for going spectral rather than splatter, but a good disembowelment rarely hurts.
Like most films of its type, "Destricted" is a decidedly mixed bag.
"Chappie" is one sad motion picture, with Blomkamp's depiction of man's inhumanity to man never more blatant.
This Quaker oater is a B-movie through and through.
A boisterous affair featuring 19th Century whaling, star-crossed lovers, and a young Clara Bow in her screen debut.
movie_title: Down to the Sea in Ships (1923)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, "Tusk" is a stunt, a comedic dare, and a fake-looking one at times (which only seems to help, not hinder, its cause). But the darkness at the film's heart is real and gross and truly disturbing.
Whatever happened to Kevin DiNovis?
The uniquely Swedish "LFO" is as droll as it is uncomfortable.
In hindsight, perhaps self-hypnosis tape recordings don't make for the most engrossing cinema.
Refusing to settle for easy exploitation, director Alexandre Moors paints a vivid, bone-chilling picture of the corrupting power of evil.
Ronan dominates virtually every scene she's in -- and she's in virtually every scene -- with a maturity well beyond her years.
Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are the reason to see this fine rendering of Emma Donoghue's unusual and contained novel of the same name.
An instant classic... and not just a vampire one.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Feels oddly perfunctory, despite valiant turns from Carey Mulligan and Helena Bonham Carter.
"The Baroness and the Pig" is an odd duck.
A cineaste's wet dream. All 13 hours of it.
Given the ultimate fate of The Meeting School, this documentary short subject remains a sad and telling commentary on the challenges of "alternative" education.
Jolly, old-school Bond, if a tad low in "Spectre" gadgets.
Well intentioned but way too obvious for its own good.
Imagine an extended episode of "Pee-wee's Playhouse" with the volume cranked to 11. That's this celluloid version of the "Aimy Micry" comic book.
An intriguing and clever-sounding idea that unfortunately loses its way in the translation from script to screen.
Plays like a collection of outtakes from some "Saw" script that never saw the light of day (or, heaven forbid, has yet to be made).
Jeremy Saulnier's "Blue Ruin" is a small, quiet film brimming with smart directorial decisions.
Monsters are few and far between, and Dark Continent was an offensive name given to Africa by 19th century Europeans, so why exactly this film is called "Monsters: Dark Continent" is anyone's guess.
Cliches abound in this waterlogged post-Cold War thriller from director Kevin Macdonald.
A nifty little shocker that leverages today's plugged in experience to excellent effect.
Another finely reenacted if longwinded history lesson from director Mike Leigh.
Finn and Katherine Yarbrough's affecting, award-winning short is a contemplation of the South Starksboro Meeting House, the oldest continually-used Quaker church in Vermont.
The scenes between Poppy (Sally Hawkins) and driving-instructor Scott (Eddie Marsan) have real bite.
David Hoyle's doomed love affair "Uncle David" is constantly at odds with itself, yet somehow it all works.
An A-list roster of session musicians--on tour with the likes of KISS, Pink, and Billy Joel--get their 15 minutes of fame in director Fran Strine's slick and professional tribute.
"The VVitch" succeeds by delivering up encroaching menace with a mysterious disregard for audience expectations.
The plausibility of its scenario gives "Nerve" an unexpected edge.
A well made and insightful documentary that humanizes the product of a broken criminal justice system.
Schlondorff's treatment is idly drab and antiseptic, indifferent almost, as though he felt Atwood's vision was cinematic enough.
Shear entertainment.
Don't believe the hype. This is one bad "'Driver."
Weisz is Streep-worthy in this somber real-life courtroom drama.
"Tower" takes the art of rotoscoping to dizzying new heights.
Nope.
2017's "My Cousin Rachel" is a solid and finely-acted version of Daphne du Maurier's deliberately-ambiguous drama.
A perfect screwball comedy.
Leave it to the South Koreans to inject new blood into the seemingly eternal vampire oeuvre.
Odd, but oddly entertaining.
One of the few superhero movies to pass the Bechdel test with flying, bullet-deflecting wrist bracelets.
"'Monster" talent.
Ambiguous and absorbing, "Nocturnal Animals" is a worthwhile sophomore essay from the artsy, enigmatic Ford.
What gives Zahler's brutal, bloody, and just plain bizarre film a lot of its oomph is the dialogue, by turns lyrical, absurd, odd, and inventive.
Fantastic looking, fully realized, and thoroughly absorbing, this extension of J.K. Rowling's wizarding world surpassed my expectations exponentially.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: We were always taught "if you can't say something nice, don't say anything at all." Here endeth my review of "Allied."
Ninety years on, "Sunrise" still packs a wallop, technically, even if its storyline is a tad melodramatic.
movie_title: Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans (1927)

movie_review_blurb: Retch Ed.
"Kong: Numbskull Island" is more like it.
"Rat" is an absurdist yarn that eventually outstays its welcome despite magnificent work by Imelda Staunton (vile Professor Umbridge in the Harry Potter films).
Funny, it seems, bears repeating
It would have made for a fantastically immersive installation at the Guggenheim; as a film, however, it's less successful.
"Well now, that music was *very* foreboding; it made a shiver go right down my spine."
Gil Birmingham is especially good, but Jeremy Renner has rarely been better, and Elizabeth Olsen continues to impress.
"Fahrenheit 9/11" doesn't add very much to Moore's all-too-familiar outrage but it certainly puts a human face on war... and a battle-scarred and bloodied face it is.
"'Lightning" strikes a chord with the surefootedness of its cast and crew.
Powerful performances by Forest Whitaker and Eric Bana highlight Roland Joffé's latest political drama.
Branagh's family friendly film is big and bold and egocentric, much like its hirsute protagonist.
A mostly enjoyable, well-written romp wisely entrusted to the comedic chemistry of Jason Bateman and Rachel McAdams.
If you can get over the film's dumb title you'll likely be well entertained.
What if you're not a murderer or a rapist or a thief yet find yourself facing incarceration? You're going to need the "Survivors Guide to Prison."
When a subdued Nicolas Cage is the best thing about your movie, well...
Worthy of its Palme D'Or win at the 2016 Cannes Film Festival.
A magnificent mess.
Thompson's terrifically-assured debut is a thoughtful and no-frills meditation that feels personal and credible and maybe even helpful to some. Stephanie Beatriz is exceptional.
Hailee Steinfeld's star continues to rise.

"Kill Order" isn't terrible, but it will likely appeal more to those who prefer their martial arts mayhem free of such contrivances as fully-realized characterizations, skilled plotting, and a satisfying tone.
An absurdist black comedy from the director of "Jonah Hex."
The whole bumpy ride is starting to feel a little stale and unashamedly lazy.
A mesmerizing portrait of a North Philadelphia family over a tumultuous decade.
Uniformly fine performances highlight this brooding Alaskan small-town noir.
Memorable, murderous fun.
In space, nobody can you hear you roll your eyes.
With carefully-crafted chills, well-developed characters, and a strong storyline, "It" deserves a place in the canon of stellar Stephen King adaptations.
"Realive" feels a little sterile and its performances are hit and miss. But its thought-provoking conceit keeps you engaged until the very--and largely ironic--end.
Fans of oom-pah-pah revelry, Hammer Horrors, and Victorian-era introspection should find plenty to whet their appetites in "The Limehouse Golem."
First-time director Matt Spicer makes good use of Aubrey Plaza's one-note appeal in "Ingrid Goes West," a stalker comedy in the tradition of Martin Scorsese's superior "The King of Comedy."
"Dude, Where's My Career?"
Gerald Kargl's home invasion splatter flick--the only film he ever made--is a fascinating experience despite the sordid subject matter.
Both the CGI bear and Leonardo DiCaprio's Oscar-winning performance were perfectly well done.
A finely-crafted ensemble piece.
A limp 70s horror entry from mannequin meister David Schmoeller (the "Puppet Master" series).
An assured and ambitious arthouse odyssey from the Zelners, with the wonderful, wistful Rinko Kikuchi at its core.
Banal and embarrassing and cliched beyond words, trite and awkward and perplexing. But hey, at least nobody dies. Well, except Hugh Grant's character, who "went down in the bush," snork, snork.
The biggest band that nobody's heard of (to quote one of its members) is documented in this flashy, big screen hucksterfest.
Denis Cote's elegant, wordless contemplation of man's fascination with--and indirect dependence on--animals is like a coffee table book thumbed through on film.
Proves without a doubt that America doesn't hold a monopoly on obnoxious child actors.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hollar if you've heard this one before.
Mikkelsen makes this personal horror show his own with a powerful and remarkably controlled performance.
A real meat and potatoes proposition -- satisfying *and* tasty!
Bogdanovich, the principal proponent of the latter-day screwball comedy, wastes a large and capable cast here.
The ups and downs of the titular Andy Warhol sculpture are as engaging as they are informative.
As sleazy a viewing experience as one might expect from a movie in which Bruce Dern kidnaps Maud Adams and scribbles all over her.
Lily Tomlin and her female counterparts excel in this drama/comedy/road movie hybrid -- a warm, small film, not earth-shattering, but genuine.
I enjoyed their films. Particularly the early, good ones.
Together, Knight and Hardy take us on an extraordinary journey.
Silverman is excellent, but she could use a better script.

"The Lobster" peters out about halfway through but regardless, director Lanthimos and co-writer Filippou have constructed a singular and ambitious vision, rich with symbolism and observant commentary about societal pressures to pair up.
As far as justifying yet another version of "Macbeth" to the Brothers Weinstein goes, this ain't a half bad way to do it.
Tom Hardy shines in "Legend"--twice, in fact--but his satisfying dual performance is the *only* thing Brian Helgeland's film has going for it.
Adorable.
If you truly want to see "Ghostbusters" remade in a fresh and reverential way, rent "Be Kind Rewind" (preferably on VHS... but stay away from those power stations!).
This Brit shocker looks and sounds good, but its plot is a little too reminiscent of the far superior Anthony Shaffer-penned/Robin Hardy-directed "'Wicker Man" for comfort.
Any film that makes Rose Byrne unappealing has its head well and truly up its bum.
Alas, there's nobody to root for in any of this: you feel manipulated by Lady Susan, sorry for Frederica, irritated by Reginald, and embarrassed by Sir James.
Competently made -- noisy and intense -- but not a pretty picture.

This disposable drama manages to blur the lines between reality and fantasy so convincingly that it's hard to tell when one shamelessly sleazy work in progress peters out and the main story arc kicks in.
A jolly if undernourished SyFy channel vision, one which could have benefited from a little attention to detail in the close-up work (its script included).
"Keeping Up with the Joneses" is a fun, silly comedy with few pretensions and an extremely likeable cast.
Time has not been kind to "Educating Rita."
Do we really need another franchise with a tall-ish, "42"-year-old vigilante drifter cracking heads? Probably not.
David Mackenzie's modern-day Western hits the high-water mark in terms of its uniformly fine performances if not, necessarily, its narrative construct.
An extremely satisfying throwback to those classic gumshoe dramas of the '40s and '50s, with their style and tone purposefully intact.
Maintains the elegance and enchantment of the original film.
Winslet and Davis are formidable in "The Dressmaker."
"Get Out" succeeds by taking a fairly-standard horror format and invigorating it with a visceral social element.
The targeted demographic--gore fans with short attention spans--are going to eat this superior sequel up.
Demis Roussos, anyone?
Not every gag lands, but those that do make this broad yet lovable schlub of a comedy worth a $3.99 online stream.
A humorless, Debbie Downer of a dysfunctional family drama, all the more disappointing given its promising pedigree.
Nate Parker might well be the next big thing... if he's ever given the chance to work in Hollywood again.
Byrum's X-rated smut fest is abundantly witty, often pointed, and well played by the entire cast (of five).
Alas, the stylized, wall-to-wall inauthenticity pries out the emotional heart of this modern-day musical fantasy, leaving it needless and empty.
Purposefully and persuasively continues the Disney tradition of tough, outspoken, and intrepid heroines without skipping a beat.
Just this old sick song keeps Georgia on my mine.
An unusual -- and unusually joyous -- embattled siblings flick, flush with quirks and neat asides and insanely funny bits you barely saw coming.
Great Scot!
Equal parts taut and titillating... until it jumps the shark in its final act.
A refreshingly arch sense of humor coupled with some non-standardization, genre-wise, elevate this gloppy creature feature.
Pegg and Bell click, and that's enough to carry the picture.
A worthy baptism for those unacquainted with the genre but less fulfilling, perhaps, for the pre-converted eager to experience more.
movie_title: Free Radicals: A History of Experimental Film (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Does exactly what it says on the tin.
Queer roller derby gets its due in Erica Tremblay's impassioned doc.
The very definition of a mondo midnight movie!
Director Danny Boyle takes a love story, wraps it up in television game show, and delivers it via a kaleidoscopic travelogue of Mumbai. And it works. Splendidly!
A cool, calculated exercise in serious discomfort.
This flat, uninspired sailing documentary from the Walt Disney studios has surprisingly little to say.
Foster is the reason to see "Flightplan"; she lends the film both a consummate strength and vulnerability.
A sedentary, well-acted, but awfully familiar-feeling Lasse Hallström drama.
Meirelles's technique -- bravura camerawork coupled with crisscross editing -- makes what might have been a straightforward political thriller his own.
"Junebug" is a Southern class struggle played out in small, with Amy Adams the brightest star among these delicate -- and often misunderstood -- flowers.
Maddeningly brilliant -- and typically excessive -- in keeping with Greenaway's more mature works.
movie_title: The Tulse Luper Suitcases Part I - The Moab Story (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Grim is as "'Grimm" does.
Smart performances (by up-and-comers Rachel McAdams and Cillian Murphy) highlight Wes Craven's overnight fright.
Wilson and Vaughn generate more chemistry than a high school science project.
Has its articulate moments but for the most part Rob Zombie's grisly, nasty "'Devils Rejects" is mostly just grisly (and nasty).
Hope springs for "Eternal," more an erotic character study than an unsightly bloodbath.
Herzog's obituary to eco-warrior Timothy Treadwell is often intriguing but ultimately feels oddly -- and sadly -- senseless.
Three words best sum up this fine film: Terrence Dashon Howard.
It's hard to imagine a more fitting interpreter of Roald Dahl, particularly his beloved 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,' than director Tim Burton.
Attractive, witty, and exceedingly cute movie seeks undiscerning viewers for good times and more!
Environmentalists will tell you that recycling is a good thing but the Adam Sandler vehicle "The Longest Yard" goes out of its way to prove otherwise.
Reminds us, unequivocally, why 3-D has yet to catch on. "Special" effects notwithstanding, this Robert Rodriguez quickie is strictly for the younger set.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: All summer blockbusters should be as loud and scary -- and deliver -- like this.
Director Boyle continues to genre hop but "Millions," a quirky comedy punctuated by unnecessary digressions, nicely fits the "childhood fantasy" bill.
Underdeveloped and uneven yet oddly watchable, the gimmicky "Palindromes" once again cements the conceit that nobody makes films quite like Todd Solondz.
Subtlety and sensitivity are not words one equates with the Farrelly Bros. but they're deployed in spades in "Fever Pitch," the shockingly good Americanization of Hornby.
The contrivances of first-time director Paul Haggis's script ultimately hurt the film but this "Crash" is still worth a curious drive-by look.
Schizophrenic but mildly diverting, with a revelatory performance by Radha Mitchell in the lead(s).
Another international accent from Kidman, another brooding, broken man from Penn, and another taut, tense, political thriller from director Pollack.
It's the performances -- three unerringly strong female ones -- that highlight this take on Jennifer Weiner's popular Philly-based chick-lit offering.
German kickboxer-turned-director Lexi Alexander's brutal, unsparing portrait of disaffected youth running rampant amid the football stands and terraces of jolly old England.
Dakota Fanning, the busiest child actor on the planet it seems, brings her usual maturity to this fine family film. The horse is pretty good too.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: You keep waiting for the weak link in the chain, or the half-hearted performance, but they never ever come.
Radha Mitchell is the reason to sit through this overblown Grand Guignol entertainment from the director of the similarly overblown "Brotherhood of the Wolf."
Presley Chweneyagae excels in this hard-hitting urban drama, South Africa's answer to "City of God" (not that anyone asked the question).
There's nothing here a good dose of Viagra couldn't cure. Impotent and dull as dishwater.
Ultracrappy more like.
They say good things come in threes: burials, for one, and Tommy Lee Jones (for another).
movie_title: The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Dogs rule, humans drool!
(Tongue-in) cheeky and rambling, much like the voluminous tome that inspired it.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Barrier grief.
Its lousy title notwithstanding, "'Indian" is a winning character study of a crusty curmudgeon, played to the handlebars by Anthony Hopkins.
A bright and often bold comedy that presents a difficult subject matter -- that of the struggle for women's rights -- in a fresh and entertaining way.
Daring and spine-tinglingly effective, Michael Haneke's "Caché" does just about everything right... until its incongruous final scene.
Comic, sexy, and ultraviolent -- one of the best films of the year!
Grumpy Glaswegians going at it are once again the focus of David ("Young Adam") Mackenzie's bleak and dreary -- but not wholly uninteresting -- drama.
Brosnan and Kinnear are a bullish odd couple.
Viewers check in... and just as quickly check out!
Rambling and naïve -- surely not what the director intended.
If "'Jesus is Magic" then God is, without a doubt, a Woman: Sarah Silverman.
A miserable misfire that might explain why so many people take their own lives during the holidays.
Excess has never felt so spectacular... but there's nothing here a good editor couldn't have improved (had he been allowed to).
A nice change of pace from Allen until, that is, about three-quarters of the way in when the pace changes too awkwardly and serves the film its first double fault.
A faithful and exultant rendering of the classic children's fable. Bring on "Prince Caspian"!
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It would be most inconvenient [to loathe this movie] since, having already seen it (thrice and counting), I swore to love it for all eternity.
With "North Country," Theron and Caro strongly suggest that "Monster" and "Whale Rider" weren't one-offs.
Hitchcock did this sort of thing much, much better of course. But "Derailed"'s strangers on a train are still worth your nine bucks or so.
Murphy models his frocks comfortably enough, but "'Pluto" is draggy in other, disappointing ways.
Well-acted, occasionally tense, and intriguing at times but mostly pat and predictable NYPD Blue screen stuff.
The best thing about Episode III? Jar Jar Binks is barely in it.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Lovely to look at but penguins waddling cross country for 80 minutes is a bit of a hard sell.
Makes "'Tomb Raider" look like an epic.
As predictable and impotent as a John McEnroe outburst.
Pretentious pornographic stuff and nonsense.
What's shocking today is very different to what was shocking 20 years ago... but John Waters doesn't seem to have noticed.
An enjoyable and visually dashing computer-generated exercise.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Simply put, rrrrRick is grrrreat!
A competent Americanization of the Argentinian film "Nine Queens," with John C. Reilly seemingly enjoying his atypical leading role.
Reese's piece certainly looks good, it's just not terribly engaging.
I didn't hate it nearly as much as I ought to have, thought I would, and/or everyone else.
Zhang Yimou's "Hero" is another stirring example of how beautifully rendered films with subtitles stand a chance of hitting paydirt in the multiplexes.
This cautionary tale for adults might be a little close to the bone, perhaps, for some audience members, but it's a sincere and finely-wrought ensemble piece.
A vain and vapid intellectual exercise that only serves to illustrate Lars von Trier's unswerving arrogance.
Part Three Stooges, part "'Seven Samurai," "Zatôichi" is the film Quentin Tarantino tried to realize with the one-two sucker punch of "Kill Bill."
Another winning Michael Mann character study (see: "The Insider," "Heat," "Thief") with Jamie Foxx revelatory in the lead.
"Open Water" muddies a compelling subject matter via shoddy and incompetent filmmaking. A shallow and frustrating exercise in treading water.
'They dropped everything for a good cause' would seem to refer more to the filmmakers than the gutsy, middle-aged women shedding their clothes for a hospital couch.
A sublime and sophisticated debut from writer/director/star Zack Braff, this year's "Lost in Translation" with Newark, NJ standing in for Tokyo.
Comparisons to "This is Spinal Tap" abound in this inside look at the heavy metal rock band Metallica, but "This is Spinal Tap" was a heck of a lot of fun also.
The filmmakers, clearly never having seen the original TV series, sideline the spacecraft and reduce this debacle to what essentially amounts to boys 'n' The Hood.
As remakes go, Demme's film is one of the better ones, but why does Hollywood insist on remaking classics when there are so many bad ones out there needing improvement?
"De-Lovely" is missing the passion and brio it needs to function on a level that best befits its iconic subject -- clever, witty and seemingly effortless in its creation.
An excellent rendering of the first third of 'A Widow for One Year,' and one of the best John Irving adaptations to date thanks to the Oscar (R)-worthy Bridges and Basinger.
There's nothing here a handful of show-stopping production numbers -- or a good steam cleaning -- couldn't fix.
"The Last Shot" commits the cardinal sin of comedies: it isn't funny.
David O. Russell continues to prove just how wacky a filmmaker he truly is. In "'Huckabees" the laughs are mixed, but the wackiness couldn't be more inspired.
Surprisingly good natured given its take-no-prisoners lampooning of ethnic and cultural stereotypes, the war in Iraq, homosexuality, AIDS... not to mention Hollywood's finest.
Another bleak, harrowingly realistic drama from Mike Leigh highlighted by a phenomenal star turn by Imelda Staunton in the title role.
Comparisons to Eastwood's Oscar-winning "Million Dollar Baby" are not only expected but welcomed, since "Cinderella Man" is (surprisingly) just as good.
Wow!
The oddest bird here doesn't have wings.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Frank and fascinating, "Gunner Palace" brings the Iraqi War home, putting the dangerous and boring lives of U.S. soldiers into equally provocative perspective.
Less is often more but in the case of "The Ring Two," the lazily-titled sequel to the popular -- and enormously successful -- "The Ring," more is less (more or less).
Bruno Ganz dominates "Downfall," a long but never dull look at Hitler's final days in his Berlin bunker.
"Dear Frankie," with its strong casting and confident direction, is a lasting love letter worth experiencing.
Get "'Shorty" out of your head for a couple of goofy, irreverent hours and there's a good chance you'll enjoy this inferior yet amiable sequel.
An unsentimental look at how beauty, artistry, and hope can emerge from the most unexpected of places.
Devilishly more entertaining than it has any right to be.
Reminds us, sweetly, charmingly, and humorously, what Will Smith used to be like before he became an overnight action sensation.
Pawel Pawlikowski's open and poetic new film proves without a shadow of a doubt that his stunning "Last Resort" from 2000 was no fluke.
Laudably manages to avoid the inherent sordidness of "Pretty Woman" and the underlying sadness of "My Best Friend's Wedding."
Delights as often as it dulls the senses.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Topher Grace dominates this smart and funny film with a thing or two to say about how people are treated and treat each other in the workplace.
Nicely cast and technically adept, "Lemony Snicket'" is the first film in a likely franchise I could fortunately tolerate.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The director and star of "Amélie" (Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Audrey Tautou) reunite for this grimmer, grimier, but no less magnificent moviegoing experience.
Director James L. Brooks has given us some familial and cultural truths to think long and hard about, with ironic performances to savor.
Despite formidable performances by Roberts, Law, Portman, and Owen, Mike Nichols's "Closer" is weakened by both its source material and odd directorial decision making.
Any resemblance between this big screen debacle and the sweet-and-funny Nickelodeon cable show on which it's supposedly based is entirely coincidental.
Spends so much time down Selma Hayek's shirt fronts that we come away suffocated.
A masterfully crafted entertainment that devolves into an overlong, overly loud, and disappointingly stock shoot 'em up.
"Saw"'s intriguing and genuinely creepy premise is quickly undone by the limitations of both the script and the performers.
The wine metaphors flow like, er... wine in this bold, boisterous, and eminently quaffable road movie/buddy movie hybrid from director Alexander Payne.
A rare disappointment from Almodóvar: perilously over-the-top gay chic coupled with an overly-familiar condemnation of the Holy Catholic Church's blind eye towards pedophilia.
Too much potty humor -- and not enough inspired comedy -- sink this fourth installment in the SM franchise.
Huffman and Zegers make "Transamerica" a road trip worth taking.
Barney and Björk certainly deserve each other; theirs is a match made purgatorial.
Alas, it just doesn't work. It could have, but it doesn't.
The games, the traps, are still the thing and as long as Jigsaw's flunkies continue to build 'em, we will come.
Nice to look at, but about as weighty as the froth atop a tall skim latte.
For all its quixotic quirkiness, "The Darjeeling Limited" is little more than artifice for the art house set.
This sporadically funny Farrellys farce is worth watching (mostly) for Stiller (Ben) and the game Akerman (Malin) in the leads.
"Good Luck Chuck" is a soft-core male indulgence posing as a hip Hollywood good luck chuckle.
There hasn't been a documentary this sick since Kirby Dick's "Sick"!
The brains behind Cartoon Network's "Aqua Teen Hunger Force" have stretched their 12-minute plus commercials 'Adult Swim' series entry into 86 rather uneven ones.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bravura performances can't save this "'One," a run-of-the-mill vigilante flick from director Neil Jordan (not known for his run-of-the-mill anything).
There are certainly worse ways to kill 90 odd minutes of one's time than spending two days in Paris in the estimable company of "Woody" (Adam) and "Mia" (Julie).
Hoffman's icy villain -- and Cruise's smoldering vulnerability -- make this the most entertaining "Mission'" to date!
It's refreshing to see the French finally producing a worthy entry in the horror genre.
Wall-to-wall stiffness runs rampant in this latest take on Jack Finney's oft-filmed "'Body Snatchers" yarn.
If you like your outhouse humor explosive then this "'Camp"'s for you!
When it's not fast and furious, "The Bourne Ultimatum" settles for slick and noisy... and it's often hard to tell these two moods apart.
I could watch Kingsley and Leoni for days. They're the film's true draw.
Cute idea, poor execution...
A cinematically sound but sub-par horror flick readied for the American mass market by the addition of English credits and some truly atrocious dubbing.
Sally Potter has achieved a work that sings to us -- sensually, angrily, and beautifully.
Lindsay, pre-drugs.
Michael Moore takes on U.S. Healthcare (or lack thereof) in this impassioned plea for change.
Better than "Bruce'" by at least two turtle doves and a 40-year-old virgin...
It's got action, romance, incredible CGI, convincing performances, a loud and lively musical score, way cool robots, and an adorable Chihuahua in a cast. What's not to like?
Six sexy spelunkers in an underground fright fest make for keen and claustrophobic cinema.
A huge disappointment after Baumbach's sublime "'Squid and the Whale." Ugly, murky, and mean.
With "No Country for Old Men," the brothers Coen return to Texas -- and to form.
A majestic and intimate romance that should rightly cement the careers of director Joe Wright and leading man James McAvoy, and give Saoirse Ronan some much-deserved exposure.
British funny man Simon Pegg continues his downwards spiral with this lame, "'Devil Wears Prada"-styled "comedy."
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Nobody plays put-upon quite like Ben Stiller.
The complexities of the script, while clever, will likely fly over the heads of most within its target demographic.
Scores an 11 (out of 10) for sheer inspired lunacy but it's the writers' unexpected fondness for their subject matter that puts the film in a class all its own.
A pleasant return to the silliness of the Coens' earlier pictures from the stiltedness of their latter-day offerings ("No Country'" excepted).
The highs and lows of getting one's first book published are intricately and delightfully examined in Norwegian director Joachim Trier's mature feature debut.
A dull dramatization of -- and ill-fitting testament to -- British journalist George Hogg's experiences in war torn China.
Jack Black puts the "POW!" in "Kung'" pao.
Stuart ("Re-Animator") Gordon's murky misuse of Mena Suvari and Stephen Rea makes John Carpenter movies look like Art.
Where are the truth in titular advertising police when you need them?
Maybe I've got some subconscious porcine fetish thing going (or something) but I think Christina Ricci looks kind of cute with a pig's snout where her nose should be...
While not entirely fantastic, this "'Four" is fun, fast-paced, and family friendly.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: More bronzed bodies bearing arms leading to inevitable shootouts delivered via a washed-out, hand-held digital style pulsing along to an infectious Latin beat.
OK of its type, even if its type is starting to exude that slightly disagreeable scent of 'been there, done that.'
Daniel Day-Lewis's magnificent, sanguine performance as oilman Daniel Plainview is just one of many reasons to catch P.T. Anderson's latest feature.
A harrowing look at how war takes its terrible toll on the innocent.
Arguably, it's 'Even Better Than the Real Thing.'
Adam Brooks's traditional rom-com isn't going to win any awards but it's easy on the brain as well as on the eyes.
Are we supposed to be charmed, or shocked, by this? Allen doesn't seem to know.
Money is really important in this world, apparently.
As an addition to the psychological thriller genre, "The Orphanage" is a solid, well-rehearsed entry.
By the end of the "The Water Horse" Russell's film has pretty much morphed into "Free Willy IV: Lassie Go Home."
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: So darned depressing in its observancy that it's no stretch to assume that writer/director Jenkins might have experienced something entirely similar first hand.
Screenwriter Cody's wit and imagination are seemingly endless.
By the time this intense, well-made drama has run its inevitable course you might well want to collapse in the snow and wave your own arms up and down in surrender.
The main draw, of course, is watching Hopkins and Gosling go head-to-head. And both are more than up to the challenge.
Yet another stirring example that The Western is still very much alive and kicking.
If you love films (and Paris) then this omnibus edition is strongly recommended.

"Infamous"' powerhouse casting doesn't add much, since most of the big names -- Sigourney Weaver, Gwyneth Paltrow, Isabella Rossellini, Hope Davis, Juliet Stevenson, and director Peter Bogdanovich -- serve as little more than window dressing.
A bloody, awful mess.
Might I suggest a new ratings category for the MPAA: NP-21 (non-parents over the age of 21 might want to skip this one altogether).
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A slick but empty period noir. De Palma can do better than this.
Neil LaBute's remake of the British horror classic is as wooden as its titular effigy... and wholly unnecessary.
Ryan Gosling wrestles with adult themes and comes out on top.
"Little Miss Sunshine" offers, among other things, ensemble acting at its very best. You'd be hard pressed to find a funnier, more touching film this year.

Utterly charming.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Funnier, less offensive, and certainly better company than "'Harry" or "'Aphrodite" but "Scoop" still suffers from an overabundance of tired borscht-belt humor.

A watery, ladylike, and extremely tall tale indeed, but one well within the reach of its fine cast (which this time includes its director).

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A high-energy document to the power of performance and uncanned creativity.
Extremely silly... and surprisingly sweet.
This "'Break-Up" is, unfortunately, hard to do.

The third "Saw" in the franchise loses its edge.
Methinks it might have connected better as a narrative piece...
Pretty as a picture... and as empty as a French peasant's portefeuille.

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Apparently it takes "'Weeks'," rather than "'Days'," to enjoy a sprightly-paced, finely-acted, and surprisingly intelligent apocalyptic zombie horror.
Not quite as inspired as "Shaun of the Dead" but near as damn it.

movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

Marky Marksman...
Worth seeing more for its thoughtful attention to detail than its satisfying completeness.
All of a sudden there's hope for "Gigli"!
While it's often fun watching Jim Carrey handle more serious material the same cannot always be said of director Joel Schumacher.

Ugh.

Part film noir, part melodrama, part Hitchcockian thriller, the film strives to be anything and everything and in many ways succeeds.
