Even bemused viewers will delight at Dietrich's sublimely ridiculous costumes as well as some of Hollywood's most awe-inspiring imagery. The elusive, unobtainable object of desire has really never been more sumptuously captured.
Switching from dour humour to humanist drama without seeming contrived, this is a masterclass in combining character and landscape that is played with deceptive poignancy by the excellent leads.
The co-directors not only chronicle a landmark scoop, but also highlight the importance of investigative journalism.
movie_title: Attacking The Devil: Harold Evans And The Last Nazi War Crime (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [A] teasingly semi-autobiographical, but decidedly underwhelming melodrama.
This adaptation of Boris Pasternak's classic novel has all the sweep and stateliness that characterised David Lean's mastery of the epic.
Eschews cosy nostalgia to focus on the skills, perils and exploitation involved in the acts and the communality of life on the road.
The suspense is superbly maintained as the excellent Gosheva struggles to stay on her pedestal.
A nostalgic, but considered tribute to an almost extinct lifestyle that kept the masses entertained for over a century.
Exquisitely designed, this cornucopia of melodramatic fragments and movie pastiches will enchant Guy Maddin fans.
The archive footage is compelling, but the soundtrack is a muddle of voice-over, music and effects.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Once again, Maddin draws his inspiration from cinema's transitional phase between silent and sound, and he is abetted wonderfully by production designer Galen Johnson and cinematographer Stéphanie Weber-Biron.
This is fascinating stuff, though the fussily faux soundtrack and heavy-handed hagiographic tone occasionally intrude too much.
movie_title: Antarctica: Ice & Sky (La glace et le ciel) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While this is always informative, it often feels like an illustrated lecture that over-scrupulously avoids the contentious topic of Guggenheim's taste in both painting and men.
Christian Duguay directs steadily and makes the most of Christophe Graillot's handsome photography.

Combining stunning vistas with intimate insights, Jennifer Peedom's compelling account of life on Mount Everest is an astute appreciation of the Sherpa existence and their value to a $350 million business that often takes them for granted.
Tellingly, little actual dancing is shown as Read snoops backstage, only scratching the surface of the scandal, though with plenty of simmering intrigue and splendid archive material.
While bullishly played by all, this raises more broad laughs than potent points about art and politics.
In truth, Bejo and Attal lack a certain romantic spark, but Barbier still manages to spring several neat surprises in the final stretch.
Coolly intelligent and noirishly compelling.
A corking conspiracy lies at the heart of Chad Gracia's debut documentary, whose darkly comic proceedings are strewn with covert recordings and animated interludes.
It's simply a masterpiece.
As always with Greenaway, the dialogue tends towards the florid and the intellectual. Nevertheless, he remains a master image-maker and an irrepressible subversive.
Lampedusa is barely eight square miles in size and some 400,000 souls have passed through it over the last 20 years. But Rosi makes it abundantly clear this is an emergency that affects everyone.
It's possible to detect an allegorical discussion of Thailand's recent travails, but this distinctive blend of lyricism and mysticism is to be experienced as much as understood.

The young leads are excellent ... as is first-time cinematographer Tobin Jones, who eschews the grimy greys of traditional northern realism to capture the everyday locales in plangently living colour.
A notable debut by an undoubted talent. But, despite the premise's intrigue, this never quite engrosses as it should.

Notwithstanding the efforts of a game cast, this is a grotesque miscalculation that disrespects the memory of those who perished in one of the darkest episodes in recent history by turning it into a piece of white-knuckle entertainment.

Employs an engaging, if sometimes strained blend of quirky comedy and mawkish melodrama to explore the emotional state of a 29-year-old striving to reconcile the loss of a beloved twin brother with the need to get on with her own life.
Chantal Akerman's final film is both a tribute to a dying mother and the last testament of a director who would take her own life just months after the premiere, aged 65.
Evoking the spirit of 1970s crime maestro Fernando Di Leo, Sollima's sense of pace and place is impeccable, while the performances seethe with decadence, danger and despair.
Hilarious in places, hideous in others, this struggles to make its philosophical case. But the performances are exceptional and the conceit could not be more daring or distinctive.

Unflinching in its eschewal of objectivity, this provides a unique perspective on a notorious case, while correcting some of the impressions about urban black youth the media cravenly peddled in its aftermath.

Adams stages the opening speedboat chase with aplomb, but the shootouts are much more formulaic and rely heavily on the laughable inaccuracy of the gang's adversaries and sassy sharpshooter Jenna Kelly's penchant for skimpy outfits.

Production designer Anna Falguères and cinematographer Jeanne Lapoirie expertly capture the town-and-country contrasts, while De France and Higelin boldly commit to their challenging, if underwritten roles.
Alongside Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs, this was the most astonishing and hard-hitting directorial debut of the 1990s.

Ostensibly, a lovingly made study of homemade cooking and old-fashioned values, this beautifully played drama also contains a mordant denunciation of the lack of compassion that shapes Japanese attitudes to social stigma.
It brilliantly recaptures the rage, cynicism and self-destructiveness of the late 1970s punk scene, while never setting up the rock 'n' roll lifestyle as a blissful idyll.
Given little to work with, Thelma Schoonmaker edits proficiently and there's a pleasing Indian-inspired score, but the film strains so hard to be equitable that it fails to engage.
Dormael can't be faulted for his ambition. But his corking idea never quite pays off.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Slickly staged and shot, this neo-noir deftly exploits its clichés. It's hardly original, but it teasingly intrigues, while Iggy Pop steals every scene.
Cinematographer Akiko Ashizawa's use of light and texture should be applauded as much as Fukatsu's touching performance.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Heavy going for all its beauty, but still superior to Disney's own live-action adaptation with Jason Scott Lee.
Needs to be viewed in its entirety in order to appreciate the depth of Portugal's malaise and the bold brilliance of Gomes's conceit.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 1 - The Restless One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 1, O Inquieto) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There is so little political depth and dramatic tension in the leaden script that the subversive aspect of Ritchie and Pinto's platonic partnership is almost negligible.

Co-directors Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato have turned a homophobic accusation into an aesthetic exhortation, as they urge viewers to look again at pictures that were branded as pornographic and recognise their artistic merit.
A visually audacious yet highly personal study of the uneasy relationship between postwar Hungary and its past.
This is a little too dependent on sassy one-liners and is awash with sentiment by the end, but is still wonderful entertainment.
The humour is exceedingly gentle and the plot increasingly improbable. But John Miller directs steadily and the performances are irresistibly knowing.
Once again, the imagery is sublime, while Gomes provides much to ponder, unsettle and amuse.
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 2 - The Desolate One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 2, O Desolado) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Rules dont mean much to Portuguese auteur Miguel Gomes and he concludes his masterly triptych by confounding expectations ...
movie_title: Arabian Nights: Volume 3, the Enchanted One (As Mil e Uma Noites: Volume 3, O Encantado) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A gruelling watch and a searing indictment of America's disregard for its indigenous peoples.
Your opinion of this tale of a troubled country superstar will depend totally on your reaction to George Strait. There's no denying he's handy with a tune, but dialogue proves more difficult for him.
A superbly acted study of suppression that's more intent on provocation than plausibility.
Some may find the blizzard of ideas and images a little spurious and overpowering, but this is a deeply personal expression of visionary art and love.
Scott Chambers reprises the role he originated on the London fringe stage and excels in debutant director Joe Stephenson's careful, if not always convincing adaptation of Freddie Machin's 2011 play.
[A] sincere, if overly familiar tale of adolescent self-obsession and sexual confusion.
Sluggishly formulaic, this is a disappointingly superficial interpretation of an important book.
Mesmerising and wondrously atmospheric ...
The camaraderie and courage on display is humblingly affecting.
movie_title: Tell Spring Not To Come This Year (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping ...
Rarely have one and a half hours felt so like a life sentence.
Provides a stark insight into the demands made of junior doctors in a health system hamstrung by staff shortages and antiquated apparatus.
movie_title: Hippocrates: Diary of a French Doctor (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Plenty to admire, amuse, contemplate and provoke.
Set in postwar occupied Vienna, the plot is a corker, littered with memorable moments and played to perfection by an unforgettable cast that's led with distinction by Orson Welles and Joseph Cotten.
Ambitious and innovative, the science is cogently presented but the plot fails to compel.
Gimmicky but making a valid and useful point.
Little analytical insight or visual flair in this lacklustre documentary.
movie_title: Faberge: A Life Of Its Own (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While beautiful, early scenes of shocking violence give way to philosophising and gauche symbolism.
The snippets from the classrooms are fascinating, as is the charming pre-reality TV naturalness of the teen subjects.

This is a meticulously researched investigation into the achievements and mysterious disappearance of Le Prince, who vanished without trace while travelling on the Dijon-Paris express in September 1890.
Stuffed with fascinating details about the stage, radio and screen achievements of the wunderkind who never quite fulfilled his potential.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The high-school reunion set-up fizzes with a Festen-like savagery, but ultimately its sapped by a resistible narcissism.
Unfortunately, [Fassbinder's] cynical detachment leaves us appalled but unmoved.
This compelling moment in history really deserves a more insightful reconstruction.
Superb star turn from Maria Alexandra Lungi but this doesn't grip as it might.
Charming if scattershot ...
Flecked with tension, wit and slick martial artistry.
The leads are splendid, with Azaïs's genial vacancy and Haenel's deadpan gravity persuading viewers that they could be a genuine couple.
For all the claustrophobic acuity of Tim Pannen's production design and the disorientating effect of Frank Lamm's kinetic camerawork, this fails to generate sufficient empathy or suspense.
Karan Johar's directorial debut was much hyped before its release, but it offers little to distinguish it from the average Bollywood melodrama.
Gritty police programmes are now so much a part of the TV landscape that it is hard to realise that a feature like The Offence once packed quite a punch.
A clumsily constructed documentary that compounds its cockeyed chronology by devoting too little time to the movies on which Fuller's reputation rests.
This is a treat.
The camera prowls menacingly through the interiors, but the writers seem too content with their improbable conceit to bother with back story or character arcs.
Exceptional human filmmaking.
Shyam Benega made his feature debut with this astute drama, a key work in the politically committed alternative to mainstream escapism known as Parallel Cinema.
Buster Keaton's third and shortest feature ranks among his best.
Compelling and powerfully played, but sometimes fussily flashy.
It's unabashed melodrama, but nevertheless wholly cinematic.

John Gielgud might not be everyone's ideal Hitchcock hero, and contemporary critics were quick to point out his lack of derring-do, but, in fact, he acquits himself admirably in this engaging thriller.
Delights in flouting generic convention at every twisting turn.
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Cinematographer Vicci Turpin achieves a brutal poetry in exploring the sprawling poverty of the Cape Flats shanty town ...
Grips like a thriller but it also amuses ...
If your little dinosaur lovers are still a bit young for Jurassic Park, then this charming cartoon should have them in raptures.
The chaos Buster causes as a stage stand-in and the sequence when he tries to put a drunken woman to bed just about save the day.
Outstanding account of a pivotal moment in small-screen history.
Director Milcho Manchevski brings an imposing portentousness to this portmanteau picture, but too often he mistakes ponderousness for gravity.
It's a bold attempt to do something dazzlingly original, although some of the gags are spectacularly unfunny and Pee-wee's nervous prattling can become irritating.
Whatever the film's shortcomings, though, the music is superb.
This was the 13th Bond movie and it's possibly the most frivolous in the series to date (it's certainly the most careless).
This lacklustre romantic comedy seems a little like a lost episode in the life of Helberg's Big Bang Theory character, Howard Wolowitz.
Prhaps the poorest film of [Hitchcock's] Hollywood career.
Although the plot becomes needlessly busy, Legrand fails to generate palpable terror and the ending feels rather rushed.
This was Timothy Dalton's debut as 007 and it was already pretty clear that he lacked the necessary ironic touch that made the credibility-straining action seem fun rather than ridiculous.
Beautifully shot, brilliantly scored by John Barry and sensitively staged by director James Hill, this charming adaptation of Joy Adamson's bestseller is one of the great animal films.
Exploring activism's role in the '60s struggle for civil rights, this is a powerful look at a contentiously iconic movement.
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Time will tell, but Brand's fans and foes alike will find much to delight and disquiet them in this difficult, but consistently fascinating documentary.
If you want to know what the ultimately synthetic box-office film would look like, then try this weepie.
Director Terence Young never quite solves the pacing problems posed by filming underwater, but John Stears's Oscar-winning special effects more than compensate.
Audrey Tautou has a poignant cameo and the production design is charming, but the magic Gondry tries so hard to inject is missing.
As much an exercise in showcasing conspicuous wealth as an insight into the man and his achievements, this is a vulgar vanity project that massively misses a unique opportunity.
The leads are outstanding, but credit should also go to the forgotten Cyril Raymond, whose decent dullness as Johnson's husband makes those stolen Thursdays seem so special.
Hugely engaging and quietly potent ...
Mesmerising, challenging and defiantly unique.

Dickensian in its empathy with the poor, uncompromising in its realism and ambitious in both scope and technique, this debut feature from Mira Nair is one of the most arresting studies of street life ever made.

While the acting styles of John Cassavetes and Charlton Heston clash like cymbals, director Larry Peerce preoccupies himself with grandstanding camerawork that does little to heighten tension or make us care for the potential targets.
But Dustin Hoffman produces a splendid depiction of cunning corruption that acts as a perfect balance to McQueen's superstar charisma.
Essential for lovers of Test cricket.
Smart and enthralling.
Menacingly entertaining.
Even though this offers poignant insights into childlike incomprehension and trust, it's less effective as a treatise on the cyclical nature of violence and the state of the modern world.
A rare glimpse at the hardslogging realities of country life.
Returning to his recurrent themes of the desensitising impact of urban life and the hopelessness of love, Antonioni presents his bleakest portrait of the modern age ...

This delicately played picture remains poignant and astute.
Polished, but lacking in scandalous tragedy.
Lacks the necessary perspicacity, objectivity and trenchancy.
Despite its sketchiness, this offers a vivid insight into the rejuvenation of a decaying city through fury, activism and music.
This spends more time on the tensions between the dominant trio than their landmark campaigning.
Even cineastes with a good working knowledge of Pier Paolo Pasolini's life and works are going to struggle to navigate this capriciously intricate account of his final days in November 1975.
The provocative themes ultimately get lost in the surfeit of overwrought emotions.
Providing an intimate insight into the realities behind the headlines, this provocative and compassionate study is both timely and essential viewing.
A superb combination of genre movie and Truffaut's special brand of perfectly observed, humanist detail.
movie_title: Shoot the Piano Player (Tirez sur le pianiste) (1962)

movie_review_blurb: The leads have a potent chemistry, which is reinforced by the tantalising flashbacks and the refusal to embrace linearity or the male gaze.
Tirard never hits the right balance between slapstick, sentiment and social satire.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The excellent cast makes up for Pollack's occasional lapses in pacing.
Bjorkman makes solid use of the family archive to focus on the Swedish star's personal travails, while Alicia Vikander reads poignantly from her letters and diaries.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As ever, Cousins draws on an impressive range of influences, but this feels more accessible than some of his earlier odysseys.
Not since Thomas O'Malley got that wanderlust in Disney's The Aristocats (1970) has the life of a street cat seemed so idyllic.
Telling an unfamiliar tale in a highly predictable manner, this is a laudable, but lightweight tribute to golf's founding fathers.
Admirably conveys the chaos and waste of warfare.
This intricate but accessible study seeks to put a human face on the 2008 credit crunch and its aftermath.

The by-play between the stars is riveting, with Deneuve boldly playing against type as a gluttonous, gambling harridan. Moreover, it's good to see a film exploring midlife ennui from a female perspective for a change.
If you can excuse the sight of the then 35-year-old David Bowie in a school uniform, this will prove most rewarding.
This is less a re-creation of an historical event than a lament for the passing of traditional forms of cinema.
movie_title: The Death of Louis XIV (La mort de Louis XIV) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Assiduously controlled and impeccably played, this cunningly convoluted thriller keeps both the protagonist and the viewer guessing until the slickly cynical climax.
The sense of place is as assured as the vigilant performances, while the defusing sequences are genuinely suspenseful.
Sinuously photographed by Benjamin Pritchard, this will have your head spinning for days.
The film combines sparkling dialogue with moments of unbearable tension.
Cousteau lived an exciting, if sometimes tortuous life. But, while it's engagingly played by a solid cast, this respectful but hardly revelatory account lacks the narrative potency to recreate it.

Having taken such pains to establish Tom's Finnish background and its attendant dangers, Karukoski hurtles through the sketchy American section without exploring any of its crucial issues in sufficient depth.
Sometimes content matters more than quality, and this sincere, humanist drama demands to be seen, as it's as much about the state of our nation as Ken Loach's I, Daniel Blake.
Works surprisingly well ...
The action meanders occasionally, while some of the symbolism is overloaded. But getting the film made at all in the face of increasing censorship is remarkable.
By juxtaposing the monochrome talking heads with colour snapshots of life on the road, the co-directors convey something of the agony and ecstasy of a potentially soul-destroying vocation.
With its bestial themes, conceptual humour and cartoonish thespians, this consciously arch farce will intrigue some and infuriate others.

This acute insight into sporting sacrifice, the price of celebrity, the appeal of the underdog and the hierarchical nature of Finnish society... an unforced nouvelle vague feel that places it in the front rank of boxing pictures.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This intelligently scripted and imposingly played costume noir revisits the conventions of Victorian melodrama to comment on modern attitudes to oppression, prejudice and morality.

Television has done much to diminish the mystique of the hospital saga, but Katell Quillévéré restores its lustre and basic sense of humanity in this sensitive but gripping adaptation of Maylis de Kerangal's bestseller.
Amoo boldly attempts to explore the social, economic and political aspects of gentrification with this freewheeling docudrama.
While cinematographer Christos Karamanis's contrasts between the sun-kissed seascapes and the tawdry nightclubs remain acute, the tonal shift in the final reel is decidedly resistible.
The archive footage is fascinating, as are Burden's reticent insights into art posing questions without necessarily having a purpose.

The performances are chillingly restrained, as is Fukada's forensic direction - his use of natural light makes the sombre wood-panelled interiors feel all the more oppressive as the jarring cacophony of the harmonium echoes all around.
Unflinching in its depiction of rural reality, this may be a dour drama, but it has been made with sincerity and an exceptional sense of place.
Setting several scenes in claustrophobic interiors that are cocooned by a choking haze and the din of electronic devices, Behzadi adheres closely to the conventions of Iranian feminist drama.
The only downside to this charming and disarmingly thought-provoking gem is that it lasts a mere 66 minutes. Few would complain if a sequel came along.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Echoing Miguel Martin's quiet intensity, this solemn slice of rustic realism compels until things go all tele-novelettish in the final reel.
Despite a wonderfully witty voiceover and the bullish playing of a willing ensemble, this bawdy romp consistently stumbles over its more contrived excesses.

Beautifully judged performances ... impart piquancy to this bittersweet rumination on memory, paternity, expectation and the different ways in which men and women approach the past, the present and the future.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Burley (who acts as cinematographer, too) has a fine eye and a Renoir-esque compassion for his often quixotic protagonists.
Mark Cousins is never going to be a multiplex superstar, but his distinctive brand of film essay has a way of getting under the skin.
As the duo describe how they summoned the will to keep living, it becomes abundantly clear that the scars have never healed.
A humourlessly misfiring blend of sci-fi erotica and social critique that is all the more frustrating because its intelligence has been compromised by self-indulgence.
A treat for children, thanks to the astonishing performances of its animal cast
Filmed on a modest budget with a subtle sense of place and pace, this highly impressive debut considers mortality with a wry compassion that's rare for such a young director.
Nyoni opts for an elliptical approach that occasionally confuses, but Mulubwa's exceptional impassivity and David Gallego's unsettlingly striking imagery help keep this focused and fascinating.
Brea certainly puts on a brave face in exposing her travails. But there's no self-pity in this admirable plea for medical science to take this cruel illness and its "missing millions" seriously.

As labours of love go, it's peerless and the way the co-directors slip some 130 Van Gogh canvases into the action often feels inspired. But, as biography, this audacious project is somewhat unreliable.
Pacho Velez and Sierra Pettengill have blown a glorious opportunity to explore the extent to which presentation matters more than content when it comes to presidential pronouncements.

Merging Catholic hagiography and Portuguese folklore with his own personal journey, Rodrigues presents a liltingly lyrical but always demanding tract that bears the imprint of both Luis Buñuel and Apichatpong Weerasethakul.
Marbled with melancholy, this is an intelligent meditation on gender, age and body image.
While it may not always be expressed cogently and can occasionally feel a touch New Age, the message of this tranquil, sincere and sensitively made documentary is unquestionably worth heeding.
movie_title: Tawai: A voice from the forest (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This deft delight resolutely refuses to patronise the performers or the audience. It has a sincerity, wit and compassion that recalls Justin Edgar's 2005 short film Special People.
Exploring workers' rights in an age of mechanisation and recession, this isn't always an easy watch. But it's played with spirit, filmed with integrity and is pleasingly full of surprises.
movie_title: The Nothing Factory (A Fábrica de Nada) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This baroque bonanza fascinates on so many levels that it demands to be repeatedly viewed and reviewed.
Writer/director Gary Sinyor spent over a decade developing this unsettling thriller, which overcomes the odd plot blip to provide some poignant insights into the psychological consequences of grief.
Uncertain but uplifting.
Demonstrating the consequences of indulging a culture built on myths and conspiracy theories, this is a compelling portrait of a war hero who epitomises many Middle American concerns and convictions.

Lupino draws a performance of crackling malevolence from William Talman, as the serial killer physically and mentally scarred by his abusive childhood. Equally authentic is the impotent terror of weekend fishermen Edmond O'Brien and Frank Lovejoy.
This is a worthy tribute to the vibrance and sheer doggedness of the people it depicts.

Many will have wondered what happened to the veteran Cuban musicians profiled in Wim Wenders's 1998 cult classic, Buena Vista Social Club, and Lucy Walker provides some of the answers in this genial if fitful documentary sequel.

A whistlestop tour of the history of a part of London that has become synonymous with sin and subversion. But the focus quickly shifts to the threat posed by property developers and fast-food franchises.
Edouard Deluc's account of Paul Gauguin's first expedition to French Polynesia doesn't just gloss over the artist's flaws, it airbrushes them out of a story that bears little resemblance to reality.
Although maybe a little naive in places, this is an unflinching record of a cry of anguish that has to be heard and acted upon. Everyone needs to see this.
Accessible, inspirational and utterly fascinating.
The youthful leads are eminently engaging, while the eccentric interludes involving body-piercings, hallucinatory puppets and a toy keyboard are dourly amusing.

Deneuve is utterly beguiling in a movie shifting between dream and reality with such deft sleights of hand that we are never sure whether we are watching episodes from Séverine's life or sharing her fantasies.
As one might expect with a former cinematographer calling the shots, the camerawork keeps the audience at the heart of the action.
Andrew Shulkind does a solid job of lighting Jessee J Clarkson's creepy sets. But the direction is manipulative and smug.
Till's second feature is not only notable for its attitude to disability, but also for its casting of differently able actors.
Director Jon Gunn's sincere, but uninspired adaptation of Lee Strobel's best-selling memoir primarily preaches to the converted.
[An] intriguing overview of the origins of Iraq.
As much about dealing with the pain of parting as an artistic memoir, this is a bittersweet delight.
Veering between scenes of unflinching savagery and psychological malady, Enyedi makes some pertinent points about the alienating nature of modern urban living.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: The performances are impressive, especially that of Khan, who steals every scene he is in from his more famous co-stars.

Far too downbeat for the festive season.

A fascinating life is reduced to a series of skittishly edited and visually stylised vignettes that do scant justice to Marie Curie's scientific achievements and Karolina Gruszka's laudably intense performance.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The three leads poignantly convey the stress of living each day in fear and frustration.
Despite a strong central performance this is undermined somewhat by melodramatic plotting and gauche characterisation.
[A] fascinating, if formulaic insight into the overthrow of Mohamed Morsi's "Muslim Brotherhood" government in July 2013.
