At its heart this is a study of how people caught up in the legal process must navigate the formalities while retaining hope and humanity. To that end, the everyday details are deftly observed and the performances, exemplary.
Good intentions can't keep this stab at social realism from descending into maudlin melodrama.
Conrad Veidt is mesmerising as the concert pianist living on his nerves after his shattered hands are replaced with those of a murderer.
Poignant and pertinent, perhaps, but ultimately somewhat self-satisfied.

While the instances of "squirrel-busting" and intimidation by counter-surveillance are unsettling and Theroux clearly gets under Miscavige's skin, he offers few fresh insights into Scientology or its methodologies.
One of the key films in the development of expressionist cinema.
Although its whodunnit aspect is weak, the strong camera angles and cast performance make this a fine film.
Sluizer inexorably and expertly draws us deeper into the mystery, exposing our own morbid curiosity in the process.
This is a fascinating subject and Shen's heart is clearly in the right place. But a touch more wit, warmth and wonder would not have gone amiss.
Notwithstanding a climactic lapse into melodrama, this is an emotionally raw record of the breakdown of a very modern marriage.

While Herzog is right to express concerns about the possibility of civilisation being taken over by machines, he is most worried about humanity's capacity for collective folly and the abnegation of responsibility for its very future.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Depicting a courageous fight back with compassion and sincerity, this capably played drama has its heart firmly in the right place.
Rising to the challenge of doing something new(ish) with an overworked sub-genre, this may not be particularly scary or funny. But it belies its modest budget to splatter to knowing effect.
[An] affecting study of independence and friendship.
Played with restraint and individuality by a fine ensemble, this is a moving but provocative study of belief, duty, compassion and acceptance.
There is evocative use of the scenery in Cork and Africa, doing justice to the colourful flora, but in the end, this lacks its heroine's free spirit.
Impossible to appreciate in a single sitting, this masterly piece of polemical filmmaking is as intoxicating as it is intriguing.
Writer/director director Rachel Lang fleshes out two acclaimed short films to make her big screen debut with this fun, freewheeling rite of passage story.
Amalric is a fine director in his own right and his performances on either side of the camera ensure this is mesmerising and unsettling.
This always cleaves closer to BritCrime than social realism and contains its quota of stereotypes, clichés and contrivances.
Abu-Assad deftly intercuts authentic footage with reconstruction as the tension builds to the grand final. But, for all its feel-good appeal, this is less substantial than his earlier outings.

Filled with striking and scarringly disconcerting images of vandalised nature, satanic mills and redundant modernity, this is a mournful tribute to a maligned migrant workforce and a sobering reminder that nothing comes cheap.
Parodying the whodunit and the country house farce, this gleefully deranged romp is undeniably a head-scratcher. But it's also bold, witty and rewarding.
An engaging if sometimes pedestrian adaptation of the Arthur Ransome children's novel.
Hoover is careful to balance Mokhnenko's tough-love philanthropy and hot-dog-guzzling geniality with his messianic egotism ...
The potency of this depiction, with its powder-keg tensions, starts with an unflinching approach behind the camera.
The animation isn't particularly sophisticated, but the ideas certainly are.
The script loses its necessary sense of dread and fails to mine the pyschological depths of a woman now glaringly aware of the spousal faults she had been willing to ignore during the good times.

[An] intellectually playful and slyly subversive treatise on communication, freedom, identity and chaos that pays homage to a range of literary and cinematic influences, including Wojciech Has, Jacques Rivette and Luis Buñuel.
The clash between police helicopters and a hijacked blimp is the highlight of the outstanding set pieces -- it's the sort of thing that Frankenheimer can do with one hand tied behind his back.
Full of fine musical moments and sparky domestic banter, this unveiling of the unexpectedly sweet side of a famously inert pop icon should intrigue more than devoted Numanoids.
movie_title: Gary Numan: Android in La La Land (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Taut, tense and teasing, this fascinating exercise in screen storytelling keeps viewers guessing whether the prime suspect might just be a victim.
Well-meaning, sobering, but imperfect.
A resistible chauvinism colours the jokes about female reading habits and, even though the middle-class gents have the tables turned on them, this always feels a touch parochial and smug.

It hardly helps that in seeking to channel their inner Withnail & I, Winder and Bennett struggle to register against their scene-stealing co-stars or that Al Joshua's loquaciously episodic script makes so few expository compromises.

While her sense of pace and place is assured, director Anne Fontaine continues to lay great emphasis on performance and Kulesza particularly repays her faith with a chilling display of misplaced piety.
Atmospheric and engrossing, this meticulous recreation of time and place acquires an unsettling contemporary relevance through its analysis of the mindset of a mass murderer with a death wish.
Intimate, oppressive and persuasively played, it's a film that nimbly shifts perspective to capture the impact of transition on ordinary lives.
movie_title: United States of Love (Estados Unidos de Amor) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Atmospherically designed and photographed in arresting long takes, this often makes for gruelling viewing, especially when the heavy metal soundtrack kicks in.
Slickly made, but too arch to be genuinely revealing.
[A] handsome and heartfelt study of the America neglected by the cosmopolitan elite.
Played with committed ferocity by the excellent Oh and Heche, this riotous state-of-the-nation satire may lack subtlety, but it has the courage of its socko convictions and certainly packs a punch.
Wonderfully evocative of time and place, this considered assault on Brazil's economic and ethical crises revolves around a majestic performance by Sonia Braga.
While this heartfelt dramedy is never less than engaging, Bollain and Laverty's conviction that idealistic youth can haul society back from the abyss sadly feels a touch naive.
The plot is more than a little contrived ...
This teasingly elliptical melodrama is more a psychological study of loneliness and the need for love than it is a generic shocker.
Although replete with creepy shocks, this lacks the narrative finesse to match the committed performances and slick visuals.

Echoes of Michael Haneke's Hidden and Cristi Puiu's Aurora reverberate around this lament for those Romanians whose dreams have been betrayed by the nation's failure to slip the shackles of its sinister past.
This is both a fitting tribute to a brave man and his committed team, and a thoughtful insight into comedy's duty to speak truth to power.
It's impressive and provocative film-making, but ultimately the dispassion and the pessimism may render you little more than a detached observer.
For those who love obscure European cinema this is one of the true masterpieces.
The primary allure lies in the way Gavin keeps us guessing - is Walker imagining the increasingly creepy occurrences during her gruelling ordeal, has Oram stage-managed them or are they real?
What leaves the deepest impression is Baldwin's unheeded warnings.
While Bellocchio organises the non-linear material with customary aplomb, his psychological insights are as unconvincing as the old-age make-up worn by Guido Caprino as Mastrandrea's detached father.
The plot pieces might slot into place with a resounding clang, but what it lacks in finesse, this brutal actioner more than makes up for in bullish bravura and technical slickness.
A tale of star-crossed love that is as poignant as the insights are acute into vanishing tradition and the changing status of women.
[A] tepid farce ...
Has its share of shuddersome moments.

Ree does what he can to fathom the mind of an inscrutable youth, but he struggles to delve too deeply into Magnus's personal life or psyche, while his distinctive approach to strategy remains a closely guarded secret.
Good as Emilia Fox is ... it's Spall's bluff charm and unexpected resourcefulness that keeps the film as rooted in reality as cinematographer Eben Bolter's seascapes.
A poetic tribute to African culture, the oral tradition and the spirit of the Gullah people.
This account of a doctor trying to salve her conscience after an understandable professional misjudgement often feels conventionally melodramatic.
A touch twee at times, but the use of classic and original animation is admirable, while Owen emerges as the king of sidekicks.
Brisk, witty, devotional and unabashedly intellectual, this is a deadpan delight.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Heady stuff, not for the faint-hearted.
This bullishly played saga has enough quirky detail, audacious incident and visual panache to sweep the storyline through its less persuasive phases.
It's the bromantic banter between the hapless, but touchingly steadfast heroes and the moments of bleakly bruising slapstick that make this impeccably paced saga so genial and enjoyable.
Fails to conjure up any sense of suspense.
Persuasively played by fine leads and a well-cast ensemble, this thoughtful treatise captures provincial life and the medical mindset with authenticity and tact.
The makers have clearly thought about what a future reversion to twentieth century-style tyranny would look like, and the design, anthems and details all ring true.
Impeccably played by Rebecca Hall, this is a thoughtful reflection on life's casual cruelties and how little attitudes towards women have changed since Watergate.

Exploring corporate sexism, the decline in business ethics, the EU's betrayal of the post-Communist bloc and communication in the mobile age, this playful screwball comedy has plenty to say about the state of the continent.
Photographed like an art film and hauntingly scored by Flying Lotus, this conceptually bold treatise on love touches hearts and minds alike.
Ruinously prioritising chic over content, this is intellectually and stylistically shallow when it should have been dynamic and compelling.
A gripping study of treachery, identity and survival.
The film certainly succeeds in generating a mood of claustrophobic menace, but the dramatic elements are too often clumsily realised.
Screenwriter Andy Bloom struggles to sustain the tensions between the holed-up thugs, with much of the talented supporting cast having too little to do.
Neatly structured and full of genuine warmth for its characters, Richard Curtis's Oscar-nominated screenplay is superbly observed and well served by Mike Newell's deft direction.
A romantic-comedy that isn't funny or romantic.
This slickly scripted, knowingly played and cameo-strewn comedy stands on its merits as an Alfie for the millennial generation.
Although the prime influence on Lee's stately style and several of the film's themes is the Japanese genius Yasujiro Ozu, there is more than a hint of Woody Allen in this complex ensemble comedy.
movie_title: Eat Drink Man Woman (Yin shi nan nu) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Combining blimpish bluster with moments of monstrous ego and unexpected humanity, Scott makes this magnificent film unforgettable.
A fly-on-the-wall look at the band that will thrill fans but may not convert too many non-believers.
movie_title: Lamb Of God's As The Palaces Burn (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A timeless musical treat and the most fun you can have with really elegant clothes on.
A sparse and languid Italian thriller that carries a debt to Melville.
A solid music doc that will please fans and newcomers alike.
Although this is drastically different compared to the rest of Godard's oeuvre, it has without a doubt had a lasting impact with its ground-breaking visuals.
Charming and whimsical, it's a feast for the eyes.
Their various trials and tribulations make for sturdy docusoap-style viewing.
This is as deliciously romantic and ingeniously mischievous as cinema gets.
The film is elevated by committed performances, and Bandele stages set-pieces, like a wedding under shellfire, with cinematic flair.
Broomfield has always employed a blend of charm and innocence to expose the frailties of his subjects. But here that tactic somewhat backfires.
Malle made his feature directorial debut with this assured thriller, which recalled both the poetic realism of Marcel Carné and the brooding menace of American films noirs.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: A mighty, ageless jolt of teen petulance. Dean is supreme.
Those who don't often delve into the avant-garde and left-field film-making may struggle to warm to this atypical love story but there's no denying Nance has a distinctive voice.
Director Harold Ramis uses every cinematic trick in the book to keep what is essentially a one-gag movie brimming with life and fresh ideas.
It's Rahimi's courage as both writer and director that makes this intense and perceptive picture so unflinchingly compelling.
Tim Allen made his feature debut in this engaging yuletide comedy, which is likely to appeal to the whole family and brims over with plenty of good ideas.
This is easily the best screen version of the much loved yuletide tale.
Powerful and mesmerising, this offers an fresh approach to a tough topic.
Cloddy period stodge.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Charmingly animated but a little unfuelled in its plotting.
One of the most visually arresting pictures of recent years.
It's a small film, but a quietly affecting one as well.
A laudably even-handed examination of a highly charged subject.
This is a cogent and courageous account of a complex and continuing situation.
A snappy, quirky German indie that will thrill fans of early Jim Jarmusch.
This is a marvel from beginning to end.
What could so easily have become something false and tacky is handled with truth and restraint.
Complemented by its black-and-white photography and a moody DJ Shadow score, this is a gritty yet often tender look at society's margins.
Gently moving and subtly powerful, this will thrill Francophiles.
Amadeus is simply one of the finest biographical dramas ever made.
An fascinating, honest look at teenage jealousies.
Not a laugh riot by any means but there's plenty of tenderness and heart in this vignette of rural life.
movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Director Stewart Raffill's film is otherwise an unashamed rip-off of Spielberg's classic.
Putting a face on inhuman misery, this remarkable achievement demonstrates film's unique power and its underperformed duty.
With its stately pace and obscure references to mythology and contemporary events, the film requires patience. But its power and intelligence more than repay the effort.
Alexander's script deftly captures the sense of community that prompts strangers to make the effort to communicate with each other or do good deeds.
For all its black comedic bravura, this is a touch too self-conscious to amuse, provoke or convince.
Vividly shot, this is a strange and seductive portmanteau of Icelandic tales.
A folksy but charming celebration of communal life.
As meticulous as one of Claudel's sculptures, Hors Satan director Dumont and his star do this true-life story justice with an empathetic telling.
Fitfully amusing and poignant in its insights into ageing, this cross-generational fling saga lacks the character and depth to say anything genuinely significant.
It's just a pity that the three martial arts kids are so charmless.
Val Kilmer does, however, pull off a remarkable impression of the troubled vocalist, although he's more convincing on stage than he is in his drunken, drug-fuelled reveries.
Sadly, in common with so many non-Disney cartoons, the standard of the songs is poor and the animation lacks magic.
If you can get your head round the idea of Julia Roberts as a ruthlessly ambitious newspaper reporter, then there's plenty to enjoy in this frivolous comedy thriller.
A fine performance from Fanny Ardant elevates Marion Vernoux's intriguing if rarely riveting study of late-life passion.
There's the hallmarks of a decent thriller in the set-up, and Peake is terrific, but the execution is purest hooey.
A ferocious, devastating doc and a must-see for anyone seeking an insider's view of the Syrian uprising.
A leisurely paced but interesting hook on technology, memory and love.
The performances as a whole are a joy and the script is a gem.
The death of Hetherington in Libya imbues this Restrepo follow-up with pathos - as do the brutal conditions endured by its subjects.
A smart, thoughtful piece of work. Recommended.
Kirk Douglas and Timothy Carey are outstanding among the troops on the front line, while Kubrick's relentlessly probing camera offers constant evidence of a film-maker at the height of his powers.
The Coop mannerisms aren't really suited to Gehrig, but he gives a typically sympathetic performance alongside Wright and real-life stars such as Babe Ruth.
This fantasy drama from director Phil Alden Robinson is a delightful blend of the blind-fate story and the more fanciful feel-good corn of Frank Capra.
Rhys contrasts the fate of spoken Welsh with such dying First American languages as Mandan, and, more soberingly, learns much about the connection between heroic exploration and colonial subjugation.
This captures many moving moments and atmospheres in the diverse settings, bu the narrative arc isn't quite as engaging as it could be.
Forte and Peake excel in a notable debut from Green that marks her out as a director to watch.
Worse films than this have been smashes, so give it a spin.
A fun and frothy mock-doc with a message buried in its axle.
The documentary footage of a decimated Berlin is still enormously powerful, especially when compared to the coverage of that other vanquished, but unscathed, capital in Rome, Open City.
Hou Hsiao-Hsien's subtle compositions and meticulous pacing draw the viewer into the heart of the drama.
movie_title: Bei qing cheng shi (A City of Sadness) (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Densely symbolic, yet never inaccessible, this is artistically unique and overwhelmingly powerful.
A sprawling study of sexual politics and smug 1960s intellectualism, Jean Eustache's masterpiece was the last hurrah of the French New Wave.
movie_title: The Mother and the Whore (La Maman et la putain) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Bresson's most earnest film is also his least engaging.
Much maligned on its release, this mesmerising picture was subsequently hailed as one of the most remarkable achievements of a brilliant career.
A road trip movie filled with simple pleasures. Ashmore does a solid job as a mariachi musician without a single grenade-launcher in his guitar case.
Lacks the raw gusto of the book but beautifully played by its two leads.
Superbly controlled and stylishly self-reflexive, this is also genuinely intriguing.
The sheer presence of Garbo in this startlingly profound performance it completely and utterly mesmerizing, and an experience that can't really be done justice on the small screen.
A maddeningly unquestioning look at a retail citadel.
Co-writer Jean-Claude Carrière was Buñuel's screenwriter and this stark story of a life at odds with a society's laws bears the hallmarks of his earlier work.
The movie is often heady, and occasionally woolly, but always enjoyable.
It may feel more like pulp than art house, but it still maintains its grip, bound together by a score composed by Nick Cave, among others.
A fan-pleasing snapshot of a musical great at the peak of his powers.
Slightly jerry-built reconstructions detract from an intriguing film with a unique angle on the country legend.
movie_title: My Father and the Man in Black (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In creating the characters Thelma and Louise for this hugely entertaining and controversial road movie, Oscar-winning scriptwriter Callie Khouri put women in the driving seat for the first time.
This hilarious tale of criminal incompetence and transatlantic eccentricity is easily John Cleese's finest achievement since Fawlty Towers.

After watching this sizzling crime thriller, you will be at a loss to explain why director Jim McBride failed to go on and take Hollywood by storm. At least the careers of Dennis Quaid and Ellen Barkin were boosted.
This is riotous fun throughout.
The film retains the gothic atmosphere of the book and looks amazing, thanks to Roger Deakins's scintillating photography. Stealing the show is Maggie Smith as beastly housekeeper Mrs Medlock.
This is, quite simply, one of the finest films ever made in the genre.

Ultimately, it lacks the resonance of such classics as All Quiet on the Western Front, but this is still well-meaning, strongly acted and slickly mounted, and ranks among the director's very best films.

This blatant, unacknowledged reworking of The Prince and the Pauper is a rattling comedy showcase for the unique talents of Eddie Murphy and Dan Aykroyd, who have seldom recaptured the form they show here.
This feathered pastiche of PoW classics such as The Great Escape and Stalag 17 is an awesome achievement by consummate film-makers.
Another Ray work of deceptive simplicity and deep-lying emotion.
The drama simmers gently, as Kurdish-Austrian director Umut Dag handles his debut feature with assurance.
Milland's sinister sophistication catches the eye, but Kelly's subtly shaded suffering is superb.

The Birth of a Nation has become a staple of any film studies course, for its excellent performances, thrilling action sequences and epic landscapes. However it's subject matter is much more controversial now.

Some of the archive footage is exceedingly harrowing, but the case against commercially condoned cruelty is made without sensationalism, and few will be able to watch this without a growing sense of outrage.
Wonderfully complex but warmly human, Bergman's drama is one of his very best.
It's a film that demands to be watched again and again -- this is good old-fashioned pulp fiction told in the slickest 1990s style.
As an exercise in conveying place, mood and human foible, this is consistently intriguing.
The courage shown by Neil and the devoted and wondrously patient Louise is not only humbling, but also genuinely moving and quietly heroic.
Brash, abrasive and unrelenting, this is a must-see.
The ambiguity of how the drama plays out only enhances the fascination of this intimate, intense but always discreet dissection of antiquated patriarchal custom.
Bold and beautiful, this is a mystery worth puzzling over.
A sometimes over-simplified but often affecting look at forbidden love.
Joel Schumacher's lamentable tear-jerker is a crass crossbreed of Love Story and Pretty Woman.
Clever and compassionate.
Despite being innovatively directed and punchily edited, as a genre piece this is lacking in depth and genuine dread.
Cogent but restrained in its politicking, The Moo Man contains plenty of wit, wisdom and compassion, as well as much bucolic charm.

What makes this so entrancing is Berger's mastery of image and tone, and the wondrous combination of glistening monochrome cinematography, evocative production design, glorious costumes and an exceptional score from Alfonso de Vilallonga.
As simple and charming as you could wish for, this is a genuinely pioneering debut from a female Saudi filmmaker and a striking piece of work by any standards.
Impassioned and disturbing, this doc matches The Cove for marrying cool intellect with real fire.
Despite Hitchcock's own reservations this is definitely worth a look. Interesting to his aficionados and darkly funny and depressing in turns.
Gunnar Fischer's photography becomes ever more luminous and Sjöström's performance grows in greatness.
For all its faults, this still has moments of hip charm.
Informative and occasionally scary.
For all its commitment and compassion, Cumming's performance always feels as embellished as his climactic torch songs.
Why must film-makers always be such slaves to the lowest common denominator?
The filmmaker firebrand is in pungent form as he dismantles the hypocrisy of Australia's treatment of its indigenous peoples.
More extravagant, but less controlled than his infamous allegorical western, El Topo.

In exploring the transience of happiness and the injustice of patriarchal society, Mizoguchi makes lyrical use of gliding long takes that reinforce his material and mystical themes. It's a work of sheer genius.
It's Joanna Lumley and Miriam Margolyes as the ghastly Spiker and Sponge who steal this wonderfully pantomimic show.
This remains a wonderfully inventive comedy that brilliantly debunks the Dark Ages and legends of chivalry.
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: The action is flashy and intermittent, deliberately wallowing in a mire of revisionist grot, churned up vistas of European mud. Time has made it more intuitive and caustic a film, than its daft reputation might suggest.

With interiors that owe much to the paintings of Doré and Vermeer, this visual feast is enhanced by the magical realism of Henri Alekan's photography, Christian Bérard's exquisite costumes and Georges Auric's audacious score.
movie_title: Beauty and The Beast (La Belle et la bête) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: It's cartoon Cocteau, but just look at the children's faces as they watch it.
Bizarre, brilliant, but wayward in its dénouement.
Even if this is only a reverie on the illogicality of the subconscious, it's still a triumph of the imagination and provides invaluable insights into Cocteau's artistic vision.
Solidly played but the pieces audibly clunk into place.
Hard-hitting stuff and tough medicine for American foreign policy loyalists.
Well-intentioned but clunky.
Director Hayao Miyazaki's insistence on hand-drawn graphics gives the CGI visuals an ethereal charm that ensures the story is always a pleasure to behold, even during its rare moments of inaction.
This masterpiece from Frank Capra still has a lot to say about community spirit and is a film with much more to it than feel-good sentimentality.
A largely dour romantic drama, hampered by thrusting non-actors into challenging lead roles.
A moving treatment of a deeply personal subject (France's own partner died of an AIDS-related illness in 1992), and an enthralling depiction of a seriously fired-up popular movement.
Alternating between intimacy and intrusion, this is a revealing, affectionate and occasionally charming insight into a creative partnership.
A beguiling and often moving treatise on the relationship between art and life.
Shot in magisterial black-and-white, veteran director Trueba's drama is a welcome return from the Belle Epoque man.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Bond rightly concentrates on the new material and Ant's new persona, the Blueblack Hussar, whose live shows are splendidly eclectic and occasionally electrifying.
Interesting, occasionally ramshackle story of grand ambition and crisis.
movie_title: Folie à Deux - madness made of two (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling, complex and wonderfully atmospheric film from Mexican director Guillermo del Toro that is as much about religion and the nature of cinema as it is a horror story.
Ealing will for ever be associated with its celebrated comedies, but this chilling quintet deserves to be considered among the studio's finest achievements.
Unsurprisingly, considering the circumstances, this is less a meticulous study of photojournalist's art than an privileged and emotional look at the life of a friend and colleague.
movie_title: Which Way Is the Front Line from Here? The Life and Times of Tim Hetherington (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Adroit performances abound in this ex-pat tale. Archipelago DP Ed Rutherford helps add to the Joanna Hogg-y feel, but this lacks the disquieting insights of Hogg's work.
Produced by Val Lewton and directed by the great Jacques Tourneur, this was one of the first Hollywood horrors to play on the audience's fears rather than expose it to ghouls and monsters.
The film bristles with menace as it draws you inexorably towards its chilling conclusion.
Neatly parodying Hitchcock and John Hughes movies, writer/director Tom Holland litters his rattling story with as many laughs as jolts.
If not quite on the level of Garbus's terrific Bobby Fischer documentary, this is still filled with fond recollections of Mazza's life and career. Fans will relish it.
Charming and quirky, this is an often whimsical look at a grave and scary subject.
Cary Grant et al are on sparkling form in this classic darkly twisted comedy.
Great chemistry between the two great comic leads and some pretty decent one-liners but this doesn't manage to hold together as a feature-length concept.
The mesmerising García and sensitive direction by Lelio light up this delicate yet spiky drama. Terrific stuff from both Chileans.
The success of this superb adaptation of HG Wells's novel is down to John P Fulton and John J Mescall's pioneering special effects and the eerie atmosphere conjured up by horror maestro James Whale.
Now practically an exile from his homeland, Kiarostami follows Certified Copy with another film-literate relationship drama with the enigmatic overtones of Hitchcock.
The performances are spirited and touching and cinematographer María Secco expertly frames the vulnerable youngsters against various hostile environments.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As funny and charming as its subject, this is manna for Otway's devoted fans.
movie_title: Rock and Roll's Greatest Failure: Otway the Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A strange story that's no less disturbing for its unbalanced telling.
Low key but charming.
For all its melancholy charm, this never delves deeply enough into issues like loss, loneliness, memory and healing before tying up the loose ends a tad too neatly.

Superb camerawork ably captures the energy of the diverse activities taking place within this distinctive circular building ... but it's the wonderful sound mix that best conveys the immediacy and intimacy that makes radio so unique.
Rinko Kikuchi's superb core performance and some striking photography stand out in the latest feature from the Zellner Brothers.
An insightful examination of racism, homophobia and identity in Latin America.
Actress Iram Haq makes a solid directorial debut with this tale of clashing cultures.
A daring, dark satire strewn with allusions to modern times.

The desensitising nature of popular culture is a theme that recurs throughout most of Michael Haneke's films, but rarely has it been more chillingly debated than in this almost nonchalant study of dysfunction and death.
While Frears's is truer to the calculating spirit of the book and has the showier cast, Forman's has greater human interest and the more heartfelt performances.
Charming performances from both leads and insightful vignettes makes up for occasional clumsy writing and plot developments.
Exasperatingly trite, but also rather sweet.

Although writer/producer/director Leo McCarey bagged three Oscars for this effortless piece of Catholic whimsy, its enduring charm rests with the Oscar-winning performances of Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald.
Courageous and indelible account and an invaluable perspective of the protests.
Belarusian director Sergei Loznitsa returns to his documentary roots for this mesmerising account of the events that transformed the Ukraine between November 2013 and February 2014.

Lanzmann draws on unused footage of a 1975 interview in Rome with Viennese rabbi Benjamin Murmelstein to assess his role as the sole surviving member of the Jewish Council installed by the Nazis to help run the Theresienstadt ghetto camp.
Only the slightly muddled structure detracts from what is otherwise an audacious cinematic experiment.
Ambitious, but doesn't quite hit the mark.
A mesmerising look at the great gallery at work.
Some of the most disconcerting imagery involves the casual racism of white Africans in British outposts like Rhodesia, where the inferiority of the black majority was taken as read.
The use of a static camera for the majority of the vignettes imposes a stylistic rigour to match the religious intransigence.
A powerful and provoking take on a violent and volatile era.
It's not among the studio's best, but it's certainly well worth watching.
An interesting idea with a dignified central performance, Bonobo is let down by supporting characterisation and a self-conscious tone.
A fun and insightful slice of Roman life. Next up, M25: The Movie?
Distilled from 700 hours of footage shot over several years and laced with rare archive material, this may be slick cine-advocacy, but it is also undeniably potent and poignant.
The term "melodrama" is rarely used as a compliment, but writer/director Robin Campillo goes some way to reclaiming it with this four-act saga that switches tone and direction with assurance.
[An] eccentric but unexpectedly touching drama.
An endlessly inventive picture that blends 1960s psychedelia with such diverse styles as pop art and Art Deco to create the fantastical world of Pepperland and its bizarre inhabitants.
A Spanish take on Snow White that picks up where The Artist left off and shows the full elegance of silent filmmaking.
Sturges' no-holds-barred comic cristicism of American Forces abroad is still challenging and funny.
The playing from all three stars is enjoyable and the festive setting allows Grant to trim a Christmas tree with the flick of a finger.
Nostalgic and charming romance with special moments in the extra-narrative action.
This witty adult fairy tale, set in the heart of the callous city, is a joy to behold thanks to the naturalism of its performances and the sublime subtlety of its direction.
The 89 year-old director has lost none of his bold inquisitiveness in a Shoah follow-up that plunges the viewer deep into the hustle and anguish of the Czech ghetto.
Curious allegorical epic which was supposed to speak to Allied spirits during the second world war but was a trifle obscure in its symbolism even then.
The quality of this acerbic study of life in a Korean War field hospital has been too often overlooked because of the popularity of the TV series it spawned.
A bit theatrical in places, which is not surprising when you consider its provenance but it suffers for it.
With quirky support from Will Patton's caustic mechanic and Walter Dalton's sympathetic security guard, this is a bittersweet triumph.

While this makes a decent introduction to a principled artist and major force in contemporary American cinema, it leaves far too many gaps about his personal and professional exploits for it to be considered definitive.

Berry delivers an uncompromising study of a tragic trend that owes much to Andrea Arnold's brand of social realism and within that, he captures the anxieties of a dead-end adolescent existence with laudable sensitivity.
Challengingly spellbinding.
Fascinating, but a failure nonetheless.
For all the doughty naturalism of the performances, the photography, editing and sound design, the film feels overly detached from the reality it is supposed to be conveying.
The argument is enervatingly imbalanced and sensationalised, so it lacks both trenchancy and authority.
A quest saga whose metaphysical digressions and dream interludes will fascinate and frustrate in equal measure.
Osmond might have delved deeper into the morality of National Hunt racing, but with editor Joby Gee she ably relates the account with archive footage, photographs and a few blurry re-constructions.
Reitz (who was in his eighties during production) directs with peerless finesse, as he mines authenticity from an inexperienced cast and brings a bygone era to vivid and engrossing life.
movie_title: Home from Home: Chronicle of a Vision (Die Andere Heimat) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Some may find all this too mannered and theatrical to intrigue, or engage, but a bit of background reading will reward those prepared to find the subtextual meaning.
Fukada shows flashes of Rohmeresque wit. But, for all his allusions to art and politics, he is currently a better image-maker (in conjunction with cinematographer Kenichi Negishi) than a storyteller.
An unassuming gem.
While much of the imagery is intimate, the reluctance to delve into crucial artistic, romantic or health issues means that this is always more affectionate than illuminating.
A charming insight into the life and art of Caroll Spinney, the puppeteer who has played Big Bird on Sesame Street since it was launched in 1969.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Every twist and shift of the mise-en-scéne adds to the complexity, ingenuity and artistic bravura of this mesmerising treatise on the refusal to be beaten by disability.
More compelling when focusing on long-serving staff and their skills and opinions.
Particularly memorable are the walking figurehead, the hideous centaur and the multi-armed statue that tests Sinbad's swordfighting skills to the maximum.
A story that's overloaded with research and unbridled speculation, all told with no clear direction.
A hauntingly beautiful film.
A sensitive, sincere and humbling profile which is truly inspirational.
Thoughtful study of how children see their parents.
A final opportunity to see a master at work in this mischievously melancholic delight.
While Mehari's motives could not be more honourable, his methods leave much to be desired.
It's Resnais's genius for making complex formal experimentation seem mischievously accessible that makes this so enjoyable. He will be much missed, but leaves a matchless legacy.
An uncompromising documentary which simply lays its subject bare and dares us not be moved by the raw humanity on display.
Puffy rather than insightful, it's a slog even for Bowie diehards.

Helped by the shimmering photography of Nicolas Roeg and hindered by a straitjacket of a script by Frederic Raphael, this laudable, lengthy adaptation of Thomas Hardy's classic novel might have benefited from a less respectful treatment.
Punishingly poetic profile filmed in breathtaking surroundings.
Well played, especially by Sandrine Kiberlain, but Jeanne Henry's film lacks consistency to be great.
Charming and touching, this film about the relationship between the widow and the trucker is a pleasant surprise.

The film's focus should have been on the way the unswervingly chauvinistic Mastroianni is forced to compromise his principles to save his marriage. But such is Barreto's fixation with Braga's body that the tone is almost risibly soft-core.
This gripping picture dating from the time when director Oliver Stone made good films rather than sensational headlines, features a tour-de-force performance from Eric Bogosian.
Ken Loach seems to acquire a surer mastery of his art with each picture, yet this, one of his earliest features, is still one of his best.
Although casting a dismissive eye over the Cinecittá ballyhoo, Antonioni is more concerned with the psychological impact of Bosé's lonely predicament.
Pacha makes no attempt to construct a narrative from their existence. Instead, she and cameraman Lutz Konermann maintain a discreet distance to capture a unique trade in mesmerising detail.
Beautifully performed by its two leads, Cycling With Molière is a comic treat.
Gert Fröbe and Orson Welles played the same parts in René Clément's sprawling epic, Is Paris Burning? (1966). But this is superior in every regard.
A painful and poignant excoriation of the American dream.
There's no satire, no farce, no wit -- just dumb utterances and whimsical slapstick.
James Stewart is superb, and Bernard Miles and Brenda de Banzie make admirable adversaries.
movie_title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1956)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of chemistry between Madden and Hall drains the film of energy and their unrequited longing is often unintentionally amusing.
This dark romantic thriller isn't as thematically complex or technically audacious as some of Alfred Hitchcock's later classics. But it's still hard to beat for pure, polished entertainment.
This sequel is less abrasive than its predecessor and was considerably less successful at the box office.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles II - The Secret of the Ooze (1991)

movie_review_blurb: Canet, who showed his aptitude with the gripping Tell No One, can't bring this dull period piece to life.
A Touch of Zen is at the same time a study of rural life, a ghost story, a discussion of philosophical ideas and a thrilling fight film, with each element being handled with rare skill by Hu.

Cleverly using camera angles to create a sense of place and parallel motifs to unify the action, Ozu reveals his directorial genius, which is confirmed by his light handling of his splendid ensemble cast.
movie_title: Nagaya shinshiroku (Record of a Tenement Gentleman) (1947)

movie_review_blurb: This is a complex and painfully honest study of a man in a personal and professional crisis.
Divided into 59 chapters but feeling more like 590, Gröning's drama is long, staccato and offers little by way of dramatic satisfaction.
movie_title: Die Frau des Polizisten (The Policeman's Wife) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Clunking and ill-executed, this a piece of art that wouldn't even make Tony Hart's gallery.
Deliberately paced and painfully sad, this may not be the ideal first-date movie but its subtle power will get under your skin.
It's the stylised beauty of [Riefenstahl's] direction that takes this simple moral fable on to a higher plane and landed her the post of Hitler's film-maker.
Beautiful and innovative -- age only adds to its brilliance and charm.
The huge potential of this all-star vehicle was mainly squandered through a lack of subtlety or irony.
It's like an Agatha Christie plot.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is a defiant assault on revisionist history that shows, through a series of harrowing flashbacks, that the crimes of the past cannot simply be buried and forgotten.
Director Seijun Suzuki outdid himself with this astonishing blend of yakuza movie, film noir and nouvelle vague.
The plot's pleasingly convoluted, the performances amusingly varied, the mood sinisterly sustained. But the set-pieces are the work of a genius.
Some of the slapstick feels forced, but Le Guay's intertextual wit is as sharp as the performances.
At a time when Elvis and Cliff were still making old-style musicals, this forerunner of the modern music video smashed the mould.
The odd gag does fall flat and Sáez's performance is an acquired taste, but the photography and music are as delightful as the premise of this low-key flight of fancy.
It's bitter, biting and brilliant.
It is exceedingly difficult to make convincing live-action versions of cult cartoon strips, and this big-screen version of the momentarily popular TV series is one of the least successful attempts.
The script is so full of old gags it must have been chiselled on stone tablets, while Stewart Raffill's direction is a model example of how not to let the action get in the way of product placements.

Godard abandoned the conventions of narrative cinema and adopted a loose picaresque format around which he could arrange subversive generic tropes, poetic digressions, political ideas and comic-book escapades.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing look at a lost voice.
Filipino maven Diaz delivers a bravura, literary human drama that does justice to its great source material.
A gripping if occasionally overwrought drama radiated by a standout turn from Seydoux.
Fifty-five years old and still a comedy masterpiece.
It's solid stuff, but too many involved seem to be marking time.
Atmospheric and visually stimulating but Josef von Sternberg's morality tale is a little thin.
It's fast, furious and funny but, even with that master of atmosphere Carol Reed as director, it could have done with a couple of fresh tricks to keep us guessing.
The kidnapping plot is inane, the slapstick inept and the cast ineffectual. All in all, mind-bogglingly bad.
Whether wondering why he survived the 1958 Munich air disaster or bantering with Georgie and team-mates, who have no idea who he is, Cox is a delight.
A surrealist fantasy of the banality and conformity of Czech society.
Anger and sadness lie at the heart of this treatise on the perpetuation of the patriarchal prejudices underpinning Turkish society.
If some of the political theorising is somewhat naive and the direction is occasionally manipulative, the acting, particularly from Juliette Binoche, is superb.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Another powerfully observed Romanian drama.
A beautiful true-life character study that does elegant justice to a largely unheralded writer.
Ambitious but only partially successful, this British character drama belongs in the 'curate's egg' bracket.
There's nothing too groundbreaking in the dramatisation of school cliques and the growing pains of teenagers, but the execution is alive with visual invention.
It's Devos's outstanding performance that ensures this compels as both cultural history and human drama.
Told mostly in flashback, this story perfectly illustrates Carné's mastery of poetic realism and Jacques Prévert's appreciation of the lyricism of everyday speech.
The sketchy storyline is overly reliant on cliché, caricature and contrivance.

Lang's preoccupation with the sights, sounds and symbolism of the railway yards too often leaves the emotions and motives of the characters (formidably played by Glenn Ford, Broderick Crawford and Gloria Grahame) stranded in the sidings.
This is a solid piece of good old-fashioned escapism.
Perhaps the most underrated of Fritz Lang's silent spectacles, this tale of master criminality has all the visceral thrill and visual atmospherics of one of Louis Feuillade's Fantomas serials.
Making moody use of light and shade, Lang ingeniously involves us more deeply than the plot merits. For all that, it's still very much a B-movie.
While perhaps overdependent on coincidence and contrivance, this deft thriller guards its secret right to the end and proved a fitting swan song to Fritz Lang's Hollywood career.
The skittishly structured storyline concocted by Troublé and Jean-Pol Fargeau becomes increasingly contrived, and they end up trivialising a serious issue.
movie_title: Je m'appelle Hmmm... (My Name Is Hmmm...) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Bound to appeal more to ABUs (Anyone But United) than fans of Old Trafford's resident football team.
This isn't just a walk down a troubled memory lane with the focus of this laudatory but never fawning picture later switching to the making of the album that caught the public imagination.
This is a compelling snapshot of Britain before the Sixties began to swing.
Consistently entertains through its emphasis on amusing anecdotes rather than hard facts.
Superbly played, designed and photographed, this is a worthy companion to Paolo Sorrentino's The Great Beauty.
A fitting tribute to a relatively unknown yet significant and influential player on the West End theatre scene.
At times, the movie comes close to hagiography. But the archive clips reveal Swartz to have been sincere, clear-thinking and selfless.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Bertolucci's superb dramatic thriller packs a powerful punch.
This is the kind of brisk, bright and thoroughly engaging comedy thriller that the British film industry has, sadly, forgotten how to make.

Despite the attention of master scriptwriter William Goldman, this gentle tribute to the hit comedy western TV series missed a golden opportunity for a razor-sharp spoof. There's no doubt the stars had a ball, though.
Such was Kuti's star power that even the Tony-nominated Sahr Ngaujah feels like an unnecessary distraction from the archive performance footage.
The delicate bond that emerges between young boys under unusual pressure is the highlight of an otherwise fairly conventional doc.
At the venerable age of 84, documentary maven Wiseman hasn't lost his touch.
A little baroque in its presentation, this is nevertheless a pungent and hard-hitting look at the events across Arabia in December 2010.
For once, Wiseman seems to be pushing a message, as he warns that a society that devalues learning will fatally undermine itself.
As startling and bleakly compelling as you'd expect from this rare combination of director and subject.
One of France's most famous novelists sportingly sends himself up in this comedy drama inspired by real-life events.
The survivors and liberators interviewed by Singer have never forgotten their experiences, and this crucial account of a dark episode in history stands as a chillingly eloquent memorial.
A sobering glimpse of reality, that's also an irresistibly involving drama.

Don Siegel emerged as more than just a Hollywood journeyman director with this hard-hitting, realistic prison picture, which presents a credible account of both the riot and the conditions that caused it.
Begins as a gently mocking comedy of small-town manners, but ends as a blazing allegorical satire on the incompetence, insularity and ideological idiocy of the country's rulers.
This is ostensibly a tribute to the Hungarian volunteers who fought with the Red Army against the pro-Tsarist Whites. But, Miklos Jancso clearly has an ironic contemporary agenda.
movie_title: Csillagosok, katonák (The Red and The White) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Jim Jarmusch's uneven but stylish comédie noire is an astute mixture of prison picture, road movie and downbeat screwball.
Hitchcock introduced the American Nightmare strain into the genre. He also revived the fast-fading art of montage with the now legendary shower sequence.
